https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/us/politics/supreme-court-eviction-ban.html/Supreme Court Rejects Request to Lift Federal Ban on Evictions/"WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday refused to lift a moratorium on evictions that had been imposed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in response to the coronavirus pandemic.
The vote was 5 to 4
column2: with Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justices Stephen G. Breyer
column3: Sonia Sotomayor
column4: Elena Kagan and Brett M. Kavanaugh in the majority.

column1: The court gave no reasons for its ruling
column2: which is typical when it acts on emergency applications. But Justice Kavanaugh issued a brief concurring opinion explaining that he had cast his vote reluctantly and had taken account of the impending expiration of the moratorium.

column1: “The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention exceeded its existing statutory authority by issuing a nationwide eviction moratorium
column2: ” Justice Kavanaugh wrote. “Because the C.D.C. plans to end the moratorium in only a few weeks
column3: on July 31
column4: and because those few weeks will allow for additional and more orderly distribution of the congressionally appropriated rental assistance funds
column5: I vote at this time to deny the application” that had been filed by landlords
column6: real estate companies and trade associations."/['Adam Liptak']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/17/us/politics/17dc-scotus-evict/17dc-scotus-evict-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/us/politics/us-afghanistan-withdrawal-airport.html/As the U.S. Pulls Out of Afghanistan
column2: Kabul’s Airport Is a Final Stand/"Military planners and intelligence analysts say the growing strength of the Taliban and planned withdrawal of international combat troops mean that the Afghan government was likely to fall in six months to two years. And while it is not clear that the Taliban would want to completely shut down the airport and isolate the country if they take full control of Afghanistan
column3: the group has signaled that it will not accept the presence of any foreign troops
column4: even from Turkey.

column1: After two decades of war
column2: failed military strategies and set-piece battles that seem to have fallen out of remembered time
column3: the fate of the airport is shaping up as a potential epitaph to America’s presence in Afghanistan.

column1: The importance of the strip of tarmac
column2: radars and terminals
column3: surrounded by the ring of mountains that define the capital city
column4: cannot be overstated. Beyond its strategic importance for maintaining embassy operations and having an evacuation route for diplomats and the forces protecting them
column5: the airport is the gateway to Afghanistan for workers from international aid groups and other nongovernmental organizations and health care providers that remain vital in a nation long reliant on foreign assistance to provide basic services.

column1: “It’s important for the diplomatic communities
column2: aid agencies
column3: international organizations and also for the country to continue to have support from outside
column4: ” Abdullah Abdullah
column5: the chairman of the Afghan government council that has led peace negotiations with the Taliban
column6: said of the airport in an interview on Friday after he and President Ashraf Ghani met with Mr. Biden at the White House.

column1: Kabul International’s importance was underscored last week after Pentagon and other administration officials said the military airport at Bagram
column2: about an hour north of Kabul
column3: would soon close on schedule.

column1: Administration officials had briefly considered delaying the closure of Bagram to give commanders more options if security arrangements at Kabul International stalled or Pentagon planners needed another airport to evacuate thousands of Western diplomats or Afghan interpreters and other workers who helped the United States."/['Thomas Gibbons-Neff'

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/us/politics/house-confederate-statues-vote.html/House Votes to Purge Confederate Statues From the Capitol/"The vote marked the latest round in a yearslong debate on Capitol Hill and across the country over the role of Confederate statuary and symbols in public spaces
column2: and the implications of removing them. Proponents of removing or relocating Confederate monuments and erecting new ones to commemorate the national struggle for equal rights have notched steady progress.

column1: The House and Senate voted overwhelmingly this month to make Juneteenth a federal holiday commemorating the end of slavery. In January
column2: Congress overrode a veto by President Donald J. Trump to enact legislation that would
column3: among other things
column4: direct the military to strip the names of Confederate leaders from bases in the coming years. And inside the Capitol
column5: Speaker Nancy Pelosi ordered portraits of four speakers who served the Confederacy be taken down from the gilded lounge adjacent to the House chamber
column6: where she has control of what artwork is displayed.

column1: The fate of the Capitol statuary has been more complicated
column2: because Congress has no authority over much of it. According to a law that originated during the Civil War
column3: each state may send two statues of deceased citizens who were “illustrious for their historic renown or for distinguished civic or military services
column4: ” and whom the state considers “worthy of this national commemoration” to be featured in Statuary Hall
column5: an ornate marble amphitheater-style room just off the House floor
column6: or elsewhere in the Capitol.

column1: The bill passed by the House on Tuesday would direct congressional officials to remove any statue of a Confederate military or government leader
column2: as well as some specific ones
column3: and allow states to send replacements. Many of the statues in question were erected in the early 20th century
column4: when Southern states were romanticizing the “Lost Cause” of the Confederacy and enforcing the segregationist code of Jim Crow.

column1: Among them is a bust of Chief Justice Taney
column2: who as the leader of the Supreme Court delivered the landmark Dred Scott v. Sandford decision denying the rights of citizenship to people of African descent. The legislation calls for Taney’s bust to be replaced with one of his fellow Marylander Thurgood Marshall
column3: the first Black Supreme Court justice."/['Nicholas Fandos']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/us/politics/29dc-confederate-1/29dc-confederate-1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/us/politics/trump-wisconsin-republicans.html/Wisconsin G.O.P. Wrestles With Just How Much to Indulge Trump/"Mr. Cruz won the state
column2: the last one he’d carry before ending his campaign a month later. Most
column3: but not all
column4: Wisconsin Republicans quickly got on board with Mr. Trump. Paul D. Ryan
column5: then the House speaker
column6: dragged his feet on endorsing Mr. Trump. Charlie Sykes
column7: at the time the most influential conservative talk radio host in the state
column8: never did
column9: and quit his job to become a Never-Trump commentator.

column1: Now
column2: as they have in Georgia and Arizona
column3: Mr. Trump’s false claims that he won Wisconsin’s presidential contest threaten to split Republicans. At the party convention on Saturday
column4: Mr. Trump delivered a prerecorded message reiterating the lie that he won the state — though he didn’t mention any of the legislative leaders he had criticized the night before.

column1: “We had actually great results in Wisconsin
column2: ” Mr. Trump said. “As you know
column3: in 2016 we won
column4: and as you also know
column5: in 2020 we won
column6: but that hasn’t been so adjudged yet.”

column1: Mr. Kapenga’s letter to Mr. Trump was a telling distillation of the delicate way Republicans try to navigate the former president’s whims
column2: combining ego-stroking and gentle pushback. He lightly scolded Mr. Trump for broadcasting misinformation
column3: saying
column4: “It is false
column5: and I don’t appreciate it being done before calling me and finding out the truth
column6: ” before softening it with a request to play golf with Mr. Trump “at the club of your choice.”

column1: The letter concludes: “I write this as I am about to board a plane due to a family medical emergency. In addition to my Trump socks
column2: I will pull up my Trump/Pence mask when I board the plane
column3: as required by federal law. I figure
column4: if the liberals are going to force me to wear a mask
column5: I am going to make it as painful for them as possible. I will continue to do this regardless of whether or not I ever hear from you. Thank you for doing great things as our President.”

column1: Mr. Vos and Mr. Kapenga have advanced legislation to make absentee voting harder and forbid the mass collecting of early votes that the city clerk in Madison
column2: the liberal state capital
column3: engaged in last fall. But they have so far resisted
column4: while not ruling out
column5: calls to subpoena large numbers of 2020 votes and embark on an Arizona-style audit."/['Reid J. Epstein']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/us/politics/29wisconsin-repubs1/29wisconsin-repubs1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/us/politics/gender-passports.html/The State Dept. will no longer require medical documents proving gender for U.S. passport applicants./"Americans will be allowed to declare their self-identified gender on their U.S. passports without providing medical documents under a new State Department rule that officials said would be announced on Wednesday
column2: the final day of Pride Month.

column1: The shift was the first step toward creating a gender marker on U.S. passports and citizenship certificates for people who identify as nonbinary or intersex
column2: or otherwise do not conform to gender roles. That process is complex and will take time to complete
column3: according to an official who spoke on condition of anonymity ahead of the announcement by Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken.

column1: In the meantime
column2: officials said
column3: Americans applying for passports and proof of citizenship when born abroad will no longer need to show medical certification if their stated gender does not match their other identification documents.

column1: The move fulfills a campaign promise by President Biden
column2: who has raised concerns that without documented proof of their self-identified gender
column3: transgender and nonbinary people risk being denied employment
column4: housing and other benefits
column5: including the right to vote."/['Lara Jakes']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/us/30new-washington-briefing-passports/30new-washington-briefing-passports-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/us/politics/biden-is-set-to-meet-with-leaders-of-western-states-to-discuss-record-heat-waves-and-drought.html/Biden is set to meet with leaders of Western states to discuss record heat waves and drought./"With a record-shattering heat wave suffocating much of the Pacific Northwest and a drought-fueled wildfire season already well underway in New Mexico
column2: Arizona and California
column3: President Biden will attend a virtual meeting with leaders of Western states on Wednesday to discuss strategies to minimize weather-related disasters this summer.

column1: Jen Psaki
column2: the White House press secretary
column3: told reporters on Friday that the president planned to bring together members of his cabinet and the Western governors to assess “the devastating intersection of drought
column4: heat
column5: and wildfires
column6: ” as well as “prevention
column7: preparedness
column8: and response efforts for this wildfire season.”

column1: The governors of California
column2: Colorado
column3: New Mexico
column4: Nevada
column5: Oregon
column6: Utah
column7: and Wyoming are expected to attend. With temperatures in Seattle climbing into triple digits over the past three days
column8: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington said Tuesday that he would join as well
column9: according to news reports.

column1: The eye-popping temperatures across the West this week have added to the alarm over the punishing drought conditions already gripping the region."/['Zach Montague']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/us/politics/30new-washington-briefing-biden-west/30new-washington-briefing-biden-west-facebookJumbo.jpg"

https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/business/economy/inflation-federal-reserve.html/Fed Unity Cracks as Inflation Rises and Officials Debate Future/"The central bank’s 18 policy officials roundly say that the economy’s path is extremely hard to predict as it reopens from a once-in-a-century pandemic. But how they think about inflation after a string of strong recent price reports — and how they feel the Fed should react — varies.
Inflation has spiked because of statistical quirks
column2: but also because consumer demand is outstripping supply as the economy reopens and families open their wallets for dinners out and long-delayed vacations. Bottlenecks that have held up computer chip production and home-building should eventually fade. Some prices that had previously shot up
column3: like those for lumber
column4: are already starting to moderate.

column1: But if the reopening weirdness lasts long enough
column2: it could cause businesses and consumers to anticipate higher inflation permanently
column3: and act accordingly. Should that happen
column4: or if workers begin to negotiate higher wages to cover the pop in living costs
column5: faster price gains could stick around.

column1: “A new risk is that inflation may surprise still further to the upside as the reopening process continues
column2: beyond the level necessary to simply make up for past misses to the low side
column3: ” Mr. Bullard said in a presentation last week. The Fed aims for 2 percent inflation as an average goal over time
column4: without specifying the time frame.

column1: Other Fed officials have said today’s price pressures are likely to ease with time
column2: but have not sounded confident that they will entirely disappear.

column1: “These upward price pressures may ease as the bottlenecks are worked out
column2: but it could take some time
column3: ” Michelle Bowman
column4: one of the Fed’s Washington-based governors
column5: said in a recent speech.

column1: The Fed’s top leadership has offered a less alarmed take on the price trajectory. Mr. Powell and John C. Williams
column2: president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York
column3: have said it is possible that prices could stay higher
column4: but they have also said there’s little evidence so far to suggest that they will."/['Jeanna Smialek'
column5: 'Jim Tankersley']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/business/29dc-divergence1/29dc-divergence1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/video/us/politics/100000007842283/house-remove-confederate-statue.html/House Debates Removing Confederate Statues/“This holiday
column2: while a celebration
column3: is also an opportunity to take steps to right the wrongs of history
column4: starting here
column5: right here in the U.S. Capitol. That is why today we are again passing legislation to remove statues of Confederate officials and other advocacies of bigotry and removing them from the U.S. Capitol. Monuments to men or people who advocated cruelty and barbarism to achieve such a plainly racist end are a grotesque affront to those ideals. They are homage to hate
column6: not heritage; they must be removed.” “Our nation was built on a unifying vision from the beginning. As Lincoln said
column7: we are conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that we are all equal. I’ll vote for this bill today
column8: just as I voted for it before. But Madam Speaker
column9: if we have not learned anything
column10: we should not divide our nation based on race.” “This is a great country. Nobody denies that. I don’t call this a racist country. I do say that this country has on occasion
column11: too often for my taste
column12: tolerated racism. That’s a fact. And nobody can deny that fact. Last time this bill came before this body
column13: over 70 of my Republican friends voted for it. I would hope we could do a little better today.”/['The Associated Press']//"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/us/politics/29new-washington-briefing-confederate1/29new-washington-briefing-confederate1-facebookJumbo.jpg?video-overlay?video-overlay?video-overlay"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/business/biden-infrastructure.html/Biden Kicks Off Sales Tour to Salvage Bipartisan Infrastructure Deal/"White House officials have spent recent days seeking to reassure progressives and centrist lawmakers
column2: as well as outside groups that have pushed for all or part of Mr. Biden’s sprawling economic agenda.

column1: Jen Psaki
column2: the White House press secretary
column3: told reporters on Air Force One on Tuesday that Mr. Biden’s aides had in recent days held calls with more than 60 Democratic and Republican lawmakers
column4: chiefs of staff and staff directors
column5: across the House and the Senate. Senior White House staff members met on Tuesday with four Democrats and four Republicans in the House Problem Solvers Caucus
column6: a centrist group
column7: and administration officials also held talks with the Congressional Progressive Caucus. Ms. Psaki said White House staff members addressed more than 100 progressive groups in a call organized by the group Build Back Together.

column1: “We have every senior member of the White House working to communicate directly with the public
column2: with groups
column3: with members of Congress about the components of this package and our continued commitment to also get the reconciliation package across the finish line
column4: ” Ms. Psaki said.

column1: In Wisconsin
column2: Mr. Biden sought to reassure everyone involved
column3: in different ways.

column1: His starting point in each case was to highlight the components of the bipartisan deal
column2: casting it as a job creator that would help urban
column3: rural and suburban Americans alike. “This bipartisan breakthrough is a great deal for the American people
column4: ” Mr. Biden said
column5: predicting the agreement would produce jobs that did not require a college degree. “This is a blue-collar blueprint to rebuild America.”

column1: He said the deal would improve the quality of life for Wisconsin residents
column2: including through more deployment of broadband internet in rural areas
column3: where the White House says about 35 percent of families lack reliable internet.

column1: Mr. Biden said the $65 billion to expand broadband access in the deal would be enough to make high-speed internet available to “every American home.” Independent experts say the money is unlikely to stretch that far. Mr. Biden’s proposed American Jobs Plan would have allocated $100 billion to fully complete the process of extending broadband to every home.
Mr. Biden also promised the bill would replace the nearly 80
column2: 000 water service lines in Milwaukee that are made of lead
column3: along with every other lead water pipe in America. He cast spending on road and bridge repairs as a means to reduce traffic for drivers across the country
column4: which he said amounted to a $1
column5: 000 annual loss for the average American because of wasted time. White House officials did not offer details of how much of that “traffic tax” the deal would alleviate."/['Jim Tankersley']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/business/29dc-biden-infrastructure/merlin_190111071_e0f0f3c1-5f92-48e0-b4ec-9282ae3fd136-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/us/politics/jim-clyburn-nina-turner-special-election-cleveland.html/No. 3 House Democrat Steps Into Ohio Race to Head Off a Sanders Acolyte/"“What I try to do is demonstrate by precept and example how we are to proceed as a party
column2: ” Mr. Clyburn said in an interview. “When I spoke out against sloganeering
column3: like ‘Burn
column4: baby
column5: burn’ in the 1960s and ‘defund the police
column6: ’ which I think is cutting the throats of the party
column7: I know exactly where my constituents are. They are against that
column8: and I’m against that.”

column1: The special election in Cleveland is highlighting the vast generational divide and ideological gulf that the Democratic Party faces as the entire House leadership heads toward the sunset. Mr. Clyburn
column2: Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the House majority leader
column3: Representative Steny H. Hoyer
column4: are all octogenarians
column5: leading an increasingly youthful
column6: diverse and restive caucus. Ms. Pelosi even agreed to vacate her position after this Congress
column7: and the next year will be an ideological battle over who will succeed her.

column1: Ms. Brown has the backing of the Democratic establishment
column2: including not only Mr. Clyburn but also Hillary Clinton; Richard Cordray
column3: a former Ohio attorney general; Representative Joyce Beatty of Ohio
column4: the chairwoman of the Congressional Black Caucus; and moderate Democrats like Representatives Josh Gottheimer of New Jersey and David Trone of Maryland.

column1: Ms. Turner
column2: who has the endorsements of much of the House Progressive Caucus
column3: including the so-called squad — Representatives Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
column4: Ayanna S. Pressley
column5: Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib — would be a strong new voice for the congressional left. And the left is increasingly focused on Black and Hispanic districts that they see as safe redoubts for ideological candidates.

column1: “You can’t take any one race and paint it as some larger aggregate for the whole country
column2: ” Ms. Ocasio-Cortez
column3: a New York Democrat
column4: said on Tuesday. “But I do think that Nina is a beloved leader in the progressive movement
column5: and the degree of excitement that she’s generated and grass-roots energy and organizing in her direction is a real testament to the asset that the base of our party can provide.”"/['Jonathan Weisman']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/us/politics/29dc-clyburn1/29dc-clyburn1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/us/politics/nsa-xkeyscore-privacy.html/Privacy Watchdog Board’s Secret Report on N.S.A. System Fell Short
column2: Member Says/"The study’s scope was chosen when the board was under Democratic control. Then some members departed and the board lacked a quorum
column3: but its staff pursued the effort. The report was completed when the board was under Republican control.

column1: Another complicating factor is that the board approved the report in December by voice vote without recorded opposition
column2: according to several officials. Mr. LeBlanc told its general counsel the next day to record him as a no
column3: they said. Mr. LeBlanc said he had abstained during the voice vote
column4: adding that he was “shocked” that the board was suddenly voting on it.

column1: “I am unable to support” the XKeyscore system report
column2: he wrote. “I harbor serious reservations about the deficiencies in our oversight of the XKeyscore program as well as significant concerns about the program’s operations.”

column1: Mr. LeBlanc offered myriad criticisms of the report
column2: portraying the board’s approval of it as rushed and pointing to gaps like a failure to scrutinize the use of artificial intelligence in connection with the system
column3: to conduct an adequate assessment of oversight mechanisms
column4: and to scrutinize the National Security Agency’s collection activities under Executive Order 12333
column5: including those that can incidentally pull in Americans’ private messages.

column1: The report
column2: he wrote
column3: “unfortunately reads more like a book report of the XKeyscore program than an independent oversight analysis grappling with key concerns in this evolving technological and legal landscape.”

column1: But Adam Klein
column2: a Republican who was the board’s chairman until he stepped down on June 20
column3: defended the effort as valuable.

column1: “This is a detailed
column2: comprehensive report and recommendations on a very complex program
column3: ” he said. “It reflects six years of work by board staff and multiple iterations of board members. It’s highly factual
column4: substantive and apolitical — the type of oversight the board was created to perform.”"/['Charlie Savage']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/us/politics/29dc-nsa/29dc-nsa-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/video/us/politics/100000007841449/biden-infrastructure-plan-wisconsin.html/Biden Touts ‘Bipartisan Breakthrough’ on Infrastructure/American has always been propelled into the future by landmark national investment
column2: investments that only the government has the capacity to make
column3: only the government working together can make. Sixty-five years ago today
column4: President Dwight Eisenhower signed a bill that created the Interstate highway system — 65 years ago today. That was the last infrastructure investment of the size and scope of the agreement I’m about to talk about today. It’s time for us to write a new chapter in that story. After months of careful negotiation
column5: of listening
column6: compromising together and in good faith
column7: moving together with ups and downs and some blips
column8: a bipartisan group of senators got together
column9: and they forged an agreement to move forward on the key priorities of my American Jobs Plan. The one sitting in front of me. As a result
column10: this is a generational investment
column11: a generational investment to modernize our infrastructure
column12: creating millions of good-paying jobs. That’s not coming from me that’s coming from Wall Street — millions of good-paying jobs and positions America to compete with the rest of the world in the 21st century. This bipartisan breakthrough is a great deal for the American people
column13: not just for folks in cities
column14: not just for red states or blue states
column15: but for everybody. This is the answer for good-paying jobs — jobs
column16: not just in our biggest cities along our coast
column17: but in small towns across the country so families can build wealth and opportunity in rural hometowns and don’t have to leave when they’re grown up. I’ve said it all along
column18: this is a blue-collar blueprint to rebuild America./['The New York Times']//"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/us/politics/29new-washington-briefing-biden4/29new-washington-briefing-biden4-facebookJumbo.jpg?video-overlay?video-overlay?video-overlay"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/podcasts/the-daily/ufo-report-pentagon.html/Inside the U.F.O. Report/"Listen and follow The Daily
Apple Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher
Recently
column2: the U.S. government released a long-awaited report that looked into unexplained aerial phenomena.

column1: Though
column2: of the 144 sightings it tackles
column3: the report comes up with an explanation for only one.

column1: At nine pages
column2: the report is short and broad
column3: but it does try to categorize those other sightings.

column1: Some categories are more mundane
column2: like natural phenomena and airborne clutter. Others pose more interesting possibilities: U.S. government secret projects
column3: advanced technology developed by foreign adversaries and an opaque “other.”

column1: What implications will the report have
column2: and will it do anything to quell theories of extraterrestrial visitations?"/[]/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/podcasts/30DAILY-UFO/30DAILY-UFO-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/article/netting-zero.html/Join Us for Netting Zero
column2: a Virtual Event Series on Climate Change/"The Covid-19 pandemic has substantially shifted the ways in which we experience urban spaces. In an instant
column3: high-density city centers have seen mass exodus to the suburbs as people have sought greener and larger spaces.

column1: If the pandemic is any indication of the challenges to come from a changing climate
column2: what lessons can we apply to help us create healthier and greener communities?

column1: On July 1
column2: join Mark Landler
column3: the Times’s London bureau chief
column4: and experts for the latest episode of Netting Zero
column5: “How Do We Build Our Homes and Cities For a Sustainable Future
column6: ” as we discuss how this shift can present new opportunities for sustainable buildings and urban spaces (R.S.V.P. above to join the conversation).

column1: Speakers joining Mark Landler in conversation on July 1 include:"/['The New York Times']//"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/05/24/climate/24NettingZero-Built/24NettingZero-Built-facebookJumbo-v3.jpg"
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/02/theater/lin-manuel-miranda-shakespeare-offstage-events.html/Lin-Manuel Miranda and Shakespeare in the Park: A Times Summer Event/"In New York
column2: coronavirus cases are going down. Vaccination rates are going up. And theater artists are stepping out of grid view and onto the stage.

column1: For the next episode of “Offstage
column2: ” our digital series about theater making during the pandemic
column3: we visit Lin-Manuel Miranda at the Drama Book Shop — which he now co-owns — to talk about the return of “Hamilton” and making spaces for artistic collaboration.

column1: We also consider the return of Shakespeare in the Park with the playwright Jocelyn Bioh and the director Saheem Ali
column2: who will talk with the New York Times critic at large Maya Phillips about their new adaptation of “The Merry Wives of Windsor” — set in Harlem
column3: imagining many characters as immigrants from West Africa
column4: and called
column5: simply
column6: “Merry Wives” — which will be staged from July 6 to September 18.

column1: Can’t wait? We’ll have a preview of the show
column2: performed by the actors Susan Kelechi Watson (“This Is Us”) and Pascale Armand (“Eclipsed”) on the outdoor stage of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park."/['Michael Paulson']/2021-06-02 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/images/icons/defaultPromoCrop.png"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/nyregion/adams-garcia-wiley-mayor-ranked-choice.html/New York Mayor’s Race in Chaos After Elections Board Counts 135
column2: 000 Test Ballots/"And Mr. Adams noted the “unfortunate” error by the Board of Elections and emphasized the importance of handling election results correctly.

column1: “It is critical that New Yorkers are confident in their electoral system
column2: especially as we rank votes in a citywide election for the first time
column3: ” he said in a statement released on Tuesday night. “We appreciate the board’s transparency and acknowledgment of their error. We look forward to the release of an accurate
column4: updated simulation
column5: and the timely conclusion of this critical process.”

column1: If elected
column2: Mr. Adams would be the city’s second Black mayor
column3: after David N. Dinkins. Some of Mr. Adams’s supporters have already cast the ranked-choice process as an attempt to disenfranchise voters of color
column4: an argument that intensified among some backers on Tuesday afternoon as the race had appeared to tighten
column5: and is virtually certain to escalate should he lose his primary night lead to Ms. Garcia
column6: who is white.

column1: Surrogates for Mr. Adams have suggested without evidence that an apparent ranked-choice alliance between Ms. Garcia and another rival
column2: Andrew Yang
column3: could amount to an attempt to suppress the votes of Black and Latino New Yorkers; Mr. Adams himself claimed that the alliance was aimed at preventing a Black or Latino candidate from winning the race.

column1: In the final days of the race
column2: Ms. Garcia and Mr. Yang campaigned together across the city
column3: especially in neighborhoods that are home to sizable Asian American communities
column4: and appeared together on campaign literature.

column1: To advocates of ranked-choice voting
column2: the round-by-round shuffling of outcomes is part of the process of electing a candidate with broad appeal. But if Ms. Garcia or Ms. Wiley were to prevail
column3: the process — which was approved by voters in a 2019 ballot measure — would likely attract fresh scrutiny
column4: with some of Mr. Adams’s backers and others already urging a new referendum on it.

column1: By Tuesday night
column2: though
column3: it was the Board of Elections that was attracting ire from seemingly all corners."/['Katie Glueck']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/nyregion/29nymayor-rcv-1/merlin_189823446_9e5b64eb-345a-4429-b618-8e9135b1c25d-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/26/nyregion/nyc-voting-election-board.html/Inside Decades of Nepotism and Bungling at the N.Y.C. Elections Board/"It is also the first presidential election in New York with early voting
column2: which began Saturday with tens of thousands of residents flooding polling places.

column1: “I expect the B.O.E. to pull this off — there’s no other option. It’s the most important election of our lifetime
column2: ” said Scott Stringer
column3: the city comptroller. “But we shouldn’t have to hold our breath because of their gross incompetence.”

column1: New York is the only state in the country with local election boards whose staffers are chosen almost entirely by Democratic and Republican Party bosses
column2: and the board in New York City illustrates the pitfalls. In recent years
column3: the board has made increasingly high-profile blunders
column4: from mistakenly purging 200
column5: 000 people from rolls ahead of the 2016 election to forcing some voters to wait in four-hour lines in 2018.

column1: “It is really hard to have co-workers who are incapable of performing what they need to do
column2: ” said Charles Stimson
column3: a trainer assistant who has worked at the board on and off since 1992.

column1: Mr. Stimson was one of more than a dozen current and former employees who told The Times that the agency has a culture where ineptitude is common and accountability is rare. Some staffers read or watch Netflix at the office
column2: the employees said. Others regularly fail to show up for work
column3: with no fear of discipline. Several employees said some staffers punch in and then leave to go shopping or to the gym."/['Brian M. Rosenthal'
column4: 'Michael Rothfeld']/2020-10-26 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/10/26/us/26nyelections-1/26nyelections-1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/nyregion/andrew-yang-mayor.html/How Andrew Yang Went from Front-Runner to Fourth Place/"“At the end
column2: there wasn’t a clear
column3: cogent argument of what he stood for that resonated
column4: ” said Ron Kim
column5: a Queens assemblyman who endorsed Mr. Yang. “If I could go back
column6: I would have encouraged him to stick with what he was known for
column7: which was being an innovator
column8: a person who can deliver out-of-the-box thinking on solutions for economic growth and jobs.”

column1: In the race’s last stages
column2: Mr. Yang threw his support to Ms. Garcia
column3: encouraging his supporters to rank her second. Though they campaigned together
column4: she did not ask the same of her supporters; she said she had hoped to piggyback on Mr. Yang’s popularity in certain sectors of the city.

column1: Mr. Yang did perform well with heavily Asian communities in Queens like Elmhurst and Flushing
column2: as well as in heavily Orthodox Jewish neighborhoods in Brooklyn
column3: like Borough Park. He did not do nearly as well in Manhattan
column4: his home borough
column5: where he garnered 10 percent of the in-person vote; Ms. Garcia captured the most votes in that borough.

column1: “There were some tensions within the team where people would say
column2: ‘Well
column3: you can’t out-cop the cop
column4: ’” Mr. Yang said in an episode of his podcast that aired Monday.

column1: “For me
column2: ” he added
column3: “both common sense and the numbers indicated that crime was going to be the number one issue.”

column1: And despite being the self-described ideas candidate
column2: Mr. Yang did not have enough of them to entice voters.

column1: “As the person who was getting most of the attention
column2: the race became a referendum on him
column3: ” said Stu Loeser
column4: who advised the campaign of Ray McGuire
column5: the former Citigroup executive. “And he proved himself to be a callow
column6: unsubstantial
column7: often dimwitted person.”"/['Dana Rubinstein']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/28/nyregion/00nymayor-yang1/00nymayor-yang1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/us/miami-condo-surfside-collapse-victims-missing.html/‘We Are Waiting for You’: An Agonizing Vigil for Surfside Families/"“His mom took us to our first Kiss concert and we went again to see them in Tampa two years ago
column2: ” Mr. Dezarraga
column4: said. They spent last Christmas together
column5: and Mr. Guara gave bikes to the twins.

column1: “I had just talked to him about two weeks ago
column2: ” he said. “What I did not know at the time is he and another friend were planning a surprise visit.”

column1: There were further indications this week that the next step — determining who or what should be blamed for the disaster — was getting underway. On Monday
column2: the state attorney for Miami-Dade County
column3: Katherine Fernández Rundle
column4: announced that she would ask a grand jury to examine the collapse
column5: though the jury has yet to be empaneled. Ms. Levine Cava pledged her support for such an investigation in a news conference on Tuesday.

column1: In addition
column2: a letter that the president of the condominium association wrote to residents in April publicly surfaced
column3: revealing deep concerns about the building’s condition less than three months before it gave way. Ross Prieto
column4: the former Surfside building official who had been apprised of problems at the Champlain Towers three years ago
column5: is now on leave from his current job as a contractor with the nearby city of Doral
column6: according to city officials there.

column1: More intimate calculations were being made closer to the site. Ms. Ramsey
column2: a marketing executive who grew up in South Florida
column3: said there was another reason she had not shouted her mother’s name when she visited the pile on Monday afternoon: Her mother
column4: she said
column5: “did not like to make a scene.”

column1: Magaly Delgado had spent decades as Magaly Alfonso
column2: but 12 years ago she divorced her longtime husband and took her maiden name back. Ms. Delgado had initiated the breakup
column3: her daughter said. “She just felt like she didn’t want any ties
column4: and wanted to be an independent woman
column5: and it wasn’t working out for her
column6: so she split things up.”"/['Richard Fausset']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/28/us/28miami-building-collapse-vigil-2/28miami-building-collapse-vigil-2-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/06/30/us/miami-building-missing-dead.html/Floor by Floor
column2: the Missing People and Lost Lives Near Miami/"In the early hours of June 24
column3: a 13-story beachfront condo partially crumbled in thunderous
column4: smoke-billowing waves. At least half of the 135 units of the Champlain Towers South in Surfside
column5: Fla.
column6: disintegrated in mere seconds in what was most likely one of the deadliest building collapses in American history. Here are the apartment locations of the known missing and the confirmed dead.

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/health/coronavirus-delta-variant-masks.html/Masks Again? Delta Variant’s Spread Prompts Reconsideration of Precautions./"Even Israel — which has one of the highest vaccination rates in the world and is aggressively immunizing younger adolescents and teenagers who qualify — has reinstated masking requirements in public indoor spaces and at large public gatherings outdoors
column2: after hundreds of new Covid-19 cases were detected in recent days
column3: including among people who had received both doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.

column1: This is not the first time the world has been consumed by a more contagious variant of the coronavirus. The Alpha variant walloped Britain and brought the rest of Europe to a standstill earlier this year. In the United States
column2: Alpha quickly became the dominant variant by late March
column3: but the rapid pace of vaccination blunted its spread
column4: sparing the nation a big surge in infections.

column1: But Delta is thought to be even more fearsome. Much of what is known about the variant is based on its spread in India and Britain
column2: but early evidence indicates that it is perhaps twice as contagious as the original virus and at least 20 percent more contagious than Alpha.

column1: In many Indian states and European nations
column2: Delta quickly outpaced Alpha to become the dominant version of the virus. It is on track to do the same in the United States.

column1: Among the variant’s many mutations are some that may help the virus partly dodge the immune system. Several studies have shown that while the current vaccines are effective against Delta
column2: they are slightly less so than against most other variants. For individuals who have received only one dose of a two-dose regimen
column3: protection against the variant is significantly reduced
column4: compared with efficacy against other forms of the virus."/['Roni Caryn Rabin'
column5: 'Apoorva Mandavilli'
column6: 'Shawn Hubler']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/science/2VIRUS-DELTA1/2VIRUS-DELTA1-facebookJumbo-v3.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/06/30/world/covid-19-vaccine-coronavirus-updates//Covid Live Updates: Kim Jong-un Says North Korea Is Facing a Virus ‘Crisis’/"Live Covid Live Updates: Kim Jong-un Says North Korea Is Facing a Virus ‘Crisis’ The pandemic has reduced life expectancy in Brazil by over a year. Scientists are studying whether the Delta variant causes different symptoms.
North Korea reports a ‘great crisis’ in its virus response. Kim Jong-un during a meeting of North Korea’s Politburo on Tuesday
column2: where he spoke of a “great crisis” in the country’s pandemic response. Credit... Korean Central News Agency/Korea News Service
column3: via Associated Press North Korea’s leader
column4: Kim Jong-un
column5: said that lapses in his country’s anti-pandemic campaign have caused a “great crisis” that threatened “grave consequences
column6: ” state media reported on Wednesday. Mr. Kim did not clarify whether he was referring to an outbreak in North Korea
column7: where the authorities had said there were no cases of the virus. But state media reported that the matter was serious enough for Mr. Kim to convene a meeting of the Political Bureau of his ruling Workers’ Party on Tuesday
column8: during which Mr. Kim reshuffled the top party leadership. Senior officials neglected implementing antivirus measures and had created “a great crisis in ensuring the security of the state and safety of the people
column9: ” Mr. Kim said. Mr. Kim also berated party officials for their “ignorance
column10: disability and irresponsibility
column11: ” said the official Korean Central News Agency. A report said there would be some “legal” consequences for the officials. The news agency said that some members of the Politburo and its Presidium
column12: as well as some Workers’ Party secretaries
column13: were replaced. In North Korea
column14: all power is concentrated in the leadership of Mr. Kim
column15: and he frequently reshuffles party officials and military leaders
column16: holding them responsible for policy failures. The North claims officially to be free of the virus
column17: although outside experts remain skeptical
column18: citing the country’s threadbare public health system and lack of extensive testing. Still
column19: North Korea has enforced harsh restrictions to contain transmission. Last year
column20: it created a buffer zone along the border with China
column21: issuing a shoot-to-kill order to stop unauthorized crossings
column22: according to South Korean and U.S. officials. South Korean lawmakers briefed by their government’s National Intelligence Service last year have said that North Korea executed an official for violating a trade ban imposed to fight the virus. Last July
column23: when a man from South Korea defected to the North
column24: North Korea declared a national emergency for fear he might have brought the virus. But Mr. Kim has also shown confidence that at least his inner circles were virus-free
column25: sometimes presiding over meetings of party elites where no one wore masks. During the meeting on Tuesday
column26: Mr. Kim urged party officials to double down on his efforts to build a “self-reliant” economy. As North Korea’s economy has been hit hard by the pandemic
column27: Mr. Kim has acknowledged that his five-year plan for growth had failed and instructed his officials to wage an “arduous march” through difficult economic times. This month
column28: he warned of a looming food shortage. The party meeting on Tuesday “suggests that the situation in the country has worsened beyond the capacity of self-reliance
column29: ” said Leif-Eric Easley
column30: an associate professor of international studies at Ewha Womans University in Seoul. “Pyongyang may be setting up a domestic political narrative to allow the acceptance of foreign vaccines and pandemic assistance
column31: ” he said. “Kim is likely to blame scapegoats for this incident
column32: purging disloyal government officials and replacing them with others considered more capable.”

column1: Covid-19 caused a significant decline in life expectancy in Brazil. Cemetery workers in São Paolo
column2: Brazil
column3: carrying the coffin of someone who died of Covid-19 this month. Credit... Rodrigo Paiva/Getty Images The coronavirus has reversed a steady rise in life expectancy in Brazil
column4: with an estimated decline of 1.3 years in 2020 and an even more accelerated drop during the first months of 2021
column5: according to a new report published in the journal Nature Medicine. Significant
column6: abrupt declines in life expectancy are rare and Brazil’s represents a major blow given the strides the country had made in improving health outcomes in recent decades
column7: said Marcia Castro
column8: the chair of the Department of Global Health and Population at Harvard
column9: the lead author of the study. “We expect declines of this magnitude when you have a major shock that leads to high mortality
column10: like a war or a pandemic
column11: ” she said. Brazil has reported more than 514
column12: 000 deaths from Covid-19
column13: an official death toll surpassed only by that in the United States
column14: which has lost more than 604
column15: 000 people. Even so
column16: the United States
column17: which has a considerably larger population
column18: experienced a slightly lower life-expectancy drop last year: 1.13 years. The pandemic has continued to steadily worsen in Brazil
column19: where vaccinations have lagged. At least 18 million Brazilians have been infected so far
column20: or at least one in 11 people
column21: and the country is averaging over 65
column22: 000 new reported cases and over 1
column23: 600 deaths a day
column24: according to official data. But
column25: as in India
column26: which has the world’s third-largest official death toll
column27: many experts believe the numbers understate the true scope of the country’s epidemic. So far
column28: about a third of Brazil’s population has had at least one shot of a vaccine
column29: according to Our World in Data. The decline in life expectancy is a jarring setback for Brazil
column30: Latin America’s largest nation
column31: which has spent billions of dollars in recent decades to expand the reach and quality of its universal public health care system. Between 1945 and 2020
column32: life expectancy in Brazil increased from 45.5 years to 76.7 years
column33: an average of about five months per year. The setbacks of the Covid-19 era have reverted the country to 2014 levels
column34: according to the study. Brazil experienced a second wave of coronavirus cases in the first few months of this year that has been far deadlier than the first one
column35: which receded at the end of 2020. Dr. Castro and fellow researchers estimated that the resulting decline in life expectancy for 2021
column36: based on the death toll recorded in the first four months of the year
column37: will be about 1.78 years. States in the Amazon region — including Amazonas
column38: Rondônia
column39: Roraima and Mato Grosso — experienced the steepest declines in life expectancy last year. Dr. Castro said states in the northeast
column40: where governors imposed relatively strict quarantine measures
column41: experienced lower drops. Dr. Castro said Brazil’s life expectancy rate was likely to decline even more as the virus continued to kill hundreds of people each day
column42: many of whom are relatively young. The average daily death toll for the past week was 1
column44: according to a New York Times tracker. “The decline in 2021 is going to be just horrible
column45: ” Dr. Castro said. “We are now losing even younger people.”

column1: Advertisement Continue reading the main story

Here’s what scientists know about the Delta variant. A vaccination center in New Delhi in May. The Delta variant was first identified in India and has reached at least 85 countries. Credit... Atul Loke for The New York Times Last week
column2: health officials announced that the Delta variant was responsible for about one in every five Covid-19 cases in the United States
column3: and that its prevalence had doubled in the last two weeks. First identified in India
column4: Delta is one of several “variants of concern
column5: ” as designated by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organization. It has spread rapidly through India and Britain and poses a particular threat in places where vaccination rates remain low. Here are answers to some common questions. Does the Delta variant cause different symptoms? It’s not clear yet. “We’re hurting for good data
column6: ” said Dr. Michael Osterholm
column7: director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota. But some evidence of a potential shift is emerging in Britain
column8: where Delta has become the dominant variant. “What we’ve noticed is the last month
column9: we’re seeing different sets of symptoms than we were seeing in January
column10: ” said Tim Spector
column11: a genetic epidemiologist at King’s College London
column12: who leads the Covid Symptom Study
column13: which asks people with the disease to report their symptoms in an app. Headaches
column14: a sore throat
column15: and a runny nose are now among those mentioned most frequently
column16: Dr. Spector said
column17: with fever
column18: cough and loss of smell less common. These findings
column19: however
column20: have not yet been published in a scientific journal
column21: and some scientists remain unconvinced that the symptom profile has truly changed. The severity of Covid
column22: regardless of the variant
column23: can vary wildly from one person to another. If I’m vaccinated
column24: do I need to worry? Although there is not yet good data on how all of the vaccines hold up against Delta
column25: several widely used shots
column26: including those made by Pfizer
column27: Moderna and AstraZeneca
column28: appear to retain most of their effectiveness against the Delta variant
column29: research suggests. “If you’re fully vaccinated
column30: I would largely not worry about it
column31: ” said Dr. Ashish K. Jha
column32: dean of the Brown University School of Public Health. Pockets of unvaccinated people
column33: however
column34: may be vulnerable to outbreaks in the coming months
column35: scientists said. “When you have such a low level of vaccination superimposed upon a variant that has a high degree of efficiency of spread
column36: what you are going to see among under-vaccinated regions
column38: cities or counties
column39: you’re going to see these individual types of blips
column40: ” Dr. Anthony Fauci
column41: the nation’s leading infectious disease expert
column42: said on CNN on Tuesday. “It’s almost like it’s going to be two Americas.”

column1: Putin promotes vaccines as a new virus wave darkens his propaganda picture. A Moscow metro passenger watching President Vladimir V. Putin’s annual call-in show. It has been a bedrock of his communication with Russians for two decades. Credit... Yuri Kochetkov/EPA
column2: via Shutterstock President Vladimir V. Putin urged Russians to get vaccinated against the coronavirus on Wednesday — his most extensive comments on the matter yet — as his country scrambles to contain a vicious new wave of the illness. Speaking at his annual televised call-in show
column3: Mr. Putin spent the opening half-hour trying to convince Russians to get one of the country’s four domestically produced shots. It was the latest instance of a marked change in tone about the pandemic from Russian officials
column4: who for months did little to push a vaccine-wary public to get immunized but are now starting to make vaccination mandatory for some groups. “It’s dangerous
column5: dangerous to your life
column6: ” Mr. Putin said of Covid-19. “The vaccine is not dangerous.” Only 23 million Russians
column7: or about 15 percent of the population
column8: have received at least one vaccine dose
column9: Mr. Putin said. Polls this year by the independent Levada Center showed that some 60 percent of Russians did not want to be vaccinated
column10: even though the domestically produced Sputnik V vaccine is widely seen as safe and effective. Analysts attribute Russians’ hesitancy to a widespread distrust of the authorities combined with a drumbeat of state television reports that described the coronavirus as either mostly defeated or not very dangerous to begin with. Mr. Putin revealed that he himself had received the Sputnik V vaccine this year — the Kremlin had previously refused to specify which shot he had been given — and that he had experienced a brief fever after the second dose. He spoke just as his handling of the pandemic — long touted by the Kremlin as superior to the approach taken in the West — threatened to turn into a major debacle. Russia’s biggest cities
column11: Moscow and St. Petersburg
column12: have been reporting more than 100 deaths per day recently
column13: setting records; nationwide
column14: the number of reported new cases per day has doubled to more than 20
column15: 000 in recent weeks
column16: with 669 deaths reported on Wednesday. The official toll is likely to be a significant undercount. Regional officials in Moscow and elsewhere have resisted lockdowns. But
column17: almost certainly with Mr. Putin’s blessing
column18: they have made vaccination mandatory for large groups of people
column19: such as service workers. That has prompted an outcry from many Kremlin critics and supporters alike. “I don’t support mandatory vaccination
column20: and continue to have this point of view
column21: ” Mr. Putin said
column22: putting the responsibility for such orders on regional officials. The renewed surge of the coronavirus could derail the Kremlin’s message of competence in comparison to Western dysfunction just as parliamentary elections approach in September. Mr. Putin’s most vocal opponents have already been jailed
column23: exiled or barred from running
column24: but obvious election fraud or a poor showing by his governing United Russia party could still weaken the president’s domestic authority.

column1: Are masks coming back? The Delta variant has some different officials rethinking precautions. Officials in Los Angeles County are advising residents to wear masks indoors
column2: regardless of vaccination status. Credit... Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images In May
column3: federal health officials in the United States said that fully vaccinated people no longer needed to mask up
column4: even indoors. The advice set the stage for a national reopening that continues to gain momentum. But that was before the spread of the Delta variant
column5: a highly infectious form of the virus first detected in India and later identified in at least 85 countries. It now accounts for one in five infections in the United States. Worried by a global surge in cases
column6: the World Health Organization last week reiterated its longstanding recommendation that everyone wear masks. On Monday
column7: health officials in Los Angeles County followed suit
column8: recommending that “everyone
column9: regardless of vaccination status
column10: wear masks indoors in public places as a precautionary measure.” Barbara Ferrer
column11: the county’s public health director
column12: said the new recommendation was needed because of upticks in infections
column13: a rise in cases due to the worrisome Delta variant
column14: and persistently high numbers of unvaccinated residents
column15: particularly children
column16: Black and Latino residents and essential workers. Roughly half of Los Angeles County residents are fully vaccinated
column17: and about 60 percent have had at least one dose. While the number of positive tests is still below 1 percent in the county
column18: the rate has been inching up
column19: Dr. Ferrer added
column20: and there has been a rise in the number of reinfections among residents who were infected before and did not get vaccinated. To the extent that Los Angeles County has managed to control the pandemic
column21: it has been because of a multilayered strategy that combined vaccinations with health restrictions aimed at curbing new infections
column22: Dr. Ferrer said. Natural immunity among those already infected has also kept transmission low
column23: she noted
column24: but it is not clear how long natural immunity will last. “We don’t want to return to lockdown or more disruptive mandates here
column25: ” Dr. Ferrer said. “We want to stay on the path we’re on right now
column26: which is keeping community transmission really low.” Health officials in Chicago and New York City indicated this week that they had no plans to revisit mask requirements. Officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention declined to comment
column27: but have also not signaled any intention to revise or re-examine masking recommendations for those who are fully vaccinated. But the Delta variant’s trajectory outside the United States suggests that concerns are likely to intensify. Roni Caryn Rabin

column29: Shawn Hubler

column1: Advertisement Continue reading the main story
Australian officials are divided over the AstraZeneca vaccine. Brisbane
column2: in Queensland
column3: Australia
column4: on Tuesday. The state has entered a three-day lockdown to contain a virus outbreak. Credit... Darren England/EPA
column5: via Shutterstock A rift has emerged between Australia’s federal government
column6: state leaders and medical groups over vaccination advice
column7: with several officials issuing public objections to Prime Minister Scott Morrison’s decision to make the AstraZeneca vaccine available to those under 40. Australia’s vaccine advisory body has recommended that people under 60 should be vaccinated with the Pfizer shot because the AstraZeneca vaccine is associated with a very small risk of a serious blood-clotting disorder. But the country’s vaccination campaign was initially planned around AstraZeneca
column8: and supplies of other shots are so far relatively constrained
column9: with Pfizer appointments not yet open to most people under 40. Less than 5 percent of Australians are fully vaccinated
column10: and just under a quarter have had one dose of a vaccine. Parts of four states or territories
column11: including four major cities
column12: are in lockdown to halt outbreaks associated with the Delta variant
column13: and there are restrictions in two more. In response to outbreaks of the more infectious Delta variant of the virus
column14: Mr. Morrison announced on Monday that the federal government would allow family doctors to administer the AstraZeneca vaccine to those under 40 who wanted it. “If you wish to get the AstraZeneca vaccine
column15: then we would encourage you to go and have that discussion” with your doctor
column16: he said. But soon after
column17: state leaders spoke against the decision. “I do not want under-40s to get AstraZeneca
column18: ” Queensland’s chief health officer
column19: Dr. Jeannette Young
column20: said at a news conference on Wednesday. “I don’t want an 18-year-old in Queensland dying from a clotting illness who
column21: if they got Covid
column22: probably wouldn’t die.” Parts of Queensland recently entered a three-day lockdown as authorities race to contain an outbreak. The premier of Western Australia
column23: Mark McGowan
column24: echoed Dr. Young’s position and called for people over 60 to be given the Pfizer vaccine to combat vaccine hesitancy. Dr. Omar Khorshid
column25: president of the Australian Medical Association
column26: which represents doctors and medical students
column27: said the announcement “was a surprise.” While some medical clinics have started providing consultations to younger people wanting to get the AstraZeneca vaccine
column28: some doctors have said they want more information before they would be comfortable doing so.

column1: ‘Hamilton
column2: ’ the biggest Broadway hit in years
column3: gets $30 million in federal aid. How did that happen? “Hamilton” qualified for millions under the federal Shuttered Venue Operators Grant program to help its five productions reopen. Credit... Cindy Ord/Getty Images Until the pandemic shuttered all of its productions
column4: “Hamilton” was making a lot of money: It has played to full houses since it opened in 2015
column5: and on Broadway it has been seen by 2.6 million people and grossed $650 million. So why is the show getting $30 million in relief from the federal government
column6: with the possibility of another $20 million coming down the road? The answer is that
column7: before the pandemic
column8: “Hamilton” had five separately incorporated productions running in the United States — one on Broadway and four on tour — and
column9: under the rules set up for the government’s Shuttered Venue Operators Grant program
column10: which provides pandemic relief for the culture sector and live-event businesses
column11: each was eligible for $10 million to help make up for lost revenue. “Remember when Chrysler and GM were about to go bankrupt? In the same way that the federal government came in to bail out auto companies
column12: it’s doing the same thing for all of show business with this legislation
column13: ” said the show’s lead producer
column14: Jeffrey Seller. “It’s returning us to health and it’s protecting the well-being of our employees.” Seller said that none of the money would go to the show’s producers (including him) or its investors
column15: and none would be used as royalties for artists (including the show’s creator
column16: Lin-Manuel Miranda). Instead
column17: he said
column18: the money will be used to remount the shuttered productions
column19: and to reimburse the productions for pandemic-related expenses. The rollout of the Shuttered Venue Operators Grant initiative
column20: a $16 billion federal aid program designed to help get cultural organizations back on their feet after the pandemic forced many to close
column21: has been plagued by delays and confusion. But the Small Business Administration
column22: which is administering the program
column23: has begun announcing grant recipients
column24: and there are indications that Broadway and its affiliated businesses could fare well."/['Choe Sang-Hun'

column2: Speaker Nancy Pelosi proposed a 13-member panel with subpoena powers and dominated by Democrats. RIGHT NOW The State Dept. will no longer require medical documents proving gender for U.S. passport applicants.

column1: The House is expected to vote to create a select committee to investigate the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol. The debate over the select committee to investigate the attack on the Capitol is all but certain to take on a highly partisan dynamic. Credit... Jose Luis Magana/Associated Press The House is expected on Wednesday to vote to create a select committee to investigate the deadly Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol
column2: pushing ahead with an inquiry into the security failures and the origins of the mob violence after Republicans blocked the creation of an independent panel to scrutinize the assault. Under a plan devised by Speaker Nancy Pelosi
column3: the 13-member panel would be dominated by Democratic appointees
column4: with eight members to be named by the majority party and just five with input from Republicans. The select committee
column5: which would have subpoena power
column6: would investigate “the facts
column7: circumstances and causes relating to the Jan. 6
column9: domestic terrorist attack” by a pro-Trump mob
column10: according to the organizing resolution slated for a vote on Wednesday. “It was a tragedy
column11: and the American people need to know all the facts
column12: ” Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland
column13: the No. 2 Democrat in the House
column14: told reporters Tuesday. “That’s what this select committee is about
column15: and I’m hopeful that our Republican colleagues will support it.” While the measure says that five members of the panel are to be named “after consultation with the minority leader
column16: ” Representative Kevin McCarthy of California
column17: the top House Republican
column18: has not said whether he will recommend anyone. Last week
column19: he told police officers injured in the attack that he would take the appointment process seriously. One of Ms. Pelosi’s aides said she was considering picking a Republican who has taken the attack seriously for one of her eight slots. Many have speculated that the speaker might select Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming
column20: a former member of House Republican leadership who was removed from her post after she pushed the party to hold itself and former President Donald J. Trump responsible for fomenting the Capitol riot with false claims that the 2020 election had been stolen. Ms. Pelosi would also name the committee’s chairman. Representative Bennie Thompson
column21: Democrat of Mississippi and the head of the Homeland Security Committee
column22: is considered a leading contender. Republicans on Tuesday were lining up in opposition to the creation of the committee. Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana
column23: the No. 2 House Republican
column24: said the Jan. 6 attack had already been investigated by existing committees
column25: citing the work of two Senate committees that examined security failures. (That inquiry secured only limited cooperation from key agencies
column26: including the F.B.I.
column27: the Justice Department and the House sergeant-at-arms. Other agencies failed to meet deadlines to hand over documents.) “Let’s see where the vote goes
column28: ” Mr. Scalise told reporters
column29: alluding to the fact that only 35 House Republicans supported the creation of an independent bipartisan inquiry. “If you look at the last vote
column30: it was overwhelmingly opposed by Republicans.” Republican leaders portrayed the independent investigation
column31: which would have had an equal number of Republican- and Democratic-appointed members
column32: as a partisan attack on Mr. Trump meant to kneecap their party in the 2022 elections. Even fewer are expected to embrace a panel with a lopsided Democratic majority. Representative John Katko
column33: Republican of New York
column34: who had jointly proposed the independent commission
column35: announced this week he would oppose the select committee
column36: calling Ms. Pelosi’s plan a “turbocharged partisan exercise.” Representative Mary Gay Scanlan
column38: said the select committee was needed to investigate both the attack and Republicans’ “new and wild claims” seeking to downplay and deny it. She was referring to the statements of far-right House Republicans who have spread misinformation about the riot
column39: sought to portray it as a mostly peaceful event and voted against honoring police officers who responded. One House Republican accused a U.S. Capitol Police officer of “lying in wait” to carry out an “execution” of a rioter. Another compared the events of Jan. 6 to a Capitol tour. column5: and on Broadway it has been seen by 2.6 million people and grossed $650 million. So why is the show getting $30 million in relief from the federal government

column9: under the rules set up for the government’s Shuttered Venue Operators Grant program
column10: which provides pandemic relief for the culture sector and live-event businesses
column11: each was eligible for $10 million to help make up for lost revenue. “Remember when Chrysler and GM were about to go bankrupt? In the same way that the federal government came in to bail out auto companies

column22: which is administering the program
column23: has begun announcing grant recipients
column24: and there are indications that Broadway and its affiliated businesses could fare well.

column1: The House is expected to vote to create a select committee to investigate the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol. The debate over the select committee to investigate the attack on the Capitol is all but certain to take on a highly partisan dynamic. Credit... Jose Luis Magana/Associated Press The House is expected on Wednesday to vote to create a select committee to investigate the deadly Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol
column2: pushing ahead with an inquiry into the security failures and the origins of the mob violence after Republicans blocked the creation of an independent panel to scrutinize the assault. Under a plan devised by Speaker Nancy Pelosi
column3: the 13-member panel would be dominated by Democratic appointees
column4: with eight members to be named by the majority party and just five with input from Republicans. The select committee
column5: which would have subpoena power
column6: would investigate “the facts
column7: circumstances and causes relating to the Jan. 6
column9: domestic terrorist attack” by a pro-Trump mob
column10: according to the organizing resolution slated for a vote on Wednesday. “It was a tragedy
column11: and the American people need to know all the facts
column12: ” Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland
column13: the No. 2 Democrat in the House
column14: told reporters Tuesday. “That’s what this select committee is about
column15: and I’m hopeful that our Republican colleagues will support it.” While the measure says that five members of the panel are to be named “after consultation with the minority leader
column16: ” Representative Kevin McCarthy of California
column17: the top House Republican
column18: has not said whether he will recommend anyone. Last week
column19: he told police officers injured in the attack that he would take the appointment process seriously. One of Ms. Pelosi’s aides said she was considering picking a Republican who has taken the attack seriously for one of her eight slots. Many have speculated that the speaker might select Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming
column20: a former member of House Republican leadership who was removed from her post after she pushed the party to hold itself and former President Donald J. Trump responsible for fomenting the Capitol riot with false claims that the 2020 election had been stolen. Ms. Pelosi would also name the committee’s chairman. Representative Bennie Thompson
column21: Democrat of Mississippi and the head of the Homeland Security Committee
column22: is considered a leading contender. Republicans on Tuesday were lining up in opposition to the creation of the committee. Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana
column23: the No. 2 House Republican
column24: said the Jan. 6 attack had already been investigated by existing committees
column25: citing the work of two Senate committees that examined security failures. (That inquiry secured only limited cooperation from key agencies
column26: including the F.B.I.
column27: the Justice Department and the House sergeant-at-arms. Other agencies failed to meet deadlines to hand over documents.) “Let’s see where the vote goes
column28: ” Mr. Scalise told reporters
column29: alluding to the fact that only 35 House Republicans supported the creation of an independent bipartisan inquiry. “If you look at the last vote
column30: it was overwhelmingly opposed by Republicans.” Republican leaders portrayed the independent investigation
column31: which would have had an equal number of Republican- and Democratic-appointed members
column32: as a partisan attack on Mr. Trump meant to kneecap their party in the 2022 elections. Even fewer are expected to embrace a panel with a lopsided Democratic majority. Representative John Katko
column33: Republican of New York
column34: who had jointly proposed the independent commission
column35: announced this week he would oppose the select committee
column36: calling Ms. Pelosi’s plan a “turbocharged partisan exercise.” Representative Mary Gay Scanlan
column38: said the select committee was needed to investigate both the attack and Republicans’ “new and wild claims” seeking to downplay and deny it. She was referring to the statements of far-right House Republicans who have spread misinformation about the riot
column39: sought to portray it as a mostly peaceful event and voted against honoring police officers who responded. One House Republican accused a U.S. Capitol Police officer of “lying in wait” to carry out an “execution” of a rioter. Another compared the events of Jan. 6 to a Capitol tour. And some have recently amplified a conspiracy theory that the F.B.I. was behind it.

column28: ” Mr. Scalise told reporters
column29: alluding to the fact that only 35 House Republicans supported the creation of an independent bipartisan inquiry. “If you look at the last vote
column30: it was overwhelmingly opposed by Republicans.” Republican leaders portrayed the independent investigation
column31: which would have had an equal number of Republican- and Democratic-appointed members
column32: as a partisan attack on Mr. Trump meant to kneecap their party in the 2022 elections. Even fewer are expected to embrace a panel with a lopsided Democratic majority. Representative John Katko
column33: Republican of New York
column34: who had jointly proposed the independent commission
column35: announced this week he would oppose the select committee
column36: calling Ms. Pelosi’s plan a “turbocharged partisan exercise.” Representative Mary Gay Scanlan
column38: said the select committee was needed to investigate both the attack and Republicans’ “new and wild claims” seeking to downplay and deny it. She was referring to the statements of far-right House Republicans who have spread misinformation about the riot

One House Republican accused a U.S. Capitol Police officer of “lying in wait” to carry out an “execution” of a rioter. Another compared the events of Jan. 6 to a Capitol tour. And some have recently amplified a conspiracy theory that the F.B.I. was behind it.

column1: Biden is set to meet with leaders of Western states to discuss record heat waves and drought. People sought relief from the punishing heat at a cooling center in Spokane

column3: on Tuesday. The city broke its record for high temperatures

column6: Arizona and California
column7: President Biden will attend a virtual meeting with leaders of Western states on Wednesday to discuss strategies to minimize weather-related disasters this summer. Jen Psaki
column8: the White House press secretary
column9: told reporters on Friday that the president planned to bring together members of his cabinet and the Western governors to assess “the devastating intersection of drought
column10: heat
column11: and wildfires
column12: ” as well as “prevention
column13: preparedness
column14: and response efforts for this wildfire season.” The governors of California
column15: Colorado
column16: New Mexico
column17: Nevada
column18: Oregon
column19: Utah
column20: and Wyoming are expected to attend. With temperatures in Seattle climbing into triple digits over the past three days
column21: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington said Tuesday that he would join as well

column23: coming off its worst wildfire season on record last year
column24: is bracing for another summer of destructive fires
column25: with mountain snowpack and reservoir levels already near record lows. The fires last year caused rolling blackouts and forced evacuations across the region
column26: leaving many people displaced and without power. The current heat wave has left tens of thousands without power across Idaho
column27: Oregon
column28: California and Nevada on Monday. Last week
