The State Dept. will no longer require medical documents proving gender for U.S. passport applicants. Demonstrators gathered in March at a rally in support of transgender rights outside the Alabama State House in Montgomery
column2: Ala. Credit... Nicole Craine for The New York Times Americans will be allowed to declare their self-identified gender on their U.S. passports without providing medical documents under a new State Department rule that officials said would be announced on Wednesday
column3: the final day of Pride Month. The shift was the first step toward creating a gender marker on U.S. passports and citizenship certificates for people who identify as nonbinary or intersex
column4: or otherwise do not conform to gender roles. That process is complex and will take time to complete
column5: according to an official who spoke on condition of anonymity ahead of the announcement by Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken. In the meantime
column6: officials said
column7: Americans applying for passports and proof of citizenship when born abroad will no longer need to show medical certification if their stated gender does not match their other identification documents. The move fulfills a campaign promise by President Biden
column8: who has raised concerns that without documented proof of their self-identified gender
column9: transgender and nonbinary people risk being denied employment
column10: housing and other benefits
column11: including the right to vote. Mr. Blinken was expected to announce that the new policy follows other countries that have taken similar steps — including Canada
column12: Australia
column13: Argentina
column14: Nepal and New Zealand — to in part align with foreign allies and partners. Currently
column15: the State Department requires a doctor’s certificate stating that a passport applicant has either transitioned
column16: or is in the process
column17: to change their gender on official consular documents. It was not immediately clear on Wednesday when that requirement would no longer be in effect. Last month
column18: the State Department reversed another policy that had disproportionally impacted L.G.B.T.Q. families
column19: and granted U.S. citizenship to babies born abroad to married couples with at least one American parent — no matter which parent was biologically related to the child. That policy
column20: a victory for same-sex couples
column21: effectively guaranteed that American and binational couples who use assisted reproductive technology to give birth overseas — such as surrogates or sperm donations — can pass along citizenship to their children.

column1: ‘Hamilton
column2: ’ the biggest Broadway hit in years
column3: gets $30 million in federal aid. How did that happen? “Hamilton” qualified for millions under the federal Shuttered Venue Operators Grant program to help its five productions reopen. Credit... Cindy Ord/Getty Images Until the pandemic shuttered all of its productions
column4: “Hamilton” was making a lot of money: It has played to full houses since it opened in 2015
column5: and on Broadway it has been seen by 2.6 million people and grossed $650 million. So why is the show getting $30 million in relief from the federal government
column6: with the possibility of another $20 million coming down the road? The answer is that
column7: before the pandemic
column8: “Hamilton” had five separately incorporated productions running in the United States — one on Broadway and four on tour — and
column9: under the rules set up for the government’s Shuttered Venue Operators Grant program
column10: which provides pandemic relief for the culture sector and live-event businesses
column11: each was eligible for $10 million to help make up for lost revenue. “Remember when Chrysler and GM were about to go bankrupt? In the same way that the federal government came in to bail out auto companies
column12: it’s doing the same thing for all of show business with this legislation
column13: ” said the show’s lead producer
column14: Jeffrey Seller. “It’s returning us to health and it’s protecting the well-being of our employees.” Seller said that none of the money would go to the show’s producers (including him) or its investors
column15: and none would be used as royalties for artists (including the show’s creator
column16: Lin-Manuel Miranda). Instead
column17: he said
column18: the money will be used to remount the shuttered productions
column19: and to reimburse the productions for pandemic-related expenses. The rollout of the Shuttered Venue Operators Grant initiative
column20: a $16 billion federal aid program designed to help get cultural organizations back on their feet after the pandemic forced many to close
column21: has been plagued by delays and confusion. But the Small Business Administration
column22: which is administering the program
column23: has begun announcing grant recipients
column24: and there are indications that Broadway and its affiliated businesses could fare well.

column1: The Supreme Court keeps in place the moratorium on evictions. A Maricopa County constable signing an eviction notice in Phoenix last year. Credit... John Moore/Getty Images The Supreme Court on Tuesday refused to lift a moratorium on evictions that had been imposed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The vote was 5 to 4
column2: with Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justices Stephen G. Breyer
column3: Sonia Sotomayor
column4: Elena Kagan and Brett M. Kavanaugh in the majority. The court gave no reasons for its ruling
column5: which is typical when it acts on emergency applications. But Justice Kavanaugh issued a brief concurring opinion explaining that he had cast his vote reluctantly and had taken account of the impending expiration of the moratorium. “The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention exceeded its existing statutory authority by issuing a nationwide eviction moratorium
column6: ” Justice Kavanaugh wrote. “Because the C.D.C. plans to end the moratorium in only a few weeks
column7: on July 31
column8: and because those few weeks will allow for additional and more orderly distribution of the congressionally appropriated rental assistance funds
column9: I vote at this time to deny the application” that had been filed by landlords
column10: real estate companies and trade associations. He added that the agency might not extend the moratorium on its own. “In my view
column11: ” Justice Kavanaugh wrote
column12: “clear and specific congressional authorization (via new legislation) would be necessary for the C.D.C. to extend the moratorium past July 31.” At the beginning of the pandemic
column13: Congress declared a moratorium on evictions
column14: which lapsed last July. The C.D.C. then issued a series of its own moratoriums. “In doing so
column15: ” the challengers told the justices
column16: “the C.D.C. shifted the pandemic’s financial burdens from the nation’s 30 to 40 million renters to its 10 to 11 million landlords — most of whom
column17: like applicants
column18: are individuals and small businesses — resulting in over $13 billion in unpaid rent per month.” The total cost to the nation’s landlords
column19: they wrote
column20: could approach $200 billion. The moratorium defers but does not cancel the obligation to pay rent; the challengers wrote that this “massive wealth transfer” would “never be fully undone.” Many renters
column21: they wrote
column22: will be unable to pay what they owe. “In reality
column23: ” they wrote
column24: “the eviction moratorium has become an instrument of economic policy rather than of disease control.” In urging the Supreme Court to leave the moratorium in place
column25: the government said that continued vigilance against the spread of the coronavirus was needed and noted that Congress had appropriated tens of billions of dollars to pay for rent arrears.

The House approves a bill to speed visas to Afghans who worked alongside U.S. troops. Former Afghan interpreters holding signs outside the U.S. Embassy in Kabul on Friday urging the United States to help protect them. Credit... Reuters Rushing to help Afghans who face retribution for working alongside American troops in their home country
column2: the House voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to speed up the process that would allow them to immigrate to the United States. With the American military in the final phases of withdrawing from Afghanistan after 20 years of war
column3: more than 18
column4: 000 Afghans who have worked for the United States as interpreters
column5: drivers
column6: engineers
column7: security guards and embassy clerks are stuck in a bureaucratic morass after applying for Special Immigrant Visas
column8: available to people who face threats because of work for the U.S. government. “I can say with confidence that I might not be here today had it not been for these men and women
column9: ” said Representative Jason Crow
column10: Democrat of Colorado and a former Army Ranger who is the lead sponsor of the bill. The measure
column11: passed 366 to 46
column12: would waive a requirement for applicants to undergo medical examinations in Afghanistan before qualifying
column13: instead allowing them to do so after entering the United States. The first in a series of bipartisan bills intended to smooth the visa process
column14: it aims to shorten the long waiting period
column15: which can be as long as six or seven years for some applicants. Mr. Crow said waiving the medical examination requirement would save the average applicant about a month on processing the visa. The bill requires that applicants complete their examinations within 30 days of arriving in the United States. “In combat and in a war zone
column16: every hour matters
column17: ” Mr. Crow said. “A month will save many
column18: many lives.” Since 2014
column19: the nonprofit No One Left Behind has tracked the killings of more than 300 translators or their family members
column20: many of whom died while waiting for their visas to be processed
column21: according to James Miervaldis

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/business/target-baltimore-store-closings.html/Target Store Closings Show Limits of Pledge to Black Communities/"BALTIMORE — When Target announced that it was opening a store in Mondawmin
column2: a predominantly Black neighborhood in this city struggling with crime and poverty
column3: it seemed like a ticket to a turnaround.

column1: And from the start
column2: it was a practical success and a point of community pride. The store
column3: which opened in 2008
column4: carried groceries
column5: operated a pharmacy and had a Starbucks cafe
column6: the only one in this part of Baltimore’s west side.

column1: People came from across the city to shop there
column2: helping to soften the Mondawmin area’s reputation for crime and the looting that followed protests over the 2015 death of Freddie Gray
column3: who was fatally injured while in city police custody. As an employer
column4: Target seemed to cater to the community’s needs
column5: making a point of hiring Black men and providing an office in the store for a social worker to support the staff. Elijah Cummings
column6: the congressman from Baltimore
column7: was known to shop there.

column1: But in February 2018
column2: with almost no warning or explanation
column3: Target closed the store.

column1: Residents
column2: especially those without cars
column3: lost a convenient place to shop for quality goods. And a marker of the community’s self-worth was suddenly taken away."/['Michael Corkery']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/business/00target-baltimore-1/00target-baltimore-1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

Fox News agrees to a $1 million penalty after workplace culture investigation. Bill O’Reilly was forced out of his Fox News show in 2017 after a series of sexual misconduct allegations against him. Credit... Robert Wright for The New York Times Fox News agreed to pay a $1 million penalty under a settlement reached last week with the New York City Commission on Human Rights. The case stemmed from a cascade of sexual misconduct allegations that shook the network several years ago and led to the exits of Roger Ailes
column2: its co-founder
column3: and the anchor Bill O’Reilly. “This is the largest civil penalty that has ever been levied by the City Commission on Human Rights
column4: ” the agency’s chair and commissioner
column5: Carmelyn P. Malalis
column6: said in an interview on Tuesday. “We need to send a message in order to deter future acts of harassment or retaliation.” The settlement
column7: which was finalized on June 25
column8: will prevent Fox News for the next four years from including in new employment contracts a clause requiring confidential arbitration in cases where an employee lodges a complaint under the city’s Human Rights Law. It also mandates that the network carry out a variety of anti-harassment training and prevention measures. The Commission on Human Rights is the agency that enforces the city’s anti-discrimination laws in workplaces
column9: housing
column10: public services and other spheres. Ms. Malalis said the commission began investigating Fox News in September 2017
column11: around the time that several employees spoke out about sexual harassment at the network; it formally opened a complaint in December 2018. In a statement on Tuesday
column12: Fox News said it was “pleased to reach an amicable resolution of this legacy matter.” “Fox News Media has already been in full compliance across the board
column13: but cooperated with the New York City Commission on Human Rights to continue enacting extensive preventive measures against all forms of discrimination and harassment
column14: ” the network said. In the last few years
column15: Fox News has hired a new human resources team and strengthened sensitivity training requirements
column16: among other measures intended to reform its workplace culture. The network’s agreement last week to pay a $1 million penalty was first reported by The Daily Beast. Read more

column1: England opens up a narrow quarantine exemption for business travelers. A sign posted in London’s Heathrow Airport. Visitors from the United States
column2: an amber list country
column3: must quarantine for 10 days. But Britain is allowing an exemption for executives of companies with over 500 employees. Credit... Andy Rain/EPA
column4: via Shutterstock The British government introduced a new exemption to its quarantine rules on Tuesday for business travelers “bringing significant economic benefit” to England
column5: but the move is unlikely to quell frustrations that certain travel routes in and out of Britain remain effectively shut. The exemption has strict criteria and applies only to executives whose work supports at least 500 British jobs. It is much tighter than one that was in place for about six weeks from early December
column6: when travelers needed to support only 50 jobs in Britain. There has been a growing concern that Britain’s strict travel rules could lead the country to miss out on business opportunities as other countries welcome the return of travelers
column7: especially from the United States. Since Britain left the European Union
column8: it is also particularly anxious about not losing lucrative business activity to its neighbors across the English Channel. Parts of Britain
column9: such as the financial and legal district of the City of London
column10: rely heavily on the presence of large multinational corporations. But most people entering the country either must quarantine for 10 days and take coronavirus tests on the second and eighth days or must pay for an additional test to end their self-isolation after five days. Earlier this month
column11: France reopened its borders to vaccinated American tourists
column12: and last week
column13: Germany said all Americans could enter the country. Jamie Dimon
column14: the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase
column15: met with President Emmanuel Macron of France this week in Paris and opened up a new European Union trading hub on Tuesday. The bank is increasing the number of staff in Paris to 700 by the end of the year
column16: up from 265 before Britain left the European Union. But Mr. Dimon won’t be stopping in Britain
column17: where the company has 19
column18: 000 employees and offices in four cities
column19: as he has in past trips to Europe
column20: because of the country’s travel restrictions. Any executives hoping to leave quarantine will have to meet strict requirements
column21: including proving that the work being done in England “has a greater than 50 percent chance of creating or preserving at least 500 U.K.-based jobs” at a company that already has at least 500 employees or at a new British business. Executives have to apply to the government and get written approval
column22: which can take up to five days
column23: before traveling. When the executive isn’t doing business activity
column24: they must self-isolate at all other times
column25: the government said. For more than a year
column26: only a handful of flights each day have operated between New York and London
column27: which used to be one of the world’s busiest travel routes. There are even fewer direct flights from London to other major American cities. The issue of limited flights between New York and London has been raised several times a day
column28: said Emanuel Adam
column29: the executive director in London of BritishAmerican Business
column30: which represents some trans-Atlantic companies. “It’s frustrating to many businesses and scary because they don’t know yet what it will mean down the line
column31: ” he said. At the same time
column32: businesses are conscious of the health concerns raised by the spread of the Delta variant of the coronavirus in Britain
column33: he said. And now
column34: restrictions against Britons are tightening; this week
column35: Hong Kong barred all travelers from Britain. In March 2020
column36: President Donald J. Trump banned nearly all non-Americans traveling from Britain
column37: and President Biden has kept the rule in place. There was a small breakthrough at the Group of 7 meetings in Britain earlier this month when the two sides agreed to set up a working group to restart international travel
column38: but likelihood of an agreement for travel to return before the fall is reportedly getting slimmer. “Many other countries have introduced similar exemptions

Fox News agrees to a $1 million penalty after workplace culture investigation. Bill O’Reilly was forced out of his Fox News show in 2017 after a series of sexual misconduct allegations against him. Credit... Robert Wright for The New York Times Fox News agreed to pay a $1 million penalty under a settlement reached last week with the New York City Commission on Human Rights. The case stemmed from a cascade of sexual misconduct allegations that shook the network several years ago and led to the exits of Roger Ailes
column2: its co-founder
column3: and the anchor Bill O’Reilly. “This is the largest civil penalty that has ever been levied by the City Commission on Human Rights
column4: ” the agency’s chair and commissioner
column5: Carmelyn P. Malalis
column6: said in an interview on Tuesday. “We need to send a message in order to deter future acts of harassment or retaliation.” The settlement
column7: which was finalized on June 25
column8: will prevent Fox News for the next four years from including in new employment contracts a clause requiring confidential arbitration in cases where an employee lodges a complaint under the city’s Human Rights Law. It also mandates that the network carry out a variety of anti-harassment training and prevention measures. The Commission on Human Rights is the agency that enforces the city’s anti-discrimination laws in workplaces
column9: housing
column10: public services and other spheres. Ms. Malalis said the commission began investigating Fox News in September 2017
column11: around the time that several employees spoke out about sexual harassment at the network; it formally opened a complaint in December 2018. In a statement on Tuesday
column12: Fox News said it was “pleased to reach an amicable resolution of this legacy matter.” “Fox News Media has already been in full compliance across the board
column13: but cooperated with the New York City Commission on Human Rights to continue enacting extensive preventive measures against all forms of discrimination and harassment
column14: ” the network said. In the last few years
column15: Fox News has hired a new human resources team and strengthened sensitivity training requirements
column16: among other measures intended to reform its workplace culture. The network’s agreement last week to pay a $1 million penalty was first reported by The Daily Beast. Read more

column1: England opens up a narrow quarantine exemption for business travelers. A sign posted in London’s Heathrow Airport. Visitors from the United States
column2: an amber list country
column3: must quarantine for 10 days. But Britain is allowing an exemption for executives of companies with over 500 employees. Credit... Andy Rain/EPA
column4: via Shutterstock The British government introduced a new exemption to its quarantine rules on Tuesday for business travelers “bringing significant economic benefit” to England
column5: but the move is unlikely to quell frustrations that certain travel routes in and out of Britain remain effectively shut. The exemption has strict criteria and applies only to executives whose work supports at least 500 British jobs. It is much tighter than one that was in place for about six weeks from early December
column6: when travelers needed to support only 50 jobs in Britain. There has been a growing concern that Britain’s strict travel rules could lead the country to miss out on business opportunities as other countries welcome the return of travelers
column7: especially from the United States. Since Britain left the European Union
column8: it is also particularly anxious about not losing lucrative business activity to its neighbors across the English Channel. Parts of Britain
column9: such as the financial and legal district of the City of London
column10: rely heavily on the presence of large multinational corporations. But most people entering the country either must quarantine for 10 days and take coronavirus tests on the second and eighth days or must pay for an additional test to end their self-isolation after five days. Earlier this month
column11: France reopened its borders to vaccinated American tourists
column12: and last week
column13: Germany said all Americans could enter the country. Jamie Dimon
column14: the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase
column15: met with President Emmanuel Macron of France this week in Paris and opened up a new European Union trading hub on Tuesday. The bank is increasing the number of staff in Paris to 700 by the end of the year
column16: up from 265 before Britain left the European Union. But Mr. Dimon won’t be stopping in Britain
column17: where the company has 19
column18: 000 employees and offices in four cities
column19: as he has in past trips to Europe
column20: because of the country’s travel restrictions. Any executives hoping to leave quarantine will have to meet strict requirements
column21: including proving that the work being done in England “has a greater than 50 percent chance of creating or preserving at least 500 U.K.-based jobs” at a company that already has at least 500 employees or at a new British business. Executives have to apply to the government and get written approval
column22: which can take up to five days
column23: before traveling. When the executive isn’t doing business activity
column24: they must self-isolate at all other times
column25: the government said. For more than a year
column26: only a handful of flights each day have operated between New York and London
column27: which used to be one of the world’s busiest travel routes. There are even fewer direct flights from London to other major American cities. The issue of limited flights between New York and London has been raised several times a day
column28: said Emanuel Adam
column29: the executive director in London of BritishAmerican Business
column30: which represents some trans-Atlantic companies. “It’s frustrating to many businesses and scary because they don’t know yet what it will mean down the line
column31: ” he said. At the same time
column32: businesses are conscious of the health concerns raised by the spread of the Delta variant of the coronavirus in Britain
column33: he said. And now
column34: restrictions against Britons are tightening; this week
column35: Hong Kong barred all travelers from Britain. In March 2020
column36: President Donald J. Trump banned nearly all non-Americans traveling from Britain
column37: and President Biden has kept the rule in place. There was a small breakthrough at the Group of 7 meetings in Britain earlier this month when the two sides agreed to set up a working group to restart international travel
column38: but likelihood of an agreement for travel to return before the fall is reportedly getting slimmer. “Many other countries have introduced similar exemptions
column39: and it is important the U.K. does not lose out on prospective major investments and new jobs as a result
column40: ” a government representative said in a statement. Read more

column1: Nikole Hannah-Jones’s tenure application will go before the U.N.C. board. A vote on tenure for the journalist Nikole Hannah-Jones is scheduled for Wednesday. Credit... James Estrin/The New York Times The University of North Carolina’s board of trustees is scheduled to hold a special meeting on Wednesday amid intensifying pressure over its failure to approve tenure for Nikole Hannah-Jones
column2: the Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent for The New York Times Magazine. A spokeswoman for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc.
column3: which is representing the journalist
column4: confirmed that the board was scheduled to vote on tenure for Ms. Hannah-Jones during the meeting. Ms. Hannah-Jones
column5: a creator of the 1619 Project
column6: a multimedia series from The Times Magazine that re-examined the legacy of slavery in the United States
column7: had agreed to a July 1 start date as the Knight Chair in Race and Investigative Journalism at the university’s Hussman School of Journalism and Media. In a letter last week
column8: her legal team said she would not join the faculty unless she was granted tenure. The University of North Carolina announced the meeting of the board
column9: which approves tenure applications
column10: in a news release on Monday. The release did not disclose the meeting’s agenda but said it was expected to include a closed session. Shortly after the meeting was announced
column11: Susan King
column12: the dean of the Hussman School
column13: said on Twitter that the board was “completing the tenure process begun so long ago to bring Nikole Hannah-Jones to our school.” Although the dean
column14: the school’s faculty members
column15: the provost and the chancellor had recommended tenure for Ms. Hannah-Jones
column16: the board declined to vote on the matter at a meeting this year. Ms. Hannah-Jones retained legal counsel to address the board’s lack of action in the matter. The hiring of Ms. Hannah-Jones
column17: who earned a master’s degree from the university’s journalism school in 2003
column18: prompted a backlash from some conservatives who have been critical of the 1619 Project’s reframing of American history. The journalist has also gained the public support of more than 200 academics and other cultural figures who published a letter in The Root last month saying the board had displayed a “failure of courage.” On Friday
column19: students at the university held a protest in support of Ms. Hannah-Jones. Ms. King
column20: the Hussman School dean
column21: included a link to a video of the demonstration in a Twitter post. “We so appreciate our great UNC students’ support & other schools’ support
column22: ” the dean wrote. Read more

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/business/hong-kong-chow-po-chung.html/Hong Kong Philosopher Taught Life’s Meaning. Now He Visits Students in Jail./"Mr. Chow has been deeply involved in the city’s pro-democracy movement. As a high school student
column2: he protested the Tiananmen crackdown in 1989. He taught John Rawls’s “A Theory of Justice” on the site of the 2014 Umbrella Movement and was arrested briefly on the last day of the pro-democracy protest. He went to many demonstrations in 2019 as an observer
column3: watching as Beijing cracked down ruthlessly. All of them failed
column4: and the security law was the final blow.

column1: “The things that should not have happened in a normal society happened
column2: ” he said in an interview at his home on the campus of the Chinese University of Hong Kong. “I’m talking about the most outstanding people
column3: the kind of people that should be held up as role models
column4: are being attacked and sentenced to jail.”

column1: For two decades
column2: Mr. Chow encouraged his students to examine the meaning of life and become active and conscientious citizens who help build societies based on values such as justice and liberty.

column1: I asked whether he taught the same thing now. He paused for nearly a minute and opened his mouth several times before saying he had stopped telling his students to be active participants.
“Of course
column2: I still tell them to care about the society and be responsible for their lives
column3: ” he said. “But it’s no longer easy to tell them what they should do because participating in political and public affairs has become a highly risky act.”

column1: Mr. Chow has enjoyed the kind of opportunities and freedom Hong Kong used to offer to its residents. Born in the southern province of Guangdong
column2: he migrated to the former British colony in 1985 at the age of 12. His family lived in a poor neighborhood in Kowloon
column3: but he thrived academically and enrolled in the Chinese University of Hong Kong."/['Li Yuan']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/business/30newworld-1/30newworld-1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/28/world/asia/china-hong-kong-security-law.html/Crossing the Red Line: Behind China’s Takeover of Hong Kong/"Hong Kong’s march toward an authoritarian future began with a single phrase in a dry policy paper. Beijing
column2: the document declared
column3: would wield “comprehensive jurisdiction” over the territory.

column1: The paper
column2: published in June 2014
column3: signaled the Chinese leader Xi Jinping’s determination to tame political defiance in the former British colony
column4: which had kept its own laws and freedoms. But the words were dismissed by many as intimidating swagger that the city’s robust legal system and democratic opposition could face down.

column1: Hong Kong now knows Mr. Xi’s ambitions with a stunned clarity. The paper marked the opening of a contest for control in the city
column2: culminating in the sweeping national security law that few saw coming.

column1: Since that law took force one year ago
column2: Beijing has unleashed a stampede of actions to bring Hong Kong into political lock step with the Chinese Communist Party: arresting activists
column3: seizing assets
column4: firing government workers
column5: detaining newspaper editors and rewriting school curriculums."/['Chris Buckley'

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/world/asia/hong-kong-security-law-anniversary.html/‘A Form of Brainwashing’: China Remakes Hong Kong/"HONG KONG — With each passing day
column2: the boundary between Hong Kong and the rest of China fades faster.

column1: The Chinese Communist Party is remaking this city
column2: permeating its once vibrant
column3: irreverent character with ever more overt signs of its authoritarian will. The very texture of daily life is under assault as Beijing molds Hong Kong into something more familiar
column4: more docile.

column1: Residents now swarm police hotlines with reports about disloyal neighbors or colleagues. Teachers have been told to imbue students with patriotic fervor through 48-volume book sets called “My Home Is in China.” Public libraries have removed dozens of books from circulation
column2: including one about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Nelson Mandela."/['Vivian Wang'

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/opinion/northern-ireland-centenary.html/Opinion | Northern Ireland Is Coming to an End/"BELFAST
column2: Northern Ireland — It was meant to be a year of celebration.

column1: But Northern Ireland
column2: created in 1921 when Britain carved six counties out of Ireland’s northeast
column3: is not enjoying its centenary. Its most ardent upholders
column4: the unionists who believe that the place they call “our wee country” is and must forever remain an intrinsic part of the United Kingdom
column5: are in utter disarray. Their largest party has ousted two leaders within a matter of weeks
column6: while an angry minority has taken to the streets waving flags and threatening violence. And the British government
column7: in resolving Brexit
column8: placed a new border in the Irish Sea.

column1: It’s harsh reward for what Northern Ireland’s first prime minister
column2: James Craig
column3: called “the most loyal part of Great Britain.” But the Protestant statelet is not what it was. Well on its way to having a Catholic majority
column4: the country’s once dominant political force — unionism — now finds itself out of step with the community that traditionally gave it uncritical support. And for all his talk of the territorial integrity of the United Kingdom
column5: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has made clear his government would cheerfully ditch this last little fragment of Britain’s empire if it continues to complicate Brexit.

column1: The writing is on the wall. While the process by which Ireland could become unified is complicated and fraught
column2: one thing seems certain: There isn’t going to be a second centenary for Northern Ireland. It might not even last another decade.

column1: A hundred years ago
column2: the mood among unionists was jubilant. When the king and queen of England came to Belfast to mark the opening of the new Northern Ireland Parliament
column3: the streets were decked out with red
column4: white and blue bunting. “The people could not contain themselves
column5: ” according to Cecil Craig
column6: the wife of the new prime minister. “All Irishmen
column7: ” King George V said
column8: should “join in making for the land which they love a new era of peace
column9: contentment and good will.”"/['Susan Mckay']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/opinion/30McKay/30McKay-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/opinion/covid-reopening-anxiety.html/Reopening Anxiety? You're Not Alone. - The New York Times/"As the pandemic winds down in the United States
column2: people are emerging from their cocoons
column3: all fired up and ready to celebrate in a communal explosion of relief and pent-up desire. The sense of anticipation is so great that some
column4: with lusty hope
column5: have called the coming months “The Summer of Love.”

column1: But in the Opinion video above
column2: we explore how not everyone is feeling this way. Many people across the country are harboring a deep anxiety as the world around them kicks back into gear.

column1: In the video
column2: you will hear from some of these quieter voices. They explain that as much as they want the pandemic to end
column3: it has also provided them with some relief from challenges
column4: inequities and injuries that were all too common in their prepandemic lives.

column1: Kirsten Imani Kasai
column3: a novelist in San Diego and self-described introvert
column4: describes how she found comfort and safety in the relative quietude of the past year — and fears the return of a noisier
column5: more-demanding world. Emily Ladau
column7: a disability rights activist in Long Island
column8: N.Y.
column9: says she worries that the shift back to in-person interactions will force her
column10: once again

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/opinion/trump-letter-chris-kapenga.html/Opinion | Dear Leader: A Near-Perfect Letter From a Trump Sycophant
column2: Annotated/"Mr. President

column1: One of the most frustrating things to watch during your presidency was the continued attacks on you from fake news outlets with no accountability to truth.
It is helpful early on to slip in a common Trumpian term like “fake news” or “Deep State” or “alternative facts.” This makes clear that you are operating in the same alternative reality as Mr. Trump.
I can’t imagine the frustration you and your family felt. Unfortunately
column2: in our positions of public service
column3: we have to accept the reality that often “truth” in the media is no longer based on facts but simply what one feels like saying.

column1: Media bashing is a requirement when soliciting Mr. Trump. If you’re not willing to go there
column2: don’t even bother.

column1: This leads me to your recent press release stating that I am responsible for holding up a forensic audit of the Wisconsin elections. This could not be further from the truth.
The segue here from sucking up to gentle criticism is a smidge bumpy. And keep in mind that “truth” is a malleable concept for Mr. Trump.
Let me first say that very few people have the honor of being named publicly by a United States president.
Now you’re back on track: Having raised your concern
column2: it is best to immediately backpedal and layer on more flattery. Plowing ahead with the details of your complaint without proper fertilizing risks getting Mr. Trump’s dander up.

column1: I never imagined mine would be mentioned
column2: much less in this light
column3: from a President that I have publicly supported
column4: and still support.

column1: The genius of this sentence is that it sounds as though you’re expressing gratitude
column2: even as you are expressing dismay.

column1: I feel I need to respond even though you will likely never hear of it
column2: as the power of your pen to mine is like Thor’s hammer to a Bobby pin.

column1: Bonus points for going with a deity from Norse mythology. Mr. Trump clearly has a soft spot for the region
column2: to the point that he expressed a desire for more Norwegian immigrants and even eyed buying Greenland from Denmark.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: I need to correct your false claim against me.

column1: Oof. Another misstep: “False” is such a harsh
column2: judgmental word. Would have been safer to go with “inaccurate” or
column3: better still
column4: “imprecise.”

column1: I never received a call from you or any of your sources asking about the election audit. If you had
column2: I would have told you that long before your press release I called the auditor in charge of the election audit that is taking place in Wisconsin and requested a forensic component to the audit.

column1: Suggesting that Mr. Trump has behaved in any way other than perfectly is always dicey. What saves you here is immediately following up with reassurances that you
column2: in fact
column3: behaved exactly as he wanted.

column1: Prior to owning several businesses
column2: I was an auditor
column3: so I understand the importance of this being done to determine what took place in the last election. This will help guide us as legislators to put fixes in place for any issues found
column4: and more importantly
column5: to ensure the integrity of elections moving forward.

column1: Deft
column2: fast pivot to expressing solidarity with Mr. Trump’s contention that there were serious voting “issues” requiring legislative “fixes.”

column1: I made specific requests on procedures and locations
column2: both of which I have not
column3: nor will not
column4: disclose. If I am not satisfied with the procedures performed
column5: I will request additional work be done. If anyone illegally attempts to hinder information from being obtained
column6: I will use my subpoena powers to get it.

column1: Always good to throw in a bit of tough-guy posturing about how none of the libs or Deep State plotters can stand in the way of your mission.
This leads me back to your press release. It is false
column2: and I don’t appreciate it being done before calling me and finding out the truth. This is what both of us have fought against.

column1: It is unclear what anyone is fighting against here
column2: but clarity should never be an impediment to flattery.

column1: Being cut from similar cloth in our backgrounds
column2: and knowing that reparation must always be of more value than the wrong done
column3: I have two requests.

column1: Curiously
column2: Wikipedia identifies Mr. Kapenga as an accountant and business owner who has been in state politics for more than a decade. This would appear to make him as similar to the high-flying reality TV star and New York real estate scion as corduroy culottes are to cheetah-skin hot pants.

column1: First
column2: I ask that you issue a press release in similar fashion that corrects the information and also encourages people to support what I have requested in the audit.

column1: Smart to sweeten your real ask by pairing it with something that Mr. Trump wants.
Second
column2: you owe me a round of golf at the club of your choice.

column1: Valiant attempt to lighten the mood while also playing to Mr. Trump’s vanity regarding the family business. Plus
column2: offering him the chance to beat you at golf is smart
column3: even if it requires you to throw the round.

column1: I write this as I am about to board a plane due to a family medical emergency.
Bold move to appeal to Mr. Trump’s humanity.
In addition to my Trump socks
column2: I will pull up my Trump/Pence mask when I board the plane
column3: as required by federal law.

column1: This bit of toadyism may feel like it’s going too far
column2: but
column3: with Mr. Trump
column4: too far is never enough. And it never hurts to take a shot at the feds.

column1: I figure
column2: if the liberals are going to force me to wear a mask
column3: I am going to make it as painful for them as possible.

column1: Always remember that the throbbing heart of Trumpism is owning the libs.
I will continue to do this regardless of whether or not I ever hear from you.
Nice dismount! Emphasizes that you have internalized Trumpian values and will live by them even if the former president does not heed your imploration.
Thank you for doing great things as our president.
Always close with straight-up bootlicking. Don’t try to be fancy — or subtle.
Respectfully
Chris Kapenga
Wisconsin Senate President"/['Michelle Cottle']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/opinion/30cottle/30cottle-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/opinion/nyc-mayor-election-boe-votes.html/Opinion | The N.Y.C. Elections Board Is a Disaster. This Is the Last Straw./"New Yorkers have endured the incompetence of the city’s Board of Elections for so long that complaints on the subject blend into the background noise of life in a megalopolis
column2: alongside gripes about overstuffed subway cars and putrid piles of sidewalk trash.

column1: This page called the board “at best a semi‐functioning anachronism” — and that was 50 years ago.
Nary an election passes without another reminder of how much contempt the agency has for the city’s vast
column2: diverse electorate. Accidentally purged voter rolls
column3: misaddressed absentee ballots
column4: intolerably long lines. The catalog of dysfunction and neglect seems endless.

column1: Yet somehow the board found a new way to humiliate itself and the city
column2: one week after 800
column3: 000 New Yorkers went to the polls to cast ballots in the most consequential mayoral primaries in a generation. Or was it 940
column4: 000 New Yorkers? Good question. For several bewildering hours on Tuesday
column5: no one had an answer.

column1: The first number
column2: which the board reported shortly after polls closed on June 22
column3: reflected the first-place votes cast in person during early voting and on Election Day
column4: and showed Eric Adams with a commanding lead in the Democratic primary. The second number included the full ranked-choice tallies of those same ballots and
column5: to the shock of the political establishment
column6: appeared to show Kathryn Garcia vaulting from third place into a near tie with Mr. Adams. But political observers across the city soon flagged the vote-total discrepancy. So did Mr. Adams
column7: who rightly demanded an explanation for the “irregularities.”"/['The Editorial Board']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/opinion/30election-01/30election-01-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column8: in a part of Nicetown-Tioga
column9: where the median household income is roughly $37
column11: trees cover only 6 percent of the area. The average temperature is more than 10 degrees higher. Decades ago
column12: this area was “redlined” and classified as “D” by the federal government limiting investments and economic growth because of its racial makeup. Such discriminatory practices still shape our cities and
column13: along with income inequality
column14: define who can enjoy a healthy tree canopy and who is surrounded by concrete.

column1: By Ian Leahy and Yaryna Serkez Ian Leahy is the vice president of urban forestry at American Forests. Yaryna Serkez is a writer and a graphics editor for Opinion.
Access to clean air and outdoor activities seems like a basic right. But in cities across the country
column2: lower-income communities and communities of color more often live in neighborhoods with a higher share of concrete surfaces such as roads
column3: buildings and parking lots
column4: and a very limited number of trees and parks.

column1: Rich Americans enjoy almost 50 percent more greenery in their environment compared with lower-income communities. Median share of tree canopy
Neighborhoods with a majority of people in poverty have 25 percent less tree canopy on average than those with a minority of people in poverty
column2: according to American Forests’ Tree Equity Score tool that analyzes income
column3: employment
column4: age
column5: ethnicity
column6: health and surface temperature with tree canopy data in 486 metro areas.

column1: In the most extreme cases
column2: wealthy areas have 65 percent more tree canopy than communities where nine out of 10 people live below the poverty line.

column1: Rich Americans enjoy more greenery in their environment compared with people in lower-income communities. This trend is present in cities across the country. In certain areas the difference can be particularly striking.
Communities with too few trees are feeling the consequences this week
column2: as a heat wave sweeps through much of the Pacific Northwest. The average temperature can vary to up to 10 degrees between places with trees and those without. And where there is more heat
column3: there is more death: Heat kills more people in the United States than any other kind of extreme weather. We can expect up to a tenfold increase in heat-related deaths in the eastern United States by the latter half of the 2050s and at least a 70 percent increase in the largest cities nationwide by 2050.

column1: Trees today prevent approximately 1
column2: 200 more heat-related deaths annually in American cities.

column1: Being in the vicinity of this living infrastructure provides many other benefits: Healthy trees trap air pollutants
column2: which helps avoid 670
column3: 000 incidences of acute respiratory symptoms each year. Being in the presence of trees has also been found to improve youth educational performance
column4: mental health
column5: physical health and social connections. A well-maintained tree canopy may even reduce several types of crime and create economic opportunities
column6: including careers that cannot be outsourced to plant and maintain those trees.

column1: So if there is no question that trees are important
column2: why doesn’t everyone have access to them? There is an emerging body of research from the U.S. Forest Service and others that has found a direct relationship between tree canopy today and discriminatory policies of the past.

column1: In predominantly white areas
column2: trees cover one-third of the surface. In communities of color
column3: barely one-fifth. Median share of tree canopy

column1: For example
column2: from the 1930s to the 1960s and even the 1970s
column3: a practice of discriminatory lending now known as “redlining” was carried out in cities across the country
column4: from Los Angeles to Baltimore. Color-coded maps dissuaded not only mortgage but also health care and infrastructure investments based on where people lived. The red lines that were drawn around neighborhoods — predominantly Black as well as Catholic
column5: Jewish and immigrant — now often line up very closely with maps showing a lack of tree canopy today.

column1: Areas that were given an “A” grade at the time were characterized by U.S.-born white populations in newer houses. Today
column2: these same neighborhoods have nearly twice as much tree coverage than communities of color that were “redlined” by receiving the “D” grade
column3: according to a recent paper analyzing 37 metro areas.

column1: These disinvestments have a tangible impact on social equity issues. A University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign study of 98 Chicago public housing buildings with residents of similar socioeconomic situations found that when controlling for a number of other factors
column2: more vegetation near a building contributed to 52 percent fewer crimes overall and 56 percent fewer violent crimes.

column1: With temperatures rising and economic disparities widening
column2: trees are indispensable infrastructure. However
column3: ensuring the right tree is planted in the right place is no easy feat. It requires expertise in selecting the most resilient and beneficial species. Planners must prepare for warming climates
column4: allow existing trees to thrive and integrate new trees with competing infrastructure. Political will and financing from the public and private sectors are needed long before a tree is planted.

column1: Despite these challenges
column2: opportunities can be found everywhere.

column1: Birmingham
column2: Alabama.

column1: Median household income: $37
column2: 976 . For example
column3: Detroit’s post-industrial landscape has the potential to become a national model for equitable green cities. Almost half of the city’s census block groups have a Tree Equity Score below 80 out of the 100 necessary to achieve an equitable balance of greenery. It would take about 400
column4: 000 more trees just to reach that minimal threshold. By starting in areas the city has already targeted for inclusionary growth
column5: such as diverse
column6: immigrant-rich Campau/Banglatown
column7: the narrative can change from trees being expendable to their becoming a critical infrastructure capable of improving child well-being
column8: public health and employment.

column1: Tree Equity Score shows it will take 522 million more trees to achieve an equitable balance of greenery in every neighborhood in metro areas with 50
column2: 000 people or more in the continental United States.

column1: Getting there requires a lot more funding to both plant new and maintain existing trees. Some promising tools have emerged to help boost investment
column2: including social impact bonds (which pay investors based on such outcomes as reduced prison recidivism) and voluntary carbon markets like City Forest Credits (a registry that issues tree planting and protection credits that can be purchased by companies to offset emissions).

column1: But an ambitious goal like 522 million new trees cannot be achieved without the public sector. There are numerous opportunities to begin addressing tree equity in cities
column2: such as through the infrastructure legislation working through Congress
column3: substantially increasing support for the Urban and Community Forestry program and proposals to create programs at federal agencies focused on housing
column4: energy and transportation.

column1: Reaching these ambitious targets would have an outsize impact on life-saving health outcomes
column2: quality of life and slowing climate change
column3: all while supporting over three million jobs
column4: especially in neighborhoods that now lack greenery."/['Ian Leahy'

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/opinion/eric-adams-kathryn-garcia-maya-wiley.html/Opinion | Eric Adams Says He’s the ‘Face of the New Democratic Party.’ Is He Right?/"The results in the mayoral primary so far are evidence of the continuing power of Black voters to act as a moderating force in a Democratic Party that has seen growing numbers of white voters shift decisively to the left. The results also suggest that Adams’s strategy of taking a strong stand on public safety in support of the police
column2: combined with a call to end abusive police practices
column3: is an effective way for the party to counter the small but significant Black and Hispanic defections to the Republican Party that began to emerge in the 2020 presidential election.

column1: I posed a series of questions about the implications of the still-unresolved New York City Democratic Primary to a group of scholars and analysts.
Nolan McCarty
column2: a political scientist at Princeton
column3: argues that the initial tally affirmed a basic but often overlooked truth about the Democratic Party nationwide:

column1: The outcomes are more evidence of an innumerate punditry that conflates the share of educated
column2: professional voters who support the Democratic Party with their electoral clout. It remains true that a majority of Democratic voters are working class without college degrees. So it is the same dynamic in New York that played out in the presidential race. While other candidates battled over of the support of the highly educated segments (of all races)
column3: Biden understood where the votes were.

column1: While most of the national attention has focused on levels of education in shaping the partisanship of white voters — with the more educated moving left and the less well educated moving right — a parallel split has been quietly developing within the multiracial Democratic coalition. Ray La Raja
column2: a political scientist at the University of Massachusetts-Amherst
column3: elaborated in his reply to my email:

column1: There has been a growing education and age divide in the Democratic Party beyond racial divisions. Additionally
column2: Adams tapped into an N.Y.C. pattern of politicians winning with strong “outer borough” ethnic support. In the past it was white ethnics — Italians
column3: Irish and Poles living in the Bronx
column4: Brooklyn and Queens — who supported the Tammany-style politicians. Today it is Hispanics and Blacks from different parts of the diaspora supporting Adams
column5: who leveraged his shared background with voters
column6: with ties to powerful political institutions (e.g.
column7: municipal unions) much like Tammany.

column1: Older Black voters
column2: La Raja continued

column1: will continue to be a moderating force in the Democratic Party. They deliver votes and they are pragmatic in their vote choices. They bear the traces of New Deal liberalism with bread-and-butter concerns about jobs
column2: education and safe neighborhoods to raise families.

column1: There are significant differences between the values and agendas that shape the voting decisions of the Garcia constituency
column2: of the Wiley electorate
column3: and of those Black voters who were the core of Adams’s support
column4: La Raja notes:

column1: Garcia won the good government progressives and liberals south of 110th street in Manhattan
column2: who are more likely to be executives at major institutions of finance
column3: technology
column4: entertainment and fashion. These voters want a livable city to support their institutions. They — like The New York Times editorial board — believe Garcia is the most credible on managing city operations. Wiley
column5: in contrast
column6: gets the young progressives just across the river in Brooklyn and Queens who haven’t quite made it up the career ladder yet. They have fewer institutional responsibilities. They are less likely to vote out of a desire to get well-functioning government and more based on their personal values.

column1: Jonathan Rieder
column2: a sociologist at Barnard and the author of “Canarsie: The Jews and Italians of Brooklyn Against Liberalism
column3: ” had more to say in his reply:

column1: The local discussion of crime gets entangled in the national culture war within the Democratic Party and within “liberalism.” As with “limousine liberalism” before it
column2: what some dub “woke” liberalism flourishes in the zones of the educated and often affluent whose lives
column3: neighborhoods and moral understandings differ from those of working and middle class people.

column1: Because of this
column2: Rieder contends
column3: the party remains caught in what has become a 50-year “battle between what used to be called ‘lunch-pail’ Democrats and more righteous ones
column4: between James Clyburn and AOC.”

column1: Rieder argues that
For all the gradual shrinkage of white non-college voters
column2: the Democrats still require a multicultural middle to include non-affluent and lesser educated whites in their majority coalition. And that will be hard to secure if the party is identified with ceding the border
column3: lawlessness
column4: ignoring less privileged whites
column5: exclusionary versions of anti-racist diversity that smack of thought reform
column6: phrasing like Latinx that large numbers of Latinos find off-putting
column7: esoteric or perplexing
column8: and so much more.

column1: Taking a more optimistic stance
column2: Omar Wasow
column3: a political scientist at Princeton
column4: acknowledges that the primary “reflected these intraparty divisions along lines of race
column5: income and education
column6: ” but
column7: he argues

column1: What was more surprising was the level of cohesion. Candidates from a wide range of backgrounds ran and
column2: overall
column3: there was remarkably little race-baiting rhetoric. In the final high-pressure days of the campaign
column4: calls to vote along racial or ethnic lines did increase but
column5: given the high level of diversity in the candidate pool and in New York City more broadly
column6: the relatively limited presence of appeals to in-group solidarity or out-group antipathy was remarkable. While some of this behavior is specific to New York
column7: it also likely reflects a strong norm among elite Democrats more generally that certain kinds of ethnic threat and resentment politics are off-limits.

column1: Wasow agrees that Black voters have become a moderating force in Democratic politics:
Put simply
column2: direct experiences of racism and dreams deferred appears to have forged a more moderate or pragmatic politics among African Americans. Where the whiter
column3: more liberal wing of the Democratic Party was considerably more optimistic about the country’s willingness to elect a woman
column4: a democratic socialist or a person of color
column5: African Americans exhibited far more skepticism. Given the narrow margins with which President Biden won
column6: the Black assessment of national white voting behavior does seem to have been more accurate.

column1: For two generations
column2: Wasow continued
column3: “Democrats have struggled to articulate a response to attacks that they’re ‘soft on crime.’ Some candidates co-opted toughness and others emphasized ‘root causes’ but ‘law and order’ kept winning.”

column1: In this context
column2: according to Wasow
column3: “Adams’s activism as a cop against police abuse is a powerful embodiment of the position that recognizes both demand for reform and desire for public safety.”

column1: Adams affirmed this two-pronged stance toward policing and crime on his website:
Our city faces an unprecedented crisis that threatens to undo the progress we have made against crime. Gun arrests
column2: shootings and hate crimes are up; people do not feel safe in their homes or on the street. As a police officer who patrolled the streets in a bulletproof vest in the 1990s
column3: I watched lawlessness spread through our city
column4: infecting communities with the same terrible swiftness of Covid-19.

column1: At the same time
column2: Adams declared

column1: We face a crisis of confidence in our police. I understand that mistrust because as a young man
column2: police beat my brother and I at a precinct house — and we still carry the pain of that. I called out racism in the NYPD as an officer and helped push through reforms
column3: including the successful effort to stop the unlawful use of Stop-and-Frisk. The debate around policing has been reduced to a false choice: You are either with police
column4: or you are against them. That is simply wrong because we are all for safety. We need the NYPD — we just need them to be better.

column1: The strong appeal to Black voters of a candidate like Adams who combines calls to reform police behavior while simultaneously pushing for aggressive enforcement to increase public safety can be seen in the results of a survey Vesla Weaver
column2: a political scientist at Johns Hopkins
column3: conducted with colleagues during the week after George Floyd’s murder."/['Thomas B. Edsall']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/opinion/30edsall-lead/30edsall-lead-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/opinion/china-us-competition.html/Opinion | ‘China Has Risen.’ And It Is Hungry for Competition./"When the Soviet Union crumbled in the 1990s
column2: Americans did a victory lap that lasted for decades. We saw it as the triumph of capitalism over communism
column3: freedom over authoritarianism
column4: democracy over one-party rule. We assumed that the game was over and that we had won. We had reached “the end of history.” We thought that it was only a matter of time before China
column5: which had already embraced some free-market reforms
column6: transitioned to a system just like ours. Americans normalized trade with China and waited patiently for the “Chinese Gorbachev.” If you’re still out there waiting
column7: don’t hold your breath.

column1: On July 1
column2: the Chinese Communist Party celebrates its 100th birthday
column3: under President Xi Jinping
column4: a man who learned a very different lesson from the Soviet Union’s demise. To him
column5: the Soviet Union dissolved not because communism is doomed but because Soviet party officials had become corrupt and lost their convictions. One of the first pledges he made as party leader in 2013 was that he would never let that happen in China.

column1: The great debate over which system is better hasn’t faded away. In fact
column2: it’s gearing up for another round. But rather than see competition with China as a zero-sum game
column3: the United States could embrace a way of competing that spurs us to make investments in our people that we should have been making all along.

column1: Mr. Xi’s Communist Party has ruled China since 1949 — longer than any other surviving political party on earth
column2: except for North Korea’s. The Chinese Communist Party didn’t just outlive its Soviet patrons. It has overseen an economy far more vibrant and prosperous than the Soviet Union’s. When Communists took over China
column3: only about 20 percent of the country could read and write. Today 97 percent of Chinese adults are literate. Per capita G.D.P. grew to over $10
column4: 000 today
column5: from less than $90 in 1960. China’s economy looks poised to be bigger than the U.S. economy by 2028
column6: a trend that has accelerated with the Covid-19 pandemic. China is investing in military strength
column7: opening its first overseas military base
column8: in Djibouti. But its economic power is even more formidable. China has quietly become the biggest lender in the world
column9: surpassing the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund combined."/['Farah Stockman']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/opinion/30stockman-03/30stockman-03-facebookJumbo-v2.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/opinion/education-covid-pandemic-principals.html/Opinion | ‘How Many Kids Are We Going to Lose?’ Four Principals Speak About the Past Year./"In the middle of March 2020
column2: schools across America closed abruptly. It didn’t take long to notice everything that disappeared — a safe place to send children while parents worked
column3: nutritious meals and health services for high-need students
column4: opportunities for young people to play and socialize with one another.

column1: We invited several principals to share what it was like to navigate their schools through this crisis. We sought out leaders of public schools from different parts of the country with varying pandemic experiences: a combined middle and high school in the small town of Pittsfield
column2: N.H.; an elementary school in a poor neighborhood near downtown St. Louis; a middle school in San Francisco that stayed shut for more than a year; and a large and diverse high school in Central Florida
column3: one of the first states to reopen all of its K-12 campuses.

column1: In our conversation
column2: the principals talked about how there’s a renewed sense of appreciation for the role schools play as community anchors. As Deborah Rogers
column3: principal of Patrick Henry Downtown Academy in St. Louis put it
column4: a school “provides service after service after service.” That
column5: she said
column6: was “a hard thing for people not in education to see until it was all taken away.”

column1: But there’s also work to be done to rebuild trust — between families and schools
column2: administration and staff
column3: teachers and students. The lessons of the pandemic can help spur school leaders to rethink how and where students learn
column4: what teachers and staff members need
column5: and how to nurture lasting connections between schools and the communities they serve."/['Emily Richmond']/2021-06-30 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/opinion/30robertson-08/30robertson-08-facebookJumbo-v2.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/opinion/heat-dome-climate-change.html/Climate Change Is Behind Heat Dome - The New York Times/"These changes matter because extreme heat is the deadliest form of extreme weather in the United States
column2: causing more deaths on average than hurricanes and floods combined over the past 30 years. Recent research projects that heat stress will triple in the Pacific Northwest by 2100 unless aggressive action is taken to reduce heat-trapping greenhouse gas emissions.

column1: Some still refuse to acknowledge the dire warning that Mother Nature is sending us. They say the science is too unsettled to take action. But uncertainty
column2: if anything
column3: is a reason for taking even more significant action to reduce carbon emissions. Uncertainty is not our friend. And the current heat dome is an excellent example of why.

column1: The heat wave afflicting the Pacific Northwest is characterized by what is known as an omega block pattern
column2: because of the shape the sharply curving jet stream makes
column3: like the Greek letter omega (Ω). This omega curve is part of a pattern of pronounced north-south wiggles made by the jet stream as it traverses the Northern Hemisphere. It is an example of a phenomenon known as wave resonance
column4: which scientists (including one of us) have shown is increasingly favored by the considerable warming of the Arctic.

column1: By decreasing the contrast in temperature between the cold pole and warm subtropics
column2: the amplified warming of the Arctic causes the jet stream to slow down and
column3: under the right circumstances
column4: like the ones prevailing now
column5: settle into a very wiggly and rather stable configuration. That
column6: in turn
column7: allows very deep high pressure centers
column8: like the current heat dome
column9: to remain locked in place over a region
column10: as it is over the Pacific Northwest.

column1: Those climate models that the critics claim are alarmist do a poor job of reproducing this phenomenon. That means that the models do not account for this critical factor behind many of the persistent and damaging weather extremes we’ve seen in recent years
column2: including the heat dome.

column1: But there is a way out of this nightmare of ever-worsening weather extremes
column2: and it’s one that will serve us well in many other ways
column3: too. A rapid transition to clean energy can stabilize the climate
column4: improve our health
column5: provide good-paying jobs
column6: grow the economy and ensure our children’s future. The choice is ours.

column1: Michael E. Mann is a professor of atmospheric science
column2: the director of the Earth System Science Center at Pennsylvania State University and the author of “The New Climate War: The Fight to Take Back Our Planet.” Susan Joy Hassol is the director of the nonprofit organization Climate Communication. She publishes the series “Quick Facts” with the American Association for the Advancement of Science’s SciLine on the connections between extreme weather and climate change."/['Michael E. Mann'
column3: 'Susan Joy Hassol']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/opinion/29mann-4/merlin_190076631_0815df44-b191-4fae-b271-08ff6d0d478f-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/opinion/hong-kong-apple-daily.html/Shutdown of Apple Daily Hurts Press Freedom in Hong Kong - The New York Times/"And so what many Hong Kongers most dreaded has come to pass: an accelerating crackdown on the very freedoms that distinguished Hong Kong from China. Not too long ago Hong Kongers stayed up through the night watching livestreams of police officers firing tear gas at protesters and beating them with truncheons. The current assault — less visible
column2: but no less violent — is on the public sphere itself.

column1: Hong Kongers fear what the next target will be after Apple Daily. The red waves are lapping at digital media outlets: The pro-democracy Stand News is already taking down online content. Others wonder whether the red sea will swamp international news outlets
column2: which could feel compelled to pull their remaining correspondents from Hong Kong for their own safety as the government prepares legislation to combat “fake news.”

column1: Attacks by the state-run Chinese media on the outspoken Bar Association are spooking the legal community
column2: with foreign judges
column3: allowed to serve under Hong Kong’s Basic Law
column4: withdrawing from the territory’s courts. The Roman Catholic Church is in the cross hairs; this month banners warning of “evil cults” appeared outside seven churches offering Masses to remember the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown.

column1: Hong Kong’s vibrant
column2: cacophonous civil society is being muzzled. As a result
column3: there is an exodus of Hong Kongers making the wrenching decision to leave all they know since they see no future in their home.

column1: Their sense of alarm has been reinforced by a government reshuffle late last week
column2: which entrenches hard-line security officials at the very top of the civil service. It is the latest dark joke that this move literally makes Hong Kong a police state — and five of its top officials now are under sanctions from the U.S. government for undermining the city’s autonomy and restricting its freedoms.

column1: Many agree that worse is still to come. Using history as a guide
column2: the China scholar Geremie Barmé is predicting that re-education programs and centers will be the next step in Beijing’s campaign of coercive ideological control.

column1: And yet
column2: many Hong Kongers are determined to pursue what they see as the right moral path
column3: no matter the cost. Jimmy Lai
column4: the jailed founder of Apple Daily
column5: is one example. He correctly predicted that the national security legislation would make the operation of the free press “not just difficult but dangerous
column6: ” yet he has vowed to continue. “What keeps me going is I believe I am doing the right thing
column7: ” he told me when I interviewed him last June."/['Louisa Lim']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/opinion/sunday/29lim/29lim-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/opinion/nda-amazon-google-facebook.html/Opinion | How Amazon
column2: Google and Other Companies Exploit NDAs/"In March
column3: when the City Council of Fort Wayne
column4: Ind.
column5: voted 7 to 2 to approve $16 million in tax breaks for a corporation to open a distribution center in the city
column6: it was something of a shot in the dark: Four of the Council members — including two who voted in favor of the deal — didn’t know which corporation they were considering.

column1: How was it possible that public officials lacked such crucial information? Alarmingly
column2: as a condition of its negotiations with the city
column3: the company had required city officials who knew its identity (including the mayor) to sign nondisclosure agreements that kept them from sharing its identity before a deal was reached.

column1: The company turned out to be Amazon.
As absurd as it may seem
column2: it is not uncommon today for large corporations negotiating economic development deals to have public officials sign nondisclosure agreements
column3: or NDAs. This practice needs to be stopped. By keeping salient information hidden
column4: these NDAs impede government accountability and public involvement in economic policymaking. State and city officials should ban them.

column1: Amazon is particularly aggressive in using economic development NDAs
column2: but it is hardly the only corporate titan to do so. Google negotiated for many months with local officials in Minnesota to build a data center in Sherburne County before residents learned in 2019 that those negotiations were occurring; the officials had agreed to an NDA that they believed kept them from discussing the project in public. And when the City Council of Gallatin
column3: Tenn.
column4: approved nearly $20 million in tax breaks last year for the creation of a data center in the city
column5: the company that stood to receive the benefit was not named. Months later
column6: it was revealed to be Facebook."/['Pat Garofalo']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/opinion/29garofalo/29garofalo-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/opinion/britney-spears-conservatorship.html/Opinion | Britney Spears and the Last Resort of Mental Health Care/"But state governments largely did not make good on Kennedy’s promise. His plan was supposed to create 1
column2: 500 well-staffed
column3: well-funded community mental health centers across the country
column4: but only about 750 were ever built
column5: and zero were ever fully funded. Today
column6: more than a third of people with serious mental illness do not receive medical help
column7: and the‌ ‌country’s‌ ‌largest‌ ‌facilities‌ ‌housing‌ ‌mentally ill people ‌are‌ ‌jails.

column1: The upshot: “Americans with depression
column2: bipolar disorder or other serious mental illnesses die 15 to 30 years younger than those without mental illness — a disparity larger than for race
column3: ethnicity
column4: geography or socioeconomic status
column5: ” Dhruv Khullar wrote for The Times in 2018. “The extraordinary life expectancy gains of the past half-century have left these patients behind
column6: with the result that Americans with serious mental illness live shorter lives than those in many of the world’s poorest countries.”

column1: What would a more humane system look like?
The question tends to divide people into one of two camps
column2: as the Times editorial board wrote in 2018: one that calls for more psychiatric beds in hospitals
column3: which have plummeted by 95 percent since the 1950s
column4: and another that argues that the problem is not the lack of psychiatric facilities but how little has been done to fill the void since they were shut down.

column1: “Neither side wants to return to the era of ‘insane asylums
column2: ’” the board wrote. “Nor does anyone disagree that the ‘system’ that replaced them is a colossal failure.” What’s needed
column3: they argued
column4: were three major reforms:

column1: A continuum of care: The community-based care model envisioned in the 1960s should be given a chance
column2: with “community mental health centers
column3: short-term care facilities
column4: and — yes — longer-term arrangements for the small portion of people who can’t live safely in the community.”

column1: Insurance equity: On paper
column2: health insurers are required to provide the same level of benefits for mental health treatments and services as they provide for other medical services. But in practice
column3: insurers often act as a barrier to mental health care.

column1: Sensible commitment standards: In general
column2: people cannot be hospitalized against their will unless they pose a clear and significant danger to themselves or others
column3: but the standard varies by state and is not always properly enforced.

column1: Another view: Adults without disabilities make decisions that run counter to their best interest all the time
column2: and some argue that disabled people should have the right to do the same as long as they’re not harming someone else.

column1: “If a nondisabled person decides
column2: ‘I’m going to skip work and have a couple of drinks and eat a whole bunch of doughnuts and then take a nap
column3: ’ that person isn’t going to have any of their fundamental rights taken away
column4: ” the journalist Sara Luterman tells Slate. “That’s a thing that normal people are allowed to do. But if you have a disability and you do those things
column5: that’s seen as further evidence of your incapacity and inability to responsibly manage your own life.”

column1: Even in cases where involuntary commitment is justified
column2: its benefits have to be weighed against its potential costs
column3: which include hopelessness
column4: fear and trauma. “I’m grateful for the medical care I got in the hospital; I know now that I needed it
column5: ” Schwiegershausen writes of her experience being hospitalized for a manic episode. “But there were ways that I was still myself throughout the experience
column6: and I’ll never forget what it was like to have people question my sanity.”

column1: Do you have a point of view we missed? Email us at debatable@nytimes.com. Please note your name
column2: age and location in your response
