column3: which may be included in the next newsletter."/['Spencer Bokat-Lindell']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/07/06/opinion/0629debatableillo/0629debatableillo-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/opinion/ezra-klein-podcast-james-suzman.html/Opinion | Why Do We Work So Damn Much?/"[MUSIC PLAYING]
ezra klein
I’m Ezra Klein
column2: and this is “The Ezra Klein Show.” [MUSIC PLAYING] So one of the truly great essays in the history of economic thought is this 1930 essay by John Maynard Keynes
column3: “Economic Possibilities for Our Grandchildren.” And it’s a weird essay. It’s done in the depth of the Great Depression
column4: so everything is terrible
column5: and people are really poor. But Keynes steps back and just imagines the future. And he makes his now famous prediction that by 2030
column6: which was a 100 years hence
column7: human beings would be so much richer
column8: so much more technologically advanced
column9: that the problem of scarcity — that the problem that had defined economics
column10: and arguably
column11: human civilization
column12: until then — would have been solved. And now we’d only work 15 hours a week. And the whole problem would be what to do with all this time. And the reason this essay still gets talked about and debated and written about today is that Keynes was interestingly right and wrong. The part of this that seems hard and probably seemed very out there when he did it
column13: the calculations for how much richer we’d get in 100 years
column14: that was not just right. If anything
column15: it was conservative. We passed his predictions for income growth decades ago. And then we got even richer than that. But you may notice we don’t work 15 hours a week. In fact
column16: in an inversion of past history
column17: the more money you make now
column18: the more hours you generally work. It used to be the point of being rich was to not work. And now we’ve built a social value system. So the reward for making a lot of money at work is
column19: you get to do even more work. And so people all up and down the income scale with levels of plenty that would have been shocking to anyone in Keynes’s time are harried
column20: burnt out
column21: always wanting more
column22: feeling there’s not enough. So what went wrong? What did Keynes get wrong? My guest today is the anthropologist James Suzman. And he flips this whole conversation on its head. Suzman has spent the last 30 years living with and studying one of the oldest enduring hunter-gatherer societies. For most of the history of civilization
column23: the prevailing belief was that life before what we now think of as civilization was
column24: as Thomas Hobbes said
column25: nasty
column26: brutish
column27: and short. But modern anthropology has turned that around. Hunter-gatherers were usually healthy. They were usually well nourished. Even in very unforgiving climates
column28: they tended to have diverse diets. And they did it while only spending about 15 hours a week on hunting and gathering. Suzman’s new book is called “Work
column29: A Deep History from the Stone Age to the Age of Robots.” And the overarching argument is that the way we work today isn’t driven by what we need. It’s driven by what we want. It’s also driven by how
column30: socially
column31: we regulate or encourage wants
column32: which is part of where his research on hunter-gatherers and how they approach this comes in. But the big thing here is that Keynes had it backwards. Humanity solved the problem of scarcity and achieved a 15-hour workweek long before modernity. But as we’ve gotten richer and built more technology
column33: we’ve developed a machine not for ending our wants
column34: not for fulfilling them
column35: but for generating new ones
column38: new forms of status competition. You can’t solve the problem of scarcity with our current system because our current system is designed to generate endlessly the feeling of more scarcity within us. It needs that. And so we keep working harder and harder and feeling like we have less and less
column39: even amidst quite a bit of plenty
column40: at least
column41: for many of us. As always

column1: james suzman
Thank you very much for having me
column2: Ezra.

column1: ezra klein
So let’s start here. What did John Maynard Keynes predict in “The Economic Possibilities for Our Grandchildren“?
james suzman
Ah
column2: he predicted a great change in pretty much everything. No
column3: but it was an extraordinary essay that he wrote. And he wrote this in 1930. And he’d just lost his personal fortune in the stock market crash and was watching the Great Depression clasp its way all over Europe and America and the rest of the world. And what Keynes decided to do was disabuse himself of short-term views to try and understand what the Great Depression was in the context of a larger economic history. And in doing so
column4: what he did was he set about predicting what the economy would look like in 100 years’ time
column5: in the time of his grandchildren
column6: so nominally around about now. And he predicted that the combination between capital growth
column7: improvements in productivity
column8: and advances in technology
column9: that nobody would be working more than 15 hours in a week. And even then
column10: he was suggesting that the reasons for this
column11: that people would continue to work was because it was really a question of habit. His view was that once we crossed all these thresholds
column12: everybody’s basic needs would be met. And if people’s basic needs were met
column13: he reasoned
column14: along with many other thinkers who were before him
column15: from Oscar Wilde to Bertrand Russell
column16: that if people’s basic needs were met
column17: then they would cease to devote their lives to endless toil and rather spend their time working on things that mattered and were meaningful to them.

column1: ezra klein
What did he get right in the specifics of this? And what did he get wrong?
james suzman
Well
column2: when Keynes made his predictions about capital growth
column3: technology advancement and productivity; he got those wrong. He massively underestimated the speed of advances in those areas. So basically
column4: the thresholds in terms of capital growth that he predicted would need to be met to usher in this 15-hour week
column5: this economic utopia
column6: we passed them ages ago
column7: in the 1980s
column8: likewise with productivity. Technology
column9: of course
column10: is much harder to measure. So in other words
column11: we passed those thresholds 30 or 40 years ago. Yet
column12: here we are. And we’re working pretty much as long hours as people did in the 1930s when Keynes wrote the essay in the first place. So that’s another critical thing he got wrong.

column1: ezra klein

So the big counterintuitive argument of your work is that Keynes had it backwards. Humanity actually had solved the problem of scarcity. It had figured out a 15-hour workweek. But the solution was in our past. And the very advances in technology and income and productivity that Keynes predicted are actually the problem
column2: actually the things that are getting us further from the 15-hour workweek. Tell me about that.

column1: james suzman

I don’t necessarily think those are the things that are taking us away from that utopian dream that Keynes actually had. I think the way we are approaching them is what’s taking us away from that utopian dream that Keynes had
column2: the fact that we have a series of cultural ideas that are deeply embedded in the very fabric of our society and the very institutions around which we organize our lives. And that
column3: in a sense
column4: is holding us back from really embracing this extraordinary affluence that we have won ourselves. And where this becomes most clear is when we look at things like hunter-gatherer populations like the Ju/‘hoansi
column5: who I worked with
column6: who had much less than we do in a material sense. In a material sense
column7: they were deeply impoverished by modern standards. And yet they consider themselves affluent and enjoyed a degree of affluence as a result of that. Yet we seem to be trapped in this cycle of ever pursuing more and greater growth
column8: greater wealth
column9: greater anything
column10: it seems. It seems that our aspirations continue to grow endlessly. And we’re caught in this kind of treadmill in which we never stop and actually enjoy the rewards of what we have won. So in some ways
column11: I think it’s to do with the fact that basically
column12: this growth and the technology and the expansion of productivity is something that keeps driving us forward. But at the same time
column13: it’s also an opportunity to organize the way we do things very differently. And for me
column14: that is something that we really ought to be looking at.

column1: ezra klein
So before we get too deep into the hunter-gatherer societies
column2: I want to ask an epistemological question. How do we know how much time hunter-gatherer societies spent working? How do we know how they lived? I mean
column3: these societies existed a very long time ago
column4: were often working off of fragmentary evidence. There are some surviving pockets of this kind of lifestyle. But it’s not the bulk of it. So what makes you certain we can speak with confidence about any of this?

column1: james suzman
Well
column2: the truth is
column3: when we talk about anything in our very deep history
column4: we’ve got to be a little bit circumspect. I speak with confidence because it seems all the pieces fit together. But the evidence
column5: as you say
column6: is thin. The problem is
column7: is that many of our hunter-gatherer ancestors — and we now know that they’ve been around for 320
column8: 000 years. That’s just modern Homo sapiens. And there’s plenty of debate about how human the various antecedents of that were. So the problem is
column9: is that most of their material culture was made of things that were pretty organic or stones and was very small scale. So we have very little in the way of actual material traces of how these societies organize themselves. And really
column10: up until the 1960s
column11: there was this absolute certainty pretty much everywhere that hunter-gatherers probably endured lives of constant misery
column12: that their lives were nasty
column13: brutish
column14: and short
column15: that they lived constantly on the edge of starvation
column16: and that this was
column17: in fact
column18: what instilled within us this obsession we have with scarcity
column19: this thing that we — you know
column20: food. Having enough food today is simply a trigger for worrying about whether we’re going to have more food tomorrow and so on. In the 1960s
column21: some anthropologists took the view that if they looked at some of the surviving groups of hunter-gatherers scattered around— and again
column22: these tended to be in very ecologically marginal places — maybe they’d be able to develop some insights into how our hunter-gatherer ancestors lived. And what they could say with some reasonable confidence was that things like the material culture were probably relatively similar. They used similar tools. And likewise
column23: based on the archaeological evidence
column24: the suggestion was that certainly in many places. And of course
column25: there was variation. And they tended to be similar group sizes to modern hunting — contemporary hunting and gathering populations. And the most famous group chosen for study were the Ju/‘hoansi of northern Namibia
column26: who
column27: at the time
column28: were living fairly remotely in northeast Namibia and northwestern Botswana and living as hunter-gatherers
column29: by and large. And one anthropologist
column30: Richard Lee
column31: went out and did a very basic economic input and output analysis of how the Ju/‘hoansi lived. And this was in a — the Ju/‘hoansi lived in a tough neighborhood. The Kalahari Desert is no easy place. This is a place that had basically defied — farmers who had been wanting to come in there into the Kalahari for 2
column32: 000 years. But it was too tough a place. You couldn’t basically raise livestock or plant vegetables in fields and so on there. And when Lee arrived there
column33: he set about doing his work. And he was really worried because it was in the middle of a terrible drought. Anyway
column34: he ended up working with them. And he discovered that pretty much on the basis of around 15 hours for women and 17 hours work week for men in terms of the food quest
column35: the Ju/‘hoansi were pretty much able to meet all of their basic needs. And then on top of that
column36: they’d work a similar number of hours on domestic household activities
column38: making fires
column39: fixing tools
column40: and so on and so forth. In other words
column41: that they worked much less than we did. And he took those findings back. And several other anthropologists had been working with other enduring hunter-gatherer populations from northern nomadic hunter-gatherers in the Arctic to Aboriginal societies to the Hadza Bay in Tanzania. And they actually all found that they had fairly similar data
column42: that these hunter-gatherers did not live constantly on the edge of starvation
column43: that they enjoyed quite a lot of leisure time
column44: and that they were surprisingly well nourished on the basis of relatively little effort. And this was just effort by economically active individuals. In other words
column46: and they supported their children. So children were not expected to work. So on the basis of this
column47: on the basis of this broad geographical spread of convergent evidence
column48: we can assume that since these hunter-gatherer populations
column49: which we now know had no cultural contact for 60
column53: so the relationship — there has been no direct cultural contact until this century between
column55: many Australian Aboriginal hunter-gatherer populations and groups like the Ju/‘hoansi. Yet
column57: very similar ways. And to me
column58: what that suggests is that the very nature of securing a living
column60: tended to create very specific kind of cultural
column63: which are broadly consistent. There’s obviously variation on all sorts of aspects. But there’s a lot more in common between hunter-gatherers than there is different. And there’s certainly a lot more different between hunter-gatherers and agricultural societies than there is between hunter-gatherer societies. And so it’s really on the basis of that that we can speculate that there must be some greater insight that these societies offer us into the way our ancestors lived and worked than certainly anything else. So it’s an imperfect lens through which to view the past. But I think it is

column1: ezra klein
So on a signpost of where we’re going to be going here
column2: the big point of that Keynes essay is that eventually
column3: we’re going to be able to produce so much
column4: we don’t need to work because we’ll have produced our way into abundance. And the point you make about hunter-gatherer societies is that — and frankly
column5: about modernity — is that what we’ve seen so far is the opposite. Abundance doesn’t come from endless production. It comes from effectively regulating what you want. Because then you can actually produce enough and fulfill that level. So let’s talk a little bit about the way the Ju/‘hoansi regulate want. And maybe we can start with demand sharing.

column1: james suzman
One of the most distinctive features about the Ju/‘hoansi and
column2: indeed
column3: many of the other hunter-gatherer societies
column4: similar ones
column5: was that they were
column6: to use the words of Richard Lee
column7: fiercely egalitarian. And they had various mechanisms to manage this egalitarianism. Now one of the most interesting mechanisms was a system called demand sharing. One anthropologist who didn’t like it much called it tolerated theft. And it is a system which is
column8: in many ways
column9: the complete inversion of our rules of giving
column10: sharing
column11: and taking. When we ask somebody for something
column12: we say please. It’s an offer of a debt. When somebody gives us something
column13: we say thank you. I’m in your debt. There’s a kind of sense of an exchange going on. And it is in the right of the giver. And generally
column14: I was always brought up
column15: wait for somebody to offer you something. And always say thank you and be in their debt. And it’s effectively in the rights of the giver to deny somebody something that they asked for. In Ju/‘hoan cultures and
column16: indeed
column17: many other hunting and gathering cultures
column18: that relationship is inverted. Basically
column19: in an idealized form
column20: demand sharing means that pretty much anybody in a society can go to anybody else. And remember
column21: these are relatively small social groupings. Can go to anybody else and demand something from them. So if
column22: for example
column23: I have a bag of tobacco
column24: somebody else is perfectly entitled to come and demand some of that tobacco from me. And it would be considered extremely rude — in fact
column25: it would be considered offensive — if I don’t give him some of that tobacco. At the same time
column26: it’s not considered at all rude to make that kind of demand. So what you have is a society where
column27: in effect
column28: everybody can spontaneously tax everybody else. The net result of this is that nobody bothers acquiring services because you’re just going to share it and give it away anyway. And people end up spontaneously sharing everything. And they see a certain virtue. It’s not a completely unconscious thing. I mean
column29: culture is habitual. It becomes unconscious. But people are aware of the virtues of it. And in hunter-gatherer life
column30: there was a real sense that if anybody tries to accumulate resources or dominate the distribution and flow of resources
column31: it is socially unhealthy. It produces tensions. It produces anxieties. It produces a hierarchy or an attempted hierarchy. It adds a whole level of risk and cost to the social life of the group. So demand sharing is really just a functional way of distributing resources within a society. And in these societies
column32: it worked really well. Because with everybody able to tax everybody else
column33: it meant that everybody actually got a reasonable share. It also meant that they got the right amount because if somebody overtaxed somebody
column34: they could be taxed back in time. So it was the sort of sense of social moderation. And what it typically produced
column35: in most instances
column36: was a very harmonious way of living and a very harmonious way of living even when things sometimes were tough

column1: ezra klein
So let me ask you about the harmonious way of living. Because there is a debate in recent years
column2: particularly about the level of intra and inter-group violence among hunter-gatherers. So you read Steven Pinker
column3: and he’ll say
column4: ah
column5: our past was much more violent. There was much more violence in these societies. I’ve heard other anthropologists and experts dispute that. I think looking at it from our current perspective
column6: you might expect something like demand sharing to lead to a lot of violence. So what is your perspective on the level of actual open conflict?

column1: james suzman
My perspective on demand sharing was that it certainly made anthropologists feel violent until they got a bit used to it. But amongst everybody else
column2: it was actually something very peaceable. Now
column3: yeah
column4: there’s been this pretty much endless debate. And it really is a debate about modernity
column5: whether we’re on this great path of progress or not. To make the case of progress
column6: it helps to say that actually our lives in the past were much more miserable and much more violent. There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that in hunter-gatherer societies throughout history
column7: there was
column8: of course
column9: violence. Certainly with Ju/‘hoansi oral histories
column10: there’s definitely memories and stories of people
column11: groups living
column12: someone in [INAUDIBLE] getting in a fight with the people from [INAUDIBLE] or — it happens. People are violent. And often
column13: they’re violent. In the Ju/‘hoansi case
column14: as they say
column15: usually
column16: there’s a fight over matters of the heart
column17: and then sometimes occasionally some revenge. Of course
column18: there’s violence. But as a general rule
column19: hanging out with hunter-gatherers and hanging out with societies like this actually is extraordinarily harmonious. So statistically
column20: it’s difficult to say whether it’s more peaceful now or more peaceful then. But what’s certainly absolutely right to say is that hunter-gatherers did not live in this state of kind of Hobbesian constant war
column21: that actually
column22: like our lives
column23: there were moments where violence erupted. And it shook people when it happened. People were traumatized by it. They found it difficult. They did not like it. It was not part of the norm. But on the whole
column24: I think life was pretty placid. And this is
column25: again
column26: the sort of overwhelming sense
column27: certainly from anthropologists who preceded me
column28: who spent more time in these societies when they were still more free to hunt and gather — of course
column29: the area I’ve worked in has been one of constant difficult change. And the overwhelming sense from all of them
column30: again
column31: is just the general serenity of life in these circumstances. And I think it’s fair to say that we are
column32: as a species
column33: relatively peace loving. And I think that applies to most of our history. But within that
column34: of course
column35: there are instances where things would have been tough and brutal and violent

column1: ezra klein
Can you talk a bit about the practice of insulting the meat?
james suzman
This is the other great egalitarian device in Ju/‘hoan life. In the Ju/‘hoan world
column2: people don’t place a great deal of store on material resources. Things are shared relatively easily and evenly. Demand sharing is not a cause of tension. But one thing in the Ju/‘hoansi world which is loved above all others is meat. And it’s one of the few things that inspires people to jealousy
column3: to anger
column4: if they feel a little bit left out. And it is also one of the few things that if somebody is too productive in bringing meat
column5: if somebody is too good a hunter
column6: then there’s a risk that that person starts to accrue additional social capital as a result of that
column7: to accrue power
column8: just simply because they’re the bringer and the distributor of meat. And so what they do is they have a number of customs around
column9: one
column10: the distribution of meat and
column11: two
column12: how to deal with the hunter themselves in order to manage any kind of tensions that might emerge from this. So when a hunter comes back with a kill and
column13: in particular
column14: if it’s a spectacular kill
column15: something huge like a giraffe or eland bull
column16: the hunter will not be praised in the way that we’d generally expect and imagine the hunter coming back with this trophy. Ha-ha
column17: everybody is going to get fed. Everybody is going to be wonderful. Pat me on the back
column18: and now I’m the hero for the night. Instead
column19: the hunter is mocked and insulted. And it’s done in a kind of lighthearted way
column20: but also with a little bit of an edge. And the hunter for his part is expected to behave with great humility. And the kinds of insults that will be — everybody knows that it’s a performance issue
column21: right? Because if a giraffe shows up
column22: it’s a big piece of meat. No poor man’s going to struggle to eat the thing over the course of a few days. But they’ll still say
column23: ah
column24: this giraffe. Ah
column25: the meat smells like urine. Ah
column26: it’s not enough to even feed my mother-in-law. And their insults come out again and again and again and again and again over the course of the consumption of this animal. And the reason they do this is to avoid the hunter accruing any unnecessary hierarchy
column27: any unnecessary authority over others and any socially destructive authority over others. There’s a wonderful quote
column28: again
column29: by Richard Lee
column30: where man describes the basis behind the practices. We use it to cool young men’s hearts. And in this way
column31: successful hunters were
column32: in effect
column33: encouraged or discouraged from hunting excessively. Now bizarrely
column34: because in hunter-gatherer bands
column35: everybody liked me
column36: you wanted to discourage the good hunters from hunting too much. And but at the same time
column37: you didn’t want the incompetent ones going out or the elderly going out and being unsuccessful all the time. So they had other methods of actually distributing the responsibility for that meat. So technically
column38: the owner of an animal that was killed was actually not the person who killed the animal and brought it home
column39: the one who effectively did the hard work
column40: but actually
column41: the person who made the arrow. And as a result
column42: that meant that in Ju/‘hoan communities
column45: and all the rest could occasionally claim to own an animal themselves and have the added burden of responsibility of distributing the meat and enduring insults.

column1: ezra klein
So this falls on our ears
column2: my ears
column3: very strangely
column4: right? I mean
column5: it it defies almost everything you would think about motivation and how you get people to do difficult tasks and excel at them. So in this world where you’re a hunter
column6: and you bring down a giraffe
column7: and then you come back and everybody insults you
column8: and somebody else gets to distribute the meat because it was their arrow and not yours
column9: why be a hunter? What is the implicit theory of motivation to do things that are valuable for society
column10: but scarce in their skillset within these groups?

column1: james suzman
This is one of the wonderful things about sort of looking at the idea of work as we go into our deep history
column2: and actually
column3: even beyond the Ju/‘hoansi
column4: into evolutionary history. It’s pretty clear that we have evolved to love work
column5: in a very basic sense. We have evolved
column6: become these extremely purposeful focused species with this extraordinary array of skills and flexible devices
column7: from our hands to our incredibly plastic brains
column8: that
column9: in a sense
column10: need to be fed. There’s a reason why when we are stuck in solitary confinement in prison for something
column11: that boredom eats us up. It’s because we can’t basically apply these extraordinary skills we’ve evolved to have. And people get extraordinary pleasure out of doing work. And it can often be different kinds of pleasure. Now in the Ju/‘hoansi case
column12: let’s take the example of hunting. Hunting is extraordinarily fulfilling work. It is very satisfying. It engages your mind. It engages your intellect. It engages years of acquired and accumulated skill. It engages your intuition. It engages your physical strength. It engages your stamina. And it engages you emotionally because you have this huge empathetic connection with the animals that you’re pursuing. It is deeply and profoundly satisfying. And in the end
column13: it turns into meat in your belly. It fulfills you quite physically at the end as well. As one Ju/‘hoan hunter put it to me
column14: he was like — he said at the end
column15: “Hunting makes my heart happy
column16: my legs heavy
column17: and my belly full.” It is profoundly satisfying work. And it’s obviously part of our evolutionary heritage
column18: this ability to work efficiently and to apply our skills to acquiring the food
column19: first of all
column20: that we need. Because that is the primary job of life — to get the food and energy into our bodies in order to grow and reproduce. And then when we have surplus energy
column21: we clearly use those same skills that have empowered us to be such versatile
column22: flexible hunters
column23: foragers
column24: understanders of an environment. We apply those skills to many other things
column25: like creating music
column26: creating art
column27: telling stories
column28: and so on and so on. And work is very much part of who we are. And when we are deprived of the ability to work
column29: we are miserable. We are listless. We are bored. We are uncomfortable. And in many senses
column30: life is not worth living.

column1: ezra klein
That makes some sense to me on a theoretical level
column2: but make the case to me that these cultural practices were actually successful. When I look around
column3: I don’t see many hunter-gatherer societies around today. And the ones that do exist are often living in pretty awful conditions. So why should I take the hunter-gatherer model seriously as a successful cultural model?

column1: james suzman
The extraordinary longevity of Homo sapiens is particularly relevant. 30 years ago
column2: when I started studying anthropology
column3: there was a sense that modern Homo sapiens
column4: cognitively modern as it was referred
column5: had been around for maybe only 40
column6: 000 years and physically modern for maybe 100
column7: 000 years. Now with genomic research
column8: we’ve pushed that date way backwards to perhaps 320
column11: 000 years
column12: which suggests that Homo sapiens have been going around
column13: acting relatively intelligently and acting as they did for quite a long time. And it also suggests that they must have had a model that worked
column14: a model that effectively enabled them to adapt
column15: firstly
column16: to changes in climate when they were still locked in Africa
column17: and then
column18: ultimately
column19: to expand and adapt to different contexts around the world. Humankind is extraordinary for its ability to basically break out of habitats and ecological niches
column20: which most animals are absolutely hostage to
column21: and adapt and develop entirely new ways of making a living. And I think that kind of structure was very much part of this process. I think that kind of flexibility
column22: that focus on the short-term
column23: that focus on securing their basic needs
column24: and then spending time otherwise was a system that effectively worked. And it enabled the gradual expansion of our species across the globe. So I think it was simply just part of who we are. We’re cultural beings. We develop forms and systems of managing and organizing ourselves
column25: which can be highly different
column26: but occasionally
column27: you come across a form that works. And in the case of hunter-gatherers
column28: I think the form of the small scale foraging societies organized on very cooperative grounds
column29: based on sharing resources
column30: and skills
column31: and so on
column32: was a successful model that allowed the slow and gradual expansion of our species to reaching a period of near dominance as had just before the agricultural revolution. I think it was a system that worked
column33: but it was also a cultural system. That was it. And was it a good one? Yes. If you measure the success of a civilization by its endurance over time
column34: by its sustainability
column35: then that is a very sustainable way of working. I mean
column37: 000 years is a very long period of time.

column1: ezra klein
I want to put a pin on how we measure success of civilizations. But I want to draw out another connection I think you make in the book
column2: which is that one thing happening here is that these societies developed
column3: in demand sharing and insulting the meat and other practices
column4: pretty extraordinary social structures to keep people from amassing too much
column5: to keep them then from wanting too much
column6: because it became kind of a pain if you got a lot. People just took it from you
column7: or they made fun of you
column8: or they got mad at you. And so one of the things happening here is that if you don’t want to work that much
column9: if you want a society where you have abundance
column10: create leisure
column11: you have to keep people’s desires under control
column12: and that what you have here in these hunter-gatherer societies
column13: and certainly
column14: in the one that you studied closely
column15: is a pretty extraordinary system for keeping desire under control. If you think of our society now as an endless engine of desire
column16: an appreciater and generator of desire and a plotter of desire
column17: that you basically have the opposite here. And so you get the time
column18: because people are being dissuaded
column19: from the kinds of things that lead to the hedonic treadmill.

column1: james suzman
I wouldn’t call it extraordinary. I’d say that where we are now is extraordinary certainly in temporal terms. But yes
column2: absolutely. What you had with these societies were societies where
column3: effectively
column4: the problem of scarcity
column5: the economic problem
column6: the thing which economists or classical economics tells us drives us to always want more
column7: this idea that we have infinite wants and limited means
column8: just did not exist. They had limited desires that were relatively easily met. So they weren’t caught in this sort of constant loop of wanting more in the future. And you talk about it as extraordinary because
column9: of course
column10: you’re looking at it from a perspective of the United States. And you’re looking at it as I was looking at it when I first went and spent time with them. And they don’t view it as extraordinary at all. They find it extraordinary — or they found it; we’ve got to be clear on historical context here. Life is changing very fast for them. But they found it extraordinary instead that people might want to accumulate wealth
column11: that people might not want to share. They respond to it with that same kind of visceral surprise that others respond to them. And again
column12: it’s a sort of telling thing about the power of how culture and experience really shapes our sense of the world around us and our sense of what is normal
column13: what is natural
column14: what is good. As far as Ju/‘hoansi are concerned
column15: not sharing is something that is unnatural. So while we see the Ju/‘hoansi as abnormal or exceptional
column16: they do the same thing with us. And I think this is the great power of cultural difference
column17: it’s what gives me hope about the fact that
column18: actually
column19: the possibilities for humankind in the future are endless. Because what we often assume as nature is just culture masquerading as nature.

column1: ezra klein

I was going to ask about that. This is a tremendously wide variation in how people act depending on the cultures they grow up in. I was thinking when you were saying that the Ju/‘hoansi see it as strange when somebody doesn’t share as unnatural
column2: I mean
column3: I’ve got a two-year-old. There’s definitely something natural about not wanting to share. He definitely does not find it an intuitive concept
column4: which is all to say
column5: do you have a view on whether there is such a thing
column6: at least in the way we discuss it now
column7: as human nature? Or is basically most of what we consider to be human nature cultural imposition? And what is really human nature is our ability to absorb cultural and social cues and the flexibility therein?

column1: james suzman
Well
column2: you’ve answered my question very nicely for me. We’ve often sought out human nature. Are we intrinsically good? Are we intrinsically bad? Are we cooperative? Are we not? And I think what we are is we’re a host of contradictions because human nature is to be
column3: one
column4: cultural
column5: two
column6: adaptive and
column7: three
column8: intransigent
column9: all at the same time. So we’re the species that can adapt to circumstances with extraordinary ease. Put us in a difficult place. Force us into a change. Like for example
column10: the lockdown of last year
column11: all the objections notwithstanding
column12: we coped with it remarkably well. This was a almost unprecedented change in behavior that was required. And we got on
column13: and we managed and adapted to it and even became habituated to it
column14: which is now why flexible working is likely to be a norm in many societies for years to come. So we’re this incredibly adaptable creature because we have these very plastic brains. And our experience imprints itself on those brains
column15: and we become habituated to things. We become creatures of habit. Certain things are normal and acceptable and doable. And that’s just the way they are. And these things can be very
column16: very different. And this is
column17: at the same time
column18: what makes us so intransigent
column19: so resistant to change
column20: which is why
column21: for example
column22: people smoke themselves into an early grave
column23: knowing that it’s killing them
column24: simply because they can’t change that habit. So human nature is to be cultural: to be
column25: at once
column26: adaptable
column27: and to be intransigent. And anything beyond that I think is to impose some kind of universality on what is ultimately a cultural norm. So to say are we basically kind to one another and humanitarian
column28: or are we basically selfish — those
column29: in my view
column30: are very clearly cultural norms. Those are normative behavior
column31: which feel natural because that is culture’s extraordinary power over us.

column1: ezra klein

So the implicit cultural tradeoff here seems to be between status egalitarianism and then personal striving and ambition. You can either encourage striving by choosing to give certain individuals greater status
column2: greater wealth
column3: greater social power
column4: given what they produce
column5: but the cost is jealousy and envy and inequality and this kind of positional competition. Or you can maintain status egalitarianism
column6: but at the cost of discouraging some of that striving and ambition. You’re probably not going to invent antibiotics in a society. You’re probably not going to invent some of the things that capitalism or even agriculture drove us towards. Is that how you see the tradeoff?

column1: james suzman
I don’t. I tend to think that people do things because that is what we are. We are thinkers
column2: doers
column3: creators
column4: makers. And we get intense personal satisfaction from doing so. Now we happen to live in societies at the moment where we get a certain amount of social credibility and social satisfaction from doing so. And also
column5: the inverse exists. If you don’t work
column6: you’re effectively denied social dignity. But work in and of itself can be extraordinarily fulfilling. So that’s use the Ju/‘hoan example again. And there was some lovely studies done in the late ‘60s looking
column7: in particular
column8: at
column9: say
column10: child development. Ju/‘hoansi children typically play in mixed age groups. They look after one another
column11: often with kind of cascading open responsibilities. Education is very undidactic. Children are expected to learn things
column12: not to be taught things. And the kinds of games that they play
column13: some of them involve a huge amount of skill. Hunting
column14: for example
column15: practicing with bows and arrows involves skill. There’s games involving catching weighted vulture feathers that are thrown in the air with a stick and twisting them up. And these are highly skillful things
column16: like playing tennis. And people master them because it gives them great pleasure to do so. But there’s no lording it over others for being better or worse at it. And so you end up with actually quite — you end up with these games which are quite intensely individually competitive in the sense that somebody might be trying to master a skill or become much better at something. But because of the context in which it takes place
column17: there’s very little of that kind of social pressure of that
column18: again
column19: the back patting and all the rest. So for example
column20: in Ju/‘hoansi society
column21: there’s very much in one place left in Namibia where people are able to still hunt and gather. There are hunters who are absolute masters of their craft. And insults and what have you notwithstanding
column22: they go on and they do the hunting because it brings them profound satisfaction. There is a great joy in executing that skill. The truth of the matter is
column23: it’s the same for most of us
column24: most honest endeavors. If I play on my guitar
column25: it brings me pleasure. But I know nobody in their right mind would want to listen to it. Most people who write books generally write them for themselves. Because you have to be very
column26: very lucky to get read more widely than just a handful of people. So there is that thing. We’ve sort of forgotten
column27: I think
column28: and lost a sense of the wonder and the joy of that kind of purposefulness and the execution of the purposefulness and how important that is to human flourishing.

column1: ezra klein
So let me play the cynic here. Because we’re talking about a set of societies that have been driven almost out of existence. I mean
column2: as you’re saying
column3: even for the Ju/‘hoansi
column4: this is a period of extraordinary change. One way of looking at this history is that we had a survival of the culturally fittest societies. And now hunter-gatherer exists only in these protected pockets. That we sort of ran a competition
column5: and they lost. And that the societies that supercharged our ambition
column6: our intensity
column7: our status competition
column8: they created
column9: for better and for worse
column10: everything from these multitrillion dollar economies
column11: to nuclear weapons
column12: to CRISPR and mRNA vaccines. Maybe we can modulate it on the margin
column13: but some of this is a cost we pay for these kinds of advances. So to say that work is its own reward
column14: it may be. I actually don’t disagree with that at all. But in terms of advancement and the kinds of things that we’ve seen in the past 100
column16: 300 years
column17: there’s something going on there that is going on differently in the broadly capitalist
column18: market oriented
column19: et cetera
column20: societies from some of their former competitors.

column1: james suzman
I’m not absolutely certain [about]
column2: for example
column3: the narrative that capitalism per se is what creates this wealth of creativity and these great advances. There’s
column4: of course — one goes through history. Wherever people have had sufficient surplus energy that they haven’t been stuck on the food quest
column5: you’ve had these great sets of innovations and creativity
column6: whether it’s artistry
column7: whether it’s medicine
column8: whether it’s theology
column9: whether it’s physics
column10: wherever you’ve had these concentrations of energy
column11: so whenever there’s been a decent surplus and knowledge can be reproduced and shared and passed on from one generation to the next. And I certainly think that the kind of capitalized culture that we’ve had is an organic consequence of the transition to agriculture. And it is very much part of what’s brought us to where we are now. But I don’t think it’s what’s part of what’s needed in order for us to take the next step on. And in fact
column12: I actually think
column13: in many ways
column14: that the kind of innovation and the productivity and the growth mindset that came out of agriculture has brought us out of the miseries of the agricultural era
column15: which was quite long and quite difficult
column16: and into a brave new era. But that very same medicine that brought us this great prosperity that we enjoy now might now well be making the patient sick.

column1: ezra klein
One of the fascinating threads of the book is the way the transition to farming transforms the way we experience labor
column2: of course
column3: but also the way we experience and understand time. And you really emphasize the human relationship to time
column4: essential to our relationship to work. So can you tell me about that
column5: the difference between how foragers and farmers related to time?

column1: james suzman

It is an extraordinary phenomenon. And it’s one that I was very attuned to right from the beginning of my first ever fieldwork. Because I was working with some Ju/‘hoansi who’d lost their land already. This was in the early 1990s. And my determination was to actually get a Ju/‘hoan oral history of what had happened. We had all these colonial histories dominating the story of Africa. I wanted to get their version of events
column2: in a sense. And that
column3: on the whole
column4: I really struggled. People didn’t have history. They didn’t talk in historical terms. They didn’t think in particularly temporal terms. And at the same time
column5: you had lots of the farmers who were trying to employ them
column6: saying
column7: ah
column8: the Ju/‘hoansi
column9: they don’t think beyond today. They don’t have a concept of tomorrow and so on and so forth. And it turned out that this was what the Ju/‘hoansi largely agreed with. And part of the reason was they had what’s called historically an immediate return economy. In other words
column10: pretty much all economic effort went into simply meeting their needs for that day. And that was based on this idea that they had few needs easily met. So they were competent foragers. They knew that within a few hours of spontaneous effort
column11: they could fill their bellies and so on in most circumstances. And as a result
column12: they didn’t really spend a great deal of time planning into the future or
column13: indeed
column14: thinking about the past. Now the transition to farming was very
column15: very different. Where hunter-gatherers viewed their environments as inherently provident
column16: as almost generous
column17: as something which gave them
column18: farming
column19: you have to view your environment as only potentially provident. For it to be provident
column20: you have to invest your labor into it. But investing your labor into land in order for it to provide you with something to eat involves a time scale. If we use
column21: for example
column22: the early wheats that were grown in the first populations to embrace agriculture in the Levant
column23: you have a seasonal cycle. You plant the seeds in the spring. You then have to nurture and look after the crop and water it and so on and so forth
column24: nurture it over several months
column25: then process it
column26: and eventually
column27: maybe by New Year’s Eve
column28: you might have a loaf of bread out of it. Everything is focused on future rewards. Now the problem with not being able to meet your immediate needs is those future rewards are rewards that are then stored and used to sustain you over the next agricultural cycle. So farmers found themselves locked into this kind of circular time
column29: this process where they invested their labor into the land. And the land
column30: in effect
column31: gave them a return at some point in the future. And this
column32: of course
column33: changed not only the relationship with land because the land became something — if you worked that land
column34: you had some kind of claim of ownership. So it change their notions of territoriality and ownership. But at the same time it transformed the perception of time. Everything became future focused
column35: much like it is for us today. Most of the work we do involves accruing some kind of return in the future. In fact
column36: there are only a handful of activities that we routinely do
column38: for example
column39: cooking is an immediate return economic activity
column40: if you’re going to eat that meal immediately afterwards. But most of the economic work we do is for the immediate future or the distant future. And in farming societies
column43: if you worked hard enough for long enough
column44: you might be able to secure a sufficiently grand surplus that’s stored away in your silos that you might be able to
column47: some kind of time off. You might be able to purchase your liberation from labor. And all of this came with the fact that
column49: farming involved a great deal more effort and work than hunting and gathering did.

column1: ezra klein

So there’s a trend in recent “history of human civilization” books of making farming sound really bad. So you work more. You have a less diverse diet. You’re more vulnerable to drought and to famine. You get pressed into these settlements. There’s more disease. I mean
column2: honestly
column3: if you read books — and yours is not a heavy one necessarily
column4: but it is there. The question that begins to rise is
column5: well
column6: why did human beings ever do this? If farming was such an unpleasant lifestyle compared to foraging
column7: then for the people on the border of those two lives
column8: why farming? What accounts for the human move into this
column9: you know
column10: apparently
column11: much more toil-filled and unstable existence?

column1: james suzman
Look
column2: part of the thing is to take away from it
column3: to make sense of it
column4: is to take away the idea that there was any kind of choice. In some sense
column5: when you look at a transition from hunting and gathering to farming
column6: it’s something that happens over a very long period of time. I mean
column7: we talk about revolutions. It’s not a thing that it happened overnight. It’s a slow process
column8: a gradual recalibration of norms and behaviors. And trying to make sense of the transition to agriculture
column9: it’s one of the great mysteries of the world today. And what’s so mysterious about it is that there used to be this narrative that the transition to agriculture happened in the Levant around 12
column10: 000 years ago in the Middle East. And this great technology spread and was adopted by hunter-gatherers
column11: saying
column12: well
column13: this is wonderful. Now we can grow our own food. But what we now know is that for a start
column14: agriculture developed independently in populations where there was no chance of knowledge being shared across them. It developed in Mesoamerica. It developed in Southeast Asia. It developed in West Africa. It developed in the Levant
column15: all independently of one another within a very short period of time
column16: a period of around 5
column17: 000 years
column18: beginning 12
column19: 000 years ago. And quite why that happened
column20: we don’t know. In the Levant
column21: the most obvious answers are to do with this intense period of climate change that happened before
column22: which would have transformed the ecological landscape and I think resulted in the case of these populations. Suddenly
column23: the fields of wild wheat is becoming prolific because of changes in the carbon cycle. And suddenly
column24: people became dependent on it. So I imagine
column25: in a sense
column26: they were sort of seduced by a period of great [INAUDIBLE]. So if you imagine you have a wild stand of berries that
column27: for example
column28: you’ve harvested episodically every couple of years as a hunter-gatherer
column29: and suddenly some shift in the climate happens
column30: that this tree and this grove just becomes unbelievably prolific
column31: and so you kind of move there and you become dependent on it. And then after 200 years of being dependent on it
column32: suddenly the weather changes again. The climate changes
column33: and you start trying to nurture it to restore that. And I think some kind of process like this must have happened in the Levant. I think similar processes probably happened elsewhere. But as I say
column34: it remains a great mystery. And I think it becomes less of a mystery if we take away the idea that there was any choice involved. This was things that happened slowly over many generations. And suddenly they were dependent on it. And this is the way it is for all of us. We become dependent on things over time. We become habituated into them. And the other truth is that once you become dependent on a single resource
column35: for example
column36: going back to being a hunter-gatherer becomes rather difficult. The Ju/‘hoansi have learned over time
column38: to identify around 150 different edible plant species in parts. And they know how to track in the behavior of the animals. Once you abandon that knowledge
column39: it takes one generation to lose that. So one generation of eating maize and maize porridge and tinned meat
column40: and you forget how to — many of the young generation of Ju/‘hoansi
column41: they wouldn’t be able to survive as their fathers and grandfathers did. Because they simply no longer have that practical knowledge acquired through years and years of experience. And so I suspect that is what happened. And once we were on that hamster wheel of growth and agricultural change

column1: ezra klein
So farming changes our relationship to time. It changes our relationship to work. And then you write about cities as really changing our relationship to want
column2: that people began pressing in together. And then you write that they develop a form of scarcity
column3: articulated in the language of aspiration
column4: jealousy
column5: and desire
column6: rather than of absolute need
column7: that we are around so many other kinds of people. We can see what they have or in competition with them. Can you talk a bit about the way density changes desire?

column1: james suzman
I think there might be something within us. We talked a little bit about human nature. There’s something within our nature that responds very viscerally to inequality
column2: to somebody having more than us. And again
column3: this is something we see when you watch two siblings sharing out their bag of sweets with immense precision. There can be no inequality in how it’s done. Cities are different spaces. And we’ve got to remember
column4: even though most history of the last 10
column5: 000 years or 7
column6: 000 years since the first cities were born
column7: there’s a history of cities because that is where people learned to write. And that’s what they focused on. Most people still lived in the countryside and made a living. And when I say most
column8: I mean really 90 percent. It was only sort of small elites that ever lived within city walls. Most people worked on the land
column9: producing the energy that they needed to survive. Cities
column10: on the other hand
column11: with these sort of exclusive spaces where nobody worked to produce energy
column12: but everybody worked to expend energy. And so the ability to monopolize
column13: control the distribution and flows of energy resources
column14: whether those took the form of food
column15: whether those took the form of beer
column16: whether those took the form of
column17: ultimately
column18: money or exchanges and debts
column19: became a source of great power and became a source of great differentiation. But at the same time within cities
column20: because people were expending energy and because they have this innate creativity
column21: this drive to work
column22: you ended up with a whole efflorescence of new professions
column23: ways
column24: and things of doing. You have this explosion of art and literature. You also had people developing religious centers and centering ritual power on themselves. And these forces ended up creating many micro communities within cities. But these micro communities were often highly differentiated by the amount of power they were able to accrue
column25: the influence they were able to work. And this effectively transformed the way people engaged and worked with one another and lived with one another and produced
column26: I think
column27: this real sense of people wanting things
column28: people wanting. You were continuously confronted by somebody who had more than you or somebody who had less than you of whatever it had happened to be. It could be any form of capital
column29: whether it’s social capital
column30: ritual capital
column31: or capital
column32: capital. But you’re constantly confronted by people having more. And we have that gut instinct to say
column33: well
column34: if they have that
column35: maybe I want to have that
column37: I think that is the kind of driver of — if it’s said that we have infinite desires. I don’t think it is. We just want to have as much as the next guy. And there are two ways of achieving it. Either you work to try and get what they have
column38: or you try and take what they have. Or
column39: as has happened throughout history — and again
column40: it’s very particularly a history of ... there have been very few what you’d call sort of great
column41: turning things over revolutions in purely rural communities — you have them in urban centers where you get elites brought down
column42: crashing down. And then the process begins almost inevitably again. [MUSIC PLAYING]

column1: ezra klein
You talk in the book about Émile Durkheim’s theory of infinite aspiration. Can you just explain that?
james suzman
Well
column2: around that period when Émile Durkheim was writing
column3: of course
column4: this was the era where economics was becoming an established science
column5: a science based on how people allocated scarcity. And there was the sense of trying to understand what is this basic economic problem
column6: this problem of scarcity? What is this idea that we have such huge desires that we can never hope to satisfy? And for me
column7: it seems that there’s a very clear correlation between that sense of economic desire and what Émile Durkheim talked about when he talked about the sense of anomie
column8: this idea that people felt left out or that they felt alienated in society
column9: and
column10: at the same time
column11: this desire they had to have something
column12: which they didn’t have at the time
column13: this constant sense that there was something unfulfilled. Durkheim explained this as a consequence of the transition really from the kind of artisan-based industries to early levels of industrialization as people moved into cities. And he believed that this kind of sense of alienation
column14: of left-outness
column15: would be ended because
column16: eventually
column17: people would coalesce around different kinds of artisanal communities in urban areas. And they would have a sort of sense of self and a sense of identity and a sense of purpose closely associated with them. But I think this idea of constant unfulfillment is something very much associated with modern life. And part of it is because things are constantly changing. The goalposts are constantly moving ahead. So
column18: for example
column19: I’ve always been a bit of a tech junky. And I’m tired of it now. But the minute you suddenly reach your goal of having the iPhone 11
column20: somebody has got an iPhone 12 out. There’s this constant reaching forth
column21: this constant sense of unsatisfaction
column22: this constant sense that as soon as we achieve a goal post
column23: it moves onwards. And I think that is very much a function of urban life. And I think it’s also very much a function of this ever changing nature of modernity.

column1: ezra klein
I think the natural way to think about that competition is material. You brought up the iPhone 11
column2: and then somebody’s got an iPhone 12. You got a house
column3: somebody gets a bigger house. But there’s also this social one. When I was reading the section of your book on Durkheim
column4: you talked about how he believes at that time that he’s simply living through a transitionary moment in society. And people will figure it out. They’ll figure out how to regulate their wants a little bit better. They’ll figure out how to not have their head turned by everything
column5: that it’s simply the explosion of material goods that is doing that. So on the one hand
column6: clearly
column7: not. It just accelerated and accelerated and accelerated. But then on top of that
column8: it made me think about the social media age. Because you often hear the same thing now
column9: which is
column10: well
column11: we’re just getting used to these new technologies. Facebook
column12: it’s certainly in my lifetime. I mean
column13: it’s in my adulthood. Twitter even more so
column14: Snapchat
column15: et cetera. But when I look at it
column16: I wonder if what we’re developing now
column17: for particularly people who are young
column18: is an age of infinite social aspiration. So I mean
column19: even if you could get a lot of things before
column20: there was still pretty limited community in which you could play out the drama of your social standing
column21: right? It was the people you knew and your family and your neighborhood. I mean
column22: it was sort of geographically bound for most people most of the time. And now it just isn’t. And you might have different social standings in different networks
column23: some of which you’re participating in as a pseudonymous player on Reddit. And then you have your real name on Instagram and on Twitter. And I’m curious how you think about that. Because a big driver here isn’t just material goods. I mean
column24: material goods partially drive because they’re reflections of our social identities. But now
column25: in some ways
column26: we’re also disentangling that. And we just have more direct social competition in all these weird
column27: little social micro worlds. So I’m curious what you see in that trend.

column1: james suzman
Well
column2: I’ll tell you what I see. I see another mystery. So exactly as Durkheim imagined that we would enter some kind of next steady state
column3: I’m now increasingly persuaded by — the data would suggest that actually
column4: we’re now — we’ve entered an era of near constant flux. And what we are becoming good at and what I hope we become good at in our infinite adaptability is to become good at coping with and dealing with constant change. And I think it’s an extraordinarily difficult thing to untangle. But I think that is the key. I think we now live in an era where there is no steady state for us to aspire to. There is no end game in front of us. And that requires an adjustment in our mindset in terms of how we engage with the world around us. And I may be being naive
column5: but I take some encouragement from how some younger people actually seem relatively at ease with it. I’m constantly surprised by my own children
column6: for example
column7: in this respect.

column1: ezra klein
I hear people say that. And my interactions with young people and then my read of the data is that they’re not at ease with it. Very
column2: very
column3: very high rates of anxiety
column4: of depression
column5: of competition
column6: of fear
column7: of suicide
column8: for that matter. One of the things that I think all this comes to is
column9: we’re in an era where the dominant systems in which we live have hooked into our desires. And they use them to propel everything forward
column10: right? That’s a part of our humanity that you could either emphasize or deemphasize
column11: to the point of this whole conversation. And we really emphasize it. And so you get weird things now
column12: weird outcomes
column13: when you have direct conflict between the desire for leisure and the desire for work. So one of them is — a really strange trend in affluent countries today
column14: is that elites are often working more than ever. They often work more than the middle and lower class work
column15: at least on the income scale. That’s weird because it used to be the point of being rich is you didn’t have to work. You did all kinds of things to show you weren’t working. But now there is survey research published a few years ago in the Harvard Business Review that found that 62 percent of high-earning individuals work over 50 hours a week. More than a third work over 60 hours a week. One in 10 works over 80 hours a week. So I mean
column16: here are people who absolutely could have abundance
column17: right? To some degree
column18: I’m one of these people. I work a lot. And I’m very tired. And I recognize that I’m enough outside it to realize something is weird in this. But I’m curious how you look at that. Because I mean
column19: we really are seeing the collision here. And even the people with the most capacity to choose leisure are choosing labor. And they’re doing so more and more. I mean
column20: it’s different than it was 100 years ago.

column1: james suzman
Yeah
column2: look
column3: it’s a very strange phenomenon
column4: in some senses. And in others
column5: it seems perfectly natural. I mean
column6: again
column7: I tend to take an anthropologist’s eye on this. Most of us are urban creatures now. We get our sense of identity
column8: our sense of self-esteem
column9: our sense of purpose
column10: our sense of community comes from work and the workplace. So beyond that kind of purposefulness
column11: even if we’re doing a job which is not particularly important but it gets us money
column12: we continue to do it. And I think
column13: in many senses
column14: because the people who are in the upper echelons
column15: the workers
column16: the highest paid and the best rewarded
column17: actually
column18: they’re in a position to dictate the nature of their work and to be able to nudge their work towards being something that actually gives them great satisfaction. So in a sense
column19: it’s a kind of privilege. And if you look through history
column20: again
column21: I mean
column22: lots of people who were — we talk about the original aspiration to be — you do your work
column23: and then you get free for leisure. But people with that leisure time spent that time doing work that meant something to them. And it just so happens I think in the urban modern world that we live in
column24: for many people
column25: there actually isn’t a great deal of life outside of work. And as cultural creatures
column26: that’s what we do. We stay with the communities and systems and processes and ways of doing things that make our lives meaningful that we are comfortable with and that we are confident with and that don’t challenge us the whole time. So I think that’s probably where the culture of workism comes from. But again
column27: I view it very much as a cultural phenomenon.

column1: ezra klein
One of the things you say in the book is that the purpose of the book is to
column2: quote
column3: “loosen the claw-like grasp that scarcity economics has held over our working lives.” Which is to say that you want to nudge us towards the idea that we can have lives of more leisure. We could enjoy the abundance we’ve created. But I found the book very pessimistic on this score. If you think the problem with how much we work is we simply haven’t produced enough
column4: well
column5: then you could say
column6: well
column7: maybe we’ll invent AI
column8: or we’ll start mining asteroids or whatever it is. And we’ll get over that production threshold. But if you think that our society’s obsession with work
column9: it’s not simply a modern reflection. It kind of sits at the heart of how we’ve built human civilization since the move to agriculture itself and that it’s kind of conquered all these societies that didn’t have it
column10: it’s won all these contests when it came to conflict with somebody saying
column11: well
column12: how about more leisure? Then it’s much harder because it implies that sort of nothing we actually invent will do it. We’ll just always come up with ways to work more
column13: or we will become miserable in the face of automation because people will feel not like they’re sharing in abundance
column14: but they’ve been deprived of dignity
column15: of a job of meaning. So instead of having a post-AI and -automation utopia
column16: you have a dystopia. I’d love you to convince me I’m wrong
column17: that there’s a more optimistic read of the trends here.

column1: james suzman
Well
column2: no
column3: let me put it this way. I am certainly not an optimist
column4: but I always remain hopeful. Because if we abandon hope
column5: then what good is it doing? What good is that doing anything? My sense of where we are and where we could be is pretty much aligned to Keynes’s dream. I mean
column6: that’s really why I actually quote him so often. Because I kind of buy into the idea that once we are liberated from tedious labor
column7: once we’re liberated from the difficult work
column8: which I think machines can and will do
column9: then we are free to do work that is meaningful to us. And at the moment
column10: of the many inequities of the way our economic systems are organized is you get lots of truly gifted people in one or other sphere of life who end up doing work completely unrelated to that gift. So I live in a university town
column11: Cambridge. And I’ve lost count of the number of friends I’ve had who’ve gone from jobs that I think were doing really useful research
column12: whether it’s in chemical engineering to medicine
column13: to taking some job in the private sector to improve the consistency of honey or the sparkliness of somebody’s dress or something. We tend to get incentivized into doing work that is not particularly interesting. I imagine that if we’re in a world where
column14: actually
column15: all of our basic needs
column16: very basic needs were met
column17: that people didn’t have to do unsatisfactory work
column18: that we would end up
column19: actually
column20: having more of the good work done in the first place. So I mean
column21: it’s a relatively trite example. But I think it’s one that serves the piece. I mean
column22: the world is full of really great musicians who
column23: pretty much
column24: nobody’s ever listened to. And nobody’s ever listened to them because they just haven’t had the good luck
column25: the kind of break that you need. For every top selling artist
column26: there are 10
column27: 000 other ones who are just as skilled and accomplished who’ve never got anywhere. And that’s because they’ve had to get stuck in doing whatever minimum wage jobs to get by because of the way we’ve organized our system of work. And what I think is that there are opportunities in front of us. And this is why I say we’ve got to unshackle ourselves from this sort of focus of perpetual growth and start asking ourselves this question
column28: how do we use our wealth as well as we can? And we can think about that wealth in terms of
column29: again
column30: this phrase
column31: “human flourishing” in terms of enriching ourselves spiritually
column32: in terms of enriching ourselves mentally and in terms of doing things that are of greater social good. And I think that world is possible
column33: a world where people do what they want and that produces greater total value for everybody. That continues to drive some kind of progress forward for all of our benefit.

column1: ezra klein
Let me ask about an example in the book where that came into direct question. You have this great sequence on the Kellogg’s cereal company. And that in the 1930s
column2: Kellogg’s
column3: they actually did it. I mean
column4: they increased productivity. They went down to a 30-hour work week. They were paying people more per hour than they had been before. I mean
column5: it’s everything you would think that we want. And so then people would have all this extra time
column6: at least theoretically
column7: in which they could make music or write novels or just hang out with their friends or play sports or take a walk
column8: whatever it might be. And then the denouement of that story was kind of shocking to me. It’s not that the Kellogg’s corporation brings back the 40-hour workweek
column9: but the work force votes back the 40-hour workweek
column10: largely because in a world of more material goods
column11: they want the option to be able to make more money. So how do you read that story? Because that struck me as a real example of like
column12: OK
column13: we had the choice. And it wasn’t like the capitalists forced it back in. But the workers said
column14: nah
column15: in the society
column16: unless everybody jumps at the same time
column17: we’re not going to be the only ones working 30 hours a week and not being able to give our families or ourselves as much as everybody else is getting.

column1: james suzman
I think the guy who produced a great answer to that particular question was John Kenneth Galbraith
column2: when he wrote that book
column3: “The Affluent Society
column4: ” round about the same time that the Kellogg’s crew were busy voting themselves back into 40-hour shifts. And this was an era I think where you had massive amplification of desire created through advertising. So when Galbraith wrote that book in 1950 — I can’t remember the exact year — he wrote it effectively as a warning to say that America was squandering its newfound wealth. And the way it was squandering it was by manufacturing desires. He made the case
column5: effectively
column6: that America had defeated scarcity. And that if they organized their resources well
column7: then everybody could be comfortably looked after. But he said the great risk was that now that we’ve defeated scarcity
column8: this kind of desire for more amongst certainly
column9: in particular
column10: I suppose
column11: wealthy entrenched businesses meant that people were manufacturing scarcity
column12: and that this great scarcity manufacturing machine
column13: in the form of an advertising industry
column14: began to expand and play directly into people’s homes
column15: elevated from small newspaper adverts to suddenly this wonderful television box and radio and just pumping desire into people’s home. Your life will not be complete if you don’t have x
column16: y
column17: or z. And this
column18: of course
column19: was a great driver of growth
column20: in a sense. This remains one of the great drivers of growth in our world
column21: this idea that if we have a little bit more
column22: we’ll find that point of satisfaction. And I think that’s really what happened. I think the Kellogg’s
column23: that era
column24: Kellogg’s was sort of swept up in this wonderful set of new great conveniences that emerged in post-war America
column25: as all these sort of wartime technologies were repurposed into domestic technologies
column26: from microwave ovens to all these great new wonders. And people wanted a part of them. And then advertisers were saying
column27: well
column28: if you’ve got more and more of this
column29: then you might make it. And so
column30: yeah
column31: it fed. Basically
column32: this desire took people to a point where they thought we need more.

column1: ezra klein
Yeah
column2: that’s a little funny piece of it there. But I want to hold on that the point about advertising. I’m always thrilled when a podcast gets back into “The Affluent Society.” I love John Kenneth Galbraith. I had Noam Chomsky on the show a couple of months back
column3: and we ended up talking about that for a while. But that’s one of the places where I get very pessimistic. So I think when people talk about a post-work world
column4: the typical technological savior is artificial intelligence and automation. The idea is that we’re going to have this super intelligent
column5: cognitive
column6: zero marginal cost workforce creating all the stuff for us. And we’ll just get to enjoy it. And then I look at who is actually creating
column7: who is actually creating the big AI platforms. And I see Google
column8: and I see Facebook. And I see Open AI
column9: which is hitched
column10: in some ways
column11: now to Microsoft and others. It’s more complicated
column12: but still
column13: there’s some connection to these companies. And you can keep going on like this. But Google and Facebook
column14: who are two of the very big players here potentially
column15: those are advertising businesses. They survive on generating desire. And it’s already my view. And by the way
column16: I’m in the media. I’m also in advertising and subscription
column17: but an advertising business. And it’s my view that advertising is both inefficient
column18: but also a pretty neglected economic force. The disdain with which a lot of modern economists treat Galbraith’s ideas just seems completely unmerited to me. But at the same time
column19: again
column20: advertising — and I know this for quite a fact — it’s usually pretty bad. It’s quite inefficient. It’s quite poorly done. It’s much more art than science. A lot of it is witchcraft. Now
column21: though
column22: if you hook it to AI
column23: feeding off of the level of data we have and the level of iteration it could do with us
column24: maybe it gets a lot better. And so rather than this sort of AI world we’re moving towards being really
column25: really good at creating abundance
column26: I worry that particularly in the near term
column27: it’s going to be really
column28: really good at creating desire. More than it’s going to give us more of what we actually want
column29: it’s going to become better and better at getting us to want more that we don’t have. Because that’s what the real business model is. And I’m curious if you have any reflections on that.

column1: james suzman
I think
column2: regrettably
column3: you’re kind of right. If I see one potential silver lining to that cloud — and it’s not a very cheerful silver lining either — is that this process of increased automation that we’ve been going through is having a number of secondary social and environmental impacts. And these produce absolute constraints upon us. Now the environmental ones you’re familiar with — I’m not going to rehearse them — but we clearly are at a stage in time in history where we need to constrain our economic behavior one way or another
column4: or at least
column5: alter it
column6: in order to respond to environmental circumstances. So that’s one absolute constraint. There is a second one. And this is the more automated our economies become
column7: the more driven by AI
column8: the more work that is actually done by machines
column9: the less marginal utility human work actually has. And when you live in a society where human work has diminished value
column10: you end up with a society where the ability to work yourself to prosperity diminishes. Prosperity becomes about access to capital because capital is what you use to acquire machines
column11: which do the actual work. And we’ve seen this mushrooming inequality
