column12: coincidentally since the beginnings of the digital revolution in the 1980s and
column13: obviously
column14: amplified by deregulation and so on. And that is because wealth now accrues effectively to wealth. Money begets money
column15: to use Benjamin Franklin’s phrase. And this continued growth
column16: if we have a continued amplification of desire and so on and so on
column17: I can only see this inequality getting worse. And my sense is
column18: is that we are. It is
column19: again
column20: part of our nature to respond to inequality. And I see these tensions as building up and potentially coming to a kind of crashing point
column21: which either forces us to some kind of action. Now my speculation and
column22: in fact
column23: my hope is
column24: is that before you end up with some sort of hideous revolutionary action
column25: and we’re seeing temperatures rising in all sorts of places
column26: my suspicion is that something
column27: perhaps an environmental disaster
column28: which makes us start thinking a little more globally and recognizing the interconnectedness of our problems
column29: might take us there. I speculated idly and kind of wish I hadn’t
column30: actually
column31: when I finished the book
column32: I speculated idly that something like a pandemic might push us into that kind of frame of collaborative thinking. And I’m certainly not convinced that it has now. But I think with these things
column33: one has to have some kind of hope. Because otherwise
column34: we’re not going to be able to deal with the bigger problems that we’re facing. And the bigger problems are
column35: above all
column38: relating to greater social fragmentation in an ever smaller world.

column1: ezra klein
Well
column2: I do think the one message of the book
column3: the more hopeful message of the book
column4: is that culture can do more than we give it credit for. And if a lot of the science fiction conversation
column5: the utopian conversation
column6: looks towards technology to usher us into the world of abundance
column7: I think some of what you’re saying is that no
column8: it’s going to have to be cultural change that allows us to live within abundance. It allows us to appreciate abundance. So in the societies that you mostly study
column9: it’s a lot of social shame and mockery and demand taxing. Those are pretty big changes. And it’s hard for me to see a near-term version where they become the tools we use to police status and to police desire. But I’m curious if you think there are cultural trends or cultural tools that are suited or more adjacent to the societies we’re in right now that could begin to play that role.

column1: james suzman
I certainly think there are some tools that are available and there are some policy ideas that are available. I mean
column2: we live in unprecedented times. I mean
column3: it’s the kind of thing that’s been said again and again and again. But we have never before lived in an era of such extraordinary material abundance with such huge energy footprints
column4: such a large population. Prior solutions are not going to work. But there does seem to me to be a real willingness to expand beyond old ideas
column5: for example
column6: this kind of tired old division between capitalism and socialism
column7: and start looking at other mechanisms that might be able to change the way we engage with things
column8: like want and desire and so on
column9: and indeed
column10: change our relationship with work. And something along the lines
column11: at least the moral lines
column12: of the universal basic income strikes me as a potentially transformative tool in terms of getting us to
column13: one
column14: work better
column15: and
column16: two
column17: diminishing
column18: potentially diminishing
column19: that sort of huge desire. I also think that there’s great value — and I mean
column20: I’m speaking to you from Europe
column21: where we have a much stronger socialist tradition. But I think now that we are in an asset-based economy
column22: it’d make perfect sense to have a taxation system based on asset ownership — in effect
column23: a wealth tax
column24: rather than an income tax. Income is so marginal in terms of real wealth creation at the moment
column25: that it seems bizarre that that is what we’re taxing. And if we instituted those kinds of structures
column26: then it produces a kind of change in morality. In Denmark
column27: they make a joke saying
column28: well
column29: we work three days for the state. And then Thursday and Friday morning
column30: we work for ourselves. But there’s a sense that actually that’s a good thing. There’s a sense that that realizes the whole sequence of benefits. And it doesn’t drive people off to a mass
column31: grand wodges of wealth
column32: or it doesn’t incentivize it massively. And because they have that general system
column33: things bizarrely
column34: like asset prices
column35: property prices in places like Copenhagen
column36: remain relatively stable. And I think there’s an opportunity to experiment. And I think because we are in unprecedented circumstances and because the risk is so high of not getting it right
column37: we’ve got to be brave. We’ve got to be prepared to experiment. We’ve got to be prepared to learn from those experiments and accept where they don’t work. And I think the best opportunity we have at the moment
column38: the one that looks best prepackaged to me
column39: is universal income. And I’d love to see a large scale experiment in it. And the problem with all the current experiments we have with it
column40: that they’re basic income experiments. They’re not universal basic income experiments. And so we don’t see how that might incentivize our relationship with desire and aspiration on a societal level.

column1: ezra klein
I think that’s a good place to come to a close. Let me ask you always our final question on the show. What are three books that have influenced you that you would recommend to the audience?
james suzman
So I’m going to mention three books
column2: two of which are books that I’ve read recently and one of which is possibly my favorite nonfiction book of all time. And that one is Adam Hochschild’s “King Leopold’s Ghost
column3: ” which tells the story of the exploitation of rubber in the Belgian Congo and the horrendous genocide that emerged out of that. For me
column4: apart from being just a beautifully written piece of history
column5: it’s a book that explores humanity at its absolute best and its worst. And it reminds us that in the kind of grimmest circumstances
column6: there is some cause for optimism and that there is some basis to ideas that sometimes seem antiquated now
column7: like dignity. The other two books are kind of closely related in a strange way. “Entangled Life” by Merlin Sheldrake
column8: which is
column9: really
column10: the story of fungus and how fungus interacts and is so critical to our ecosystem. And it’s one of these many books now that are bringing in
column11: I suppose
column12: a sort of mix between philosophy and very hard core science
column13: but which reminds us that our environments are far more complex and interconnected than
column14: really
column15: we’d ever imagined before. And these are the kind of things that are driving the new extended evolutionary synthesis and really waking us up to the interconnectedness of our actions with those of our broader environments. The other book which I want to talk about is “Other Minds” by Peter Godfrey Smith. And this is a story about alternate forms of intelligence. And it’s a mix of philosophy and biology. And it’s about his time working primarily with octopus. And so
column16: in a sense
column17: it’s a bit like that movie
column18: “My Octopus Teacher
column19: ” but a far more sophisticated engagement with it. And what it does is it introduces us to the idea of possibly supremely different kinds of consciousnesses. And in the case of octopus
column20: the fact that they have separate brains for each of their legs and that the main brain is actually a minor player in the mix is just amazing. And he talks about — where it’s particularly wonderful is there’s now all this talk about potential extraterrestrial contact and alternative forms of intelligence. And it reminds us that intelligence can manifest in some supremely strange and very
column21: very different ways
column22: ways that force us to really question our basic categories of what intelligence is.

column1: ezra klein
James Suzman
column2: your book is “Work: A Deep History from the Stone Age to the Age of Robots.” I enjoyed it tremendously and recommend it very much
column3: even as I betrayed almost every message in it while working on this to create the podcast. But thank you so much for being here.

column1: james suzman
Thank you very much for having me
column2: Ezra. [MUSIC PLAYING]

https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/30/business/covid-shot-impulse-buy.html/Tennis Balls and Boxed Wine: What You Bought After the Covid Shot/"The 15 minutes after getting a Covid shot can be a time of profound emotion
column2: a moment of relief or gratitude or release as you wait to make sure you don’t have a bad reaction to the vaccine.

column1: So we were curious: If you got vaccinated in a pharmacy
column2: did you wander the aisles while you waited
column3: and if so
column4: did you treat yourself to something impulsive or important or out of character?

column1: We recently ask readers what they indulged in. We received hundreds of responses. You told us stories of celebration
column2: practicality
column3: and occasional mishaps — and we asked our photographer Kyle Berger to re-envision some of those stories. Here are a select few with your responses
column4: edited and condensed for clarity."/['Kyle Berger'
column5: 'Alana Celii'

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/29/theater/bruce-springsteen-broadway-usher.html/The Boss Is Back on Broadway. The Workers Are Coming Back
column2: Too./"Barry
column3: originally from Bay Ridge
column4: Brooklyn
column5: took an unusual path to the theater industry. For 27 years
column6: he had worked in banking
column7: first as a teller
column8: and then as a bank officer in Times Square.

column1: He saw theater
column2: occasionally
column3: and loved it. As a teenager he saw Danny Kaye in “Two by Two
column4: ” and later he saw “Jesus Christ Superstar.” (“I couldn’t believe it was so fantastic.”) But the production he most excitedly remembers seeing is “Grease
column5: ” at the Royale Theater; a friend got him access to walk onto the stage before the show. “It gave me the bug
column6: ” he said.

column1: So when he decided he needed to earn more money
column2: and began looking for a second job
column3: he reached out to one of his customers at the bank
column4: a woman who worked in payroll at Jujamcyn Theaters
column5: which operates five Broadway theaters
column6: including the St. James. She asked if he’d be open to ushering.

column1: That was in 2001. The first shift he worked was at a dress rehearsal for “The Producers
column2: ” which was about to open. “You know you belong when your body just gets enveloped in euphoria
column3: ” he said."/['Michael Paulson']/2021-06-29 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/30/arts/29USHER1/29USHER1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/28/business/retirement/women-social-security-retirement.html/A Woman’s Guide to Making the Most of Social Security/"As a single woman with no children
column2: Karen Callahan is putting together the financial pieces that will protect her for a potentially long life on her own. A large piece of her puzzle: getting as much Social Security income as she can.

column1: Ms. Callahan
column3: of Marlborough
column4: Mass.
column5: is holding off on claiming her benefits until she turns 70
column6: when she will be eligible for $3
column7: 100 a month. If she claimed today
column8: she said
column9: her benefit would be permanently reduced to about $2

column1: The income from a web design business she owns will cover her expenses until 70
column2: including a $375 monthly condo fee on her townhouse. In excellent health and able to bench press 120 pounds
column3: Ms. Callahan expects to live long enough to get more in lifetime benefits by waiting than by claiming less for a longer time.

column1: “Hell’s bells — I have put the money in
column2: and I am going for the max
column3: ” she said.

column1: For many older single women
column2: as well as for divorced women and widows
column3: getting the most out of Social Security is crucial
column4: experts say. Women tend to live longer than men
column5: and they depend more on Social Security as a primary source of retirement income. Also
column6: their benefits
column7: on average
column8: are smaller
column9: in part because of lost earnings or part-time work during years caring for children and older relatives."/['Susan B. Garland']/2021-06-28 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/29/business/27jpRetiring1-print/27jpRetiring1-print-facebookJumbo-v2.jpg"

column1: Cookies. Cookies are small files that are placed on your computer when you visit a website. Cookies may be used to store a unique identification number tied to your computer or device so that you can be recognized as the same user across one or more browsing sessions
column2: and across one or more sites. Cookies serve many useful purposes. For example:

column1: Cookies can remember your sign-in credentials so you do not have to enter those credentials each time you visit a Service.

Cookies can help us and third parties understand which parts of our Services are the most popular because they help us see which pages and features visitors access and how much time they spend on the pages. By studying this kind of information
column2: we are better able to adapt our Services and provide you with a better experience.

column1: Cookies help us and third parties understand which ads you have seen so that you don’t receive the same ad each time you access a Service.
Most browsers accept cookies automatically
column2: but can be configured not to do so or to notify the user when a cookie is being sent. If you wish to disable cookies
column3: refer to your browser help menu to learn how to disable cookies. If you disable browser cookies or flash cookies
column4: it may interfere with the proper functioning of the Services.

column1: Beacons. We
column2: along with third parties
column3: also may use technologies called beacons (or “pixels”) that communicate information from your device to a server. Beacons can be embedded in online content
column4: videos
column5: and emails
column6: and can allow a server to read certain types of information from your device
column7: know when you have viewed particular content or a particular email message
column8: determine the time and date on which you viewed the beacon
column9: and the IP address of your device. We and third parties use beacons for a variety of purposes
column10: including to analyze the use of our Services and (in conjunction with cookies) to provide content and ads that are more relevant to you.

column1: Local Storage & Other Tracking Technologies. We
column2: along with third parties
column3: may use other kinds of technologies
column4: such as Local Shared Objects (also referred to as “Flash cookies”) and HTML5 local storage
column5: in connection with our Services. We also may use unique identifiers associated with your device
column6: such as mobile ad identifiers. These technologies are similar to the cookies discussed above in that they are stored on your device and can be used to store certain information about your activities and preferences. However
column7: these technologies may make use of different parts of your device from standard cookies
column8: and so you might not be able to control them using standard browser tools and settings. For HTML5 local storage
column9: the method for disabling HTML5 will vary depending on your browser. For Flash cookies
column10: information about disabling or deleting information contained in Flash cookies can be found here.

column3: now we gotta show them there are consequences to what they did. And think about this: How long before some other sicko group takes something cool from nature? Like clouds or something. We gotta destroy rainbows now.”

Dear Allison

It was my 21st birthday a couple days ago. The ONLY thing I asked my Nana for was a pair of diamond earrings. I don’t know how I should feel because I found out they are cubic zirconium. My stepmother pointed it out yesterday
column2: and thinking about it
column3: I cried on the way to work. I don’t know if I should say something. I don’t want to sound like a spoiled brat
column4: but it was the only thing I asked for. Should I mention it? I really want to say something.

column1: -Faked Out
Dear Faked
Aww
column2: poor you. Too late
column3: you already sound like a spoiled brat. 21? Nana is wise enough to know you’ll lose an earring during one of your many drunk night – most likely while you’re going down on a stranger with an STD who picked you up while you were blacked out at the bar. What are you
column4: a rich bitch? It’s time to grow up and realize Nana’s bank account doesn’t revolve around you. Whatever your job is
column5: it isn’t hard enough. You should try mining your own diamond for a bowl of gruel a day.

column1: But then again
column2: I’m not really the person to ask since my own mother would’ve slapped me if I had the balls to ask for diamonds. Maybe you should buy yourself a bunch of booze and get the courage to call your Nana. I’m sure if you whine enough she’ll get you a much better present next year.

column1: Dear Allison
I am torn between my 16 year-old daughter
column2: “Uniquea” and my bae
column3: “Tyrone”. My fiancé got me a stuffed monkey for my birthday a couple weeks ago. Wellllllll…afterwards we got in a fight
column4: and he wanted it back. I told him no
column5: cuz he gave that to me. Anyway
column6: he comes over to get it
column7: and we got in another altercation over it. After we had it out
column8: he apologized and started kissin’ up on me. My daughter screamed
column9: she sick of him hustlin’ me and after kissin’ on me like it was a’ight. Then she took his Ray-Bans and ran in the other room. I screamed at her to give ‘em back
column10: but she twisted them ‘till they was broke beyond repair. Tyrone insists Uniquea needa pay for them out of her hair/nail allowance
column11: but I say Tyrone shouldn’t of been over here provokin’ in the first place. Should I side with my man or my daughter?

column1: -Hassled at Home
Dear Hassled
Your fiancé sounds like quite the catch. I bet the moment you don’t put out
column2: he demands you give him all those cheesy “I Luv You” Valentine’s teddy bears that line your headboard. Unfortunately
column3: it doesn’t matter what you do. You’re screwed. You’re daughter’s screwed. It doesn’t matter if Tyrone is in your life because you’re all cursed to live an ignorant
column4: drama-filled existence
column5: regardless. Continue modeling that kind of behavior and just pray Uniquea’s first baby isn’t doesn’t end up with as God-awful a name as she did and that her baby-daddy actually pays child support.

DEAR ALLISON

How do I know if the man I married is really “the one?” My husband and I have been married for 2 years. He does everything for me. He works three jobs so I can stay home and build my small business. He cooks
column2: and cleans. He’s fantastic in bed. We are doing really well…but there is something that’s just missing. What if I made a mistake?

column1: – CONCERNED in CALIFORNIA
Dear Concerned
The man sounds like a saint. To be honest
column2: I don’t think he probably is the one for you. If anything
column3: he sounds like the one for me. After the string of losers I’ve been with
column4: I could use a man who knows how to cook
column5: how to clean
column6: and how to do me right. Tell you what
column7: Concerned – you let him go. If he comes back
column8: then he’s “the one.” If you find him in my bed
column9: then it looks like he was the one
column10: but you’re too stupid to have known it. You’re living every woman’s dream
column11: and you’re thinking it might have been a mistake? You must be a lesbian.

column1: DEAR ALLISON
For my 18th birthday my boyfriend got me a tattoo
column2: but I didn’t tell my parents. I still live at home
column3: and my Dad will FREAK OUT if he knows that I got “Chris Forever” tattooed on my thigh. How do I tell my parents that I got inked?

column1: – TATTED in TALLAHASSE
Dear Tatted
First off
column2: the fact that you’re barely 18 and you got your boyfriend’s name tattooed on you already screams how dumb you are. There are people who have been married decades who don’t do stupid things like that. My suggestion would be to tell your parents as soon as possible
column3: and hope they forgive you enough to help pay to have it lasered off. The only name you should put on your body is your child’s. Hell
column4: you shouldn’t even put that. Get a damn flower or a heart like every other teenage idiot out there
column5: and call it a day. Since I got this letter 2 weeks ago
column6: I’d assume that Chris has already left you for some other bimbo. Now you get to spend the rest of your life dating only men named Chris
column7: or else they’re going to go limp as soon as you take your pants off.

column1: DEAR ALLISON
My mother is a die-hard Christian
column2: and on more than one occasion has made it quite known to me
column3: my family
column4: and everyone else who will listen that she hates gay people
column5: and thinks they are an abomination. I’m 23 now
column6: and I’m afraid to come out of the closet for fear I will lose my mother’s love. What do I do?

column1: -IN THE CLOSET in INDIANAPOLIS
Dear Closet
Man up
column2: my gay friend. If your mother is such a bigot that she would disown her child because of their sexual orientation
column3: than you don’t need her! Find a new mom. Find a mate
column4: and have their mom be your new mom! There are plenty of people out there who will accept you for who you are. It will probably be hard at first to tell your mother
column5: but if she can’t handle it
column6: then how is she going to handle when you find a mate? Get married? Adopt children? In my opinion
column7: your mother needs to grow the hell up and deal. It’s 2014 for crying out loud. How much longer are we going to have to deal with these conservative bigots? Listen
column8: you tell your mom that she’s going to have to accept you
column9: or you smack that bitch in the face. No two ways about it. Good luck!

DEAR ALLISON
Sometimes I think my step-mother really holds me back from having any fun. If I ask her if it’s okay to go to movies with friends
column2: she won’t let me unless I do something for her
column3: like the dishes or mow the lawn or any number of other household chores. I am the only one that she makes do this – my two step-brothers and my step-sister get to go out and do whatever they want. Why does she make me do things but they never have to?

column1: -CRYING in COLORADO
Dear Crying
You don’t have to be such a crybaby
column2: you know. Just do the damn dishes
column3: and then you can go hang out with friends or go to the movies. Your step-mother is letting her kids do things without “paying her” for them because they are the fruit of her loins. Since you were ejected from some other woman’s lovehole
column4: she’s more than likely making you pay for it. No step-mother has ever liked her step-children. Haven’t you ever seen Cinderella? Your best bet is to hurry up and turn 18
column5: so you can tell her exactly where to go
column6: and exactly how to get there.

column1: DEAR ALLISON
I hate it when people spoil the endings of my favorite TV shows or movies I haven’t seen on social media. Simple question
column2: but how do I get people to stop talking about things before I see them?!

column1: -UGH in UTAH
Dear Ugh
First
column2: let me congratulate you on coming up with the worst damn pseudonym that I’ve ever seen. “Ugh?” Oh God
column3: you must be 12. Anyway
column4: this might come as a surprise to you
column5: but you could
column6: you know
column7: get the hell off the internet once in a while. You could also stop worrying about TV and movies getting spoiled for you
column8: because they’re just entertainment
column9: and if knowing who died on last night’s episode of Game of Thrones before you’ve had a chance to watch it is ruining your life
column10: I think you’re going to have much
column11: much bigger problems in life the older you get. Good luck in life
column12: Ugh. You’re definitely going to need it.

column1: DEAR ALLISON
I got married last week
column2: and my mother-in-law got completely hammered drunk at the wedding. Long story short
column3: she ended up hitting on my still-very-married father. It made my mother extremely upset
column4: and now my husband’s family and my family will have nothing to do with each other. What can I do to reconcile this whole ordeal?

column1: -TOASTED in TULSA
Dear Toasted
Who cares if your families can’t get along? Do they really have to have anything to do with each other? My husband hasn’t spoken to my side of the family since the wedding four years ago
column2: and he’s never been happier. In case you didn’t know this
column3: in-laws have never gotten along with their son or daughter’s significant other. Or you could play it the complete opposite way and try and get your parents divorced so you can hook up your father and mother-in-law. It could be one big
column4: happy family. It’s really your call. Either way
column5: people do stupid things when drunk. If your mother doesn’t know that
column6: she must be a complete and total stick in the ass…or mud. Whatever floats your boat.

DEAR ALLISON

column3: there really is no other explanation. I’d suggest that you “be that bitchy girlfriend” and go through his phone or Facebook. You don’t want to confront him
column4: because what’s the point? Is he just going to say “oh
column5: you’re right
column6: dear

column8: he’s going to deny it. Your best course of action is to wait until he’s asleep and smell his penis. It sounds crude
column9: but everyone knows men rarely wash themselves period
column10: and the odds of him showering after having his mistress over is zero. Definitely sniff that shaft
column11: and you’ll have all the evidence you need.

column1: DEAR ALLISON
My girlfriend of two years is lazy and doesn’t wanna do anything for me. In my circle
column2: the other girlfriends will make food for the game
column3: and then go off and do their own thing
column4: but they always come out to see if we need more beer or snacks
column5: you know? My girlfriend doesn’t do those things

column7: they give me crap about how lazy she is. When we watch the game at my house

column9: and then she sits around
column10: trying to talk through the game. Like we’re interested in listening to her long
column11: boring stories about shoes? The other day I was checking out my buddy’s girlfriend’s ass as she bent over to pick up our beer cans
column12: and I thought – “that’s what I deserve.” I’m wondering if I should break up with her because this isn’t working
column13: and it’s not like I don’t have other options.

column1: – FED-UP in FREEPORT
Dear FED-UP

Start packing her bags right now – I can’t believe you’ve dealt with her for two years! By this point she should definitely know her place. If she isn’t going to make you a sandwich and sit quietly during the game
column2: or let you go out with your bros without nagging
column3: then she isn’t the one. Look at your buddies; sounds like they’ve got their women trained perfectly! There are plenty of girls out there who have learned their lessons
column4: so just choose one of the dumb sluts you’re probably already flirting with
column5: and plug her hard. After you’ve gotten your ex out of the way
column6: make sure you tell the new girl how much you love the cheese dip your buddy’s girlfriend always brings over

column8: she’ll learn to jump right up at the sound of a crushed beer can
column9: or you can tell her where to go
column10: too.

column1: DEAR ALLISON
I hate my mother. She has the mentality of an extremely spoiled teenager in the body of an overweight
column2: pushy fifty year-old troll. She is in complete denial about all the abuse she put me through when I was growing up. She says that everything bad in her life is my fault

column5: saying that I pawned her jewelry for drugs or that I’ve prostituted myself for spare change. These lies hurt
column6: because my family and friends are now ostracizing me. I’ve never even had sex

column9: or should I just move on with my life?

DEAR MISERABLE
Judging by your letter
column2: I’d say you and your mother have more in common than you think! You must be extremely spoiled yourself. Here you are calling your mother nasty things in a massive public setting
column3: just like you say she’s done to you! Way more people will see your letter here
column4: calling your mother a fat troll
column5: than the minimal amount of friends and family members who she no doubt has on her Facebook page. How do you think she’s going to feel when she sees your letter here? Yeah
column6: probably the same way you felt when she called you a little whore. Your family probably doesn’t want to talk to you anymore because you’re the worst kind of bitch – the kind who blames everyone else around her for her own shortcomings. Plus
column7: they probably know you’ll steal their valuables for drug money next! Go to counseling with your mother. You both sound like a couple of nut jobs.

NEW YORK CITY
column2: NY –

column1: President Trump was arrested by the NYC Police Department while exiting his former residence at Trump Tower on Sunday morning
column2: according to reports from the Associated Press.

column1: Police Chief Mario Brann said that his officers were acting on an open warrant from 1998
column2: when Trump allegedly struck a pedestrian while driving through the city
column3: and left the scene. The pedestrian
column4: whose name was not released
column5: later died of their injuries.

column1: “It is with great pleasure that I announce that we have taken President Donald Trump into custody for his role in the death of a young man in 1998
column2: ” said Chief Brann. “Mr. Trump is alleged to have killed the victim in a hit-and-run accident
column3: for which he had never been charged. That changes today.”

column1: Lawyers for President Trump say that the charges are “absolutely ridiculous” and “totally absurd.”
“There is no way that he was driving through the streets of New York and killed someone
column2: ” said Richard Moorehouse
column3: a private attorney retained by the president. “President Trump cannot drive. The guy can barely navigate a golf course in a golf cart
column4: you think he has ever learned to drive an actual car? He’s a total moron. Nobody would let him behind the wheel. If this accident occurred as they say
column5: then we attest that Mr. Trump had a driver at the time
column6: and he is not guilty of anything.”

column1: “I’ve heard of people pleading insanity
column2: but I’ve never heard of anyone pleading total idiocy to get out of a crime before
column3: ” said Chief Brann. “I am intrigued to see how this plays out. Either way
column4: this gives everyone a break from Trump’s stupid goddamn tweets for a few hours.”

column1: https://newspunch.com/ex-cdc-chief-calls-delta-variant-a-heat-seeking-missile-that-targets-the-unvaxxed//Ex-CDC Chief Calls Delta Variant A ‘Heat-Seeking Missile’ That Targets The Unvaxxed/"Former CDC chief Tom Frieden was slammed on Monday after he called the Covid Delta variant a “heat-seeking missile” that targets the unvaccinated.
Frieden
column2: who served as the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) under former president Barack Obama between 2009 and 2017 said “As Delta spreads rapidly
column3: it’s acting like a heat-seeking missile targeting those who haven’t yet been vaccinated”

column1: As Delta spreads rapidly
column2: it's acting like a heat-seeking missile targeting those who haven't yet been vaccinated. — Dr. Tom Frieden (@DrTomFrieden) June 28

column1: Many ridiculed and criticized Frieden over his claim while pointing out that the Delta strain is also infecting the vaccinated.
RT reports: However
column2: it’s not what Frieden wrote – and while some rolled their eyes over the bluntness of the statement
column3: others wondered if the ex-official even understood how heat-seeking missiles and coronavirus work.

column1: Good grief. These hersterics treat diseases like monster movies. As if the Dreaded Delta is stalking you. https://t.co/kxCW2arw2o — William M Briggs (@FamedCelebrity) June 29

That’s not how “heat seeking” missiles work. The infrared seeker head hones in on a heat source (jet exhaust) and sends a signal to to the control surfaces to steer yonder missile. Then when in range (they generally aren’t direct strike) the warhead goes boom like a shotgun https://t.co/oF8BwHyLRG — Possum Bookie/Band Aid King Dempsey (@DempMcgee) June 29

Several users countered with reports that the Delta variant has been targeting those vaccinated against Covid-19 as much as it has been targeting the unvaccinated. That seems to be a picture emerging from Israel – the most-vaccinated country in the world – with Israeli Health Ministry head
column2: Chezy Levy
column3: telling the state broadcaster Kan Bet last week that up to 50% of new Delta variant cases in Israel have been recorded among vaccinated individuals. The official added that the authorities are still analyzing the actual figures
column4: but fully vaccinated Israelis who’ve come in contact with the Delta variant will be told to self-isolate.

column1: Many of the critics cited the developments in Israel as the reason they considered that Frieden’s statement clashed with reality.
50% of Delta variant cases in Israel have been in people fully vaxed.
In the UK
column2: where the Delta variant makes up more than 90% of cases
column3: 26 of 73 total deaths associated with the Delta variant were among people who had been fully vaccinated
column4: The Telegraph reported this week. — cjstova (@cjkovalic) June 28

column1: It actually appears to be targeting everyone
column2: as around 50% of the new cases in Israel are in vaccinated individuals.https://t.co/902G1QpIEU — Lisa Johnston (@LisaForKansas) June 28

column1: Delta is rife amongst the vaccinated too. — Dorian Harris (@dorianjharris) June 28

column2: Pets Should Be Given Covid Jabs/"The Labour party is urging Ministers to consider giving the coronavirus vaccine to pets once the human population has been dealt with.

column1: According to ‘experts’ vaccinating cats and dogs may help stop variants developing and spreading.
The Mirror reports: Labour’s Sir Mark Hendrick said: “Covid possibly started in bats. The priority is to vaccinate humans
column2: but a year or so down the line we have to look at animal vaccines.”

column1: And Kevin Tyler
column2: editor of journal Virulence
column3: added: “Mutations could come back into humans looking quite different.

column1: “A substantially different variant could be a problem in the future. The best way to deal with that might be vaccines.”
Animal-to-human transmission is rare – but last July a cat tested positive in the UK after catching the virus from its owner.
The British Veterinary Association recommends owners wash hands after touching pets in case the virus is on their fur.
Russia has developed the first animal-specific jab tested successfully on cats and dogs
column2: and a US firm is also working on one.

column1: Independent SAGE virologist Prof Deenan Pillay said: “It may be the current vaccines would need a tweak for nonhuman species.”"/['Niamh Harris']/2021-06-30 12:23:06+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/covid-Vaccine-for-pets-1200x630-cropped.jpg.optimal.jpg"

Frieden
column2: who served as the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) under former president Barack Obama between 2009 and 2017 said “As Delta spreads rapidly
column3: it’s acting like a heat-seeking missile targeting those who haven’t yet been vaccinated”

column1: As Delta spreads rapidly
column2: it's acting like a heat-seeking missile targeting those who haven't yet been vaccinated. — Dr. Tom Frieden (@DrTomFrieden) June 28

column1: Many ridiculed and criticized Frieden over his claim while pointing out that the Delta strain is also infecting the vaccinated.
RT reports: However
column2: it’s not what Frieden wrote – and while some rolled their eyes over the bluntness of the statement
column3: others wondered if the ex-official even understood how heat-seeking missiles and coronavirus work.

column1: Good grief. These hersterics treat diseases like monster movies. As if the Dreaded Delta is stalking you. https://t.co/kxCW2arw2o — William M Briggs (@FamedCelebrity) June 29

That’s not how “heat seeking” missiles work. The infrared seeker head hones in on a heat source (jet exhaust) and sends a signal to to the control surfaces to steer yonder missile. Then when in range (they generally aren’t direct strike) the warhead goes boom like a shotgun https://t.co/oF8BwHyLRG — Possum Bookie/Band Aid King Dempsey (@DempMcgee) June 29

Several users countered with reports that the Delta variant has been targeting those vaccinated against Covid-19 as much as it has been targeting the unvaccinated. That seems to be a picture emerging from Israel – the most-vaccinated country in the world – with Israeli Health Ministry head
column2: Chezy Levy
column3: telling the state broadcaster Kan Bet last week that up to 50% of new Delta variant cases in Israel have been recorded among vaccinated individuals. The official added that the authorities are still analyzing the actual figures
column4: but fully vaccinated Israelis who’ve come in contact with the Delta variant will be told to self-isolate.

column1: Many of the critics cited the developments in Israel as the reason they considered that Frieden’s statement clashed with reality.
50% of Delta variant cases in Israel have been in people fully vaxed.
In the UK
column2: where the Delta variant makes up more than 90% of cases
column3: 26 of 73 total deaths associated with the Delta variant were among people who had been fully vaccinated
column4: The Telegraph reported this week. — cjstova (@cjkovalic) June 28

column1: It actually appears to be targeting everyone
column2: as around 50% of the new cases in Israel are in vaccinated individuals.https://t.co/902G1QpIEU — Lisa Johnston (@LisaForKansas) June 28

column1: Delta is rife amongst the vaccinated too. — Dorian Harris (@dorianjharris) June 28
Others focused on the ex-CDC director’s scandalous past
column2: with one branding him a “heat-seeking sexual predator eyeing his prey
column3: ” in reference to Frieden pleading guilty to groping a woman without her consent in 2019. Though Frieden faced up to a year in prison at the time on charges of forcible touching

column3: that’s exactly how I look now
column4: ” Jimin said.

column3: as well

column2: ” they said of the 18 surgeries that cost more than $150

column3: ” Jimin said

column1: “Nobody would do this for attention — nobody would go through this much pain
column2: this much suffering

column3: ” they said of 18 surgeries in eight years.

column1: “I hope I can be an inspiration to others
column2: ” said Jimin
column3: who conceded that it can be “a little confusing for some people.”

column1: But anyone who has “followed my journey for the last eight years” knows “I’ve really struggled with identity issues
column2: with who I am
column3: ” they said.

column1: While they got some support online — albeit some seemingly sarcastic — the announcement sparked plenty of outrage.
“This is actually unbelievably degrading to Koreans like me if he asserts that simply getting surgery to make his eyes more slanted makes him Korean
column2: ” Kangmin Lee tweeted.

column1: “Korean isn’t a pronoun
column2: nor is it a persona you decide to suddenly take on because of kpop hype
column3: ” another Korean commentator said. “I can’t commend you for taking a whole ethnicity and treating it like a persona.”

column1: Others were especially angered when they reimagined the South Korean flag to include Pride rainbow colors.
“Playing with a flag from another country? Man. That is serious. Every flag has a history about it and he has the audacity to change it
column2: ” one person tweeted
column3: while others said it was actually a criminal offense in the country Jimin now identifies with."/['Sean Adl-Tabatabai']/2021-06-29 11:40:18+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/british-influencer.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/biological-male-is-crowned-miss-nevada-usa//Biological Male Is Crowned Miss Nevada USA/"Kataluna Enriquez
column2: a biological male
column3: has won the title of Miss Nevada USA for the first time in the pageant’s history.

column1: Enriquez won the beauty pageant on Sunday at the South Point Hotel-Casino in Las Vegas
column2: which means he will go on to represent Nevada as the first transgender person ever to compete in the Miss USA Pageant on November 29.

column1: Breitbart.com reports: Enriquez beat 21 other contestants in the Miss Nevada USA pageant
column2: according to a report by Associated Press.

column1: In March
column2: Enriquez was crowned Miss Silver State USA
column3: which is described as the “biggest preliminary competition for the Miss Nevada USA pageant.”

column1: The Las Vegas Review-Journal reports that Enriquez first took part in transgender pageants in 2016 while working as a model
column2: and started competing in women’s pageants last year.

column1: Women’s beauty pageants are not the only place where biological males are beginning to dominate.
Transgender models Valentina Sampaio and Leyna Bloom have both appeared in Sports Illustrated‘s annual Swimsuit Issue.
Chelsea Wolfe
column2: a transgender BMX freestyle rider and U.S. Olympic team alternate — who once said his goal was to win the Olympics so that he could burn the American flag on the podium — has become Team USA’s first trans athlete.

column1: Additionally
column2: a biological male named Laurel Hubbard will become the first trans athlete to compete in the Olympics. Hubbard will compete against biological females
column3: representing New Zealand in an international weightlifting competition."/['Sean Adl-Tabatabai']/2021-06-29 11:33:20+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/transgender-crowned.jpeg.optimal.jpeg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/commie-california-bans-state-travel-to-florida-over-their-anti-trans-laws//Commie California BANS State Travel to Florida Over Their ‘Anti-Trans’ Laws/"176 SHARES LinkedIn Email Reddit Telegram
California has officially banned Florida and four other states from state-funded travel due to their alleged anti-LGBTQ laws.
Democrat State Attorney General Rob Bonta announced Monday that Arkansas
column2: Montana
column3: North Dakota and West Virginia had also joined Alabama
column4: Idaho
column5: Iowa
column6: Kansas
column7: Kentucky
column8: Mississippi
column9: North Carolina
column10: Oklahoma
column11: South Carolina
column12: South Dakota
column13: Tennessee and Texas on the no-go list
column14: which was first created in 2016.

column1: “When states discriminate against LGBTQ+ Americans
column2: California law requires our office to take action
column3: ” Bonta declared.

column1: “These new additions to the state-funded travel restrictions list are about exactly that … Rather than focusing on solving real issues
column2: some politicians think it’s in their best interest to demonize trans youth and block life-saving care.

column1: “Make no mistake
column2: ” Bonta said.

column1: “We’re in the midst of an unprecedented wave of bigotry and discrimination in this country — and the State of California is not going to support it.”
Nypost.com reports: Bonta’s office cited laws enacted in Arkansas
column2: Florida
column3: Montana and West Virginia that bar transgender females from participating in girl’s school sports. North Dakota made the list due to a law that permits certain publicly-funded student organizations to prevent LGBT students from joining without losing funding.

column1: The California AG’s office also cited two other Arkansas laws. One allows medical providers to deny care to LGBTQ people if they have a “conscientious objection” to doing so
column2: while the other prohibits gender-confirming treatments or surgery for transgender youths. The latter law was passed by the state legislature earlier this year
column3: overriding the veto of Republican Gov. Asa Hutchinson.

column1: The new state travel bans go into effect July 1 for Florida and Montana
column2: July 8 for West Virginia
column3: July 29 for Arkansas
column4: and Aug. 1 for North Dakota.

column1: California’s law has exemptions for some trips
column2: such as travel needed to enforce state law and to honor contracts signed before the states were added to the list. Travel to conferences or out-of-state training are examples of trips that can be blocked.

column1: It’s unclear what effect California’s travel ban will have. Bonta did not have information about how many state agencies have stopped sending state employees to the states on the list or the financial impact of California’s travel ban on those states."/['Sean Adl-Tabatabai']/2021-06-29 11:28:21+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/newsom-bans-travel-florida.jpg.optimal.jpg"

https://newspunch.com/china-orders-citizens-to-hunt-down-all-religious-books-forces-state-church-to-sing-pro-communist-songs//China Orders Citizens To ‘Hunt Down’ All Religious Books – Forces State Church To Sing Pro-Communist Songs/"Christiantiy is under fresh assault from the Communist Chinese government
column2: with citizens now being told that they must hunt down all religious books and sing pro-communist songs when they attend church.

column1: Chinese American Pastor Bob Fu of the group China Aid
column2: tweeted last week: “New Cultural Revolution” starts in #CCPChina this notice to students in a 1st Grade class demanding all parents and teachers to hunt all “religious books
column3: antagonistic books & overseas books including books & videos that are copied/duplicated &translated”. Everyone is mandated!”

column1: “New Cultural Revolution” starts in #CCPChina this notice to students in a 1st Grade class demanding all parents and teachers to hunt all “religious books
column2: antagonistic books & overseas books including books & videos that are copied/duplicated &translated”. Everyone is mandated! pic.twitter.com/BHX4ZdPfkF — Bob Fu傅希秋 (@BobFu4China) June 25

column1: “CCP controlled ‘three-self church’ sings ‘Without the Communist Party
column2: There Would Be No New China’. The choir waves Communist Party flags on the pulpit. #Fakechurch watch the video clip here: https://youtu.be/AOVe7tddeqk via @YouTube The Lord is our Way
column3: Truth and Life. john14:6
column4: ” he said in a follow-up tweet.

column1: CCP controlled “three-self church” sings ""Without the Communist Party
column2: There Would Be No New China “The choir waves Communist Party flags on the pulpit. #Fakechurch watch the video clip here: https://t.co/YapZ3lQEZQ via @YouTube The Lord is our Way
column3: Truth and Life. john14:6 pic.twitter.com/ot4xmTZQG9 — Bob Fu傅希秋 (@BobFu4China) June 27

column1: Cbn.com reports: CBN News Senior International Correspondent Gary Lane says this is not only just another effort by the Chinese Communist Party to indoctrinate students
column2: but it’s also trying to prevent disruptions for the 2022 Winter Olympics which will be held in Beijing next February.

column1: “We’ve got an Olympics coming up and the Chinese communist government does not want any disruptions for the Olympics
column2: ” Lane said during an interview during Monday’s edition of CBN’s Newswatch. “They really fear there could be protests
column3: a pro-democracy movement going
column4: and so forth
column5: leading up to the Olympics and during the Olympics.”

column1: “So this sends a message to the parents. ‘Look
column2: no outside influence. We don’t want any collusion with foreigners here
column3: ’ because they know that foreigners are pro-democracy
column4: ” Lane explained. “And so they are indoctrinating students
column5: but they are also targeting not only the youth of China
column6: but also sending a message to the adults.”

column1: But how does this new cultural revolution differ from Mao’s cultural revolution back in the 1960s?
“Mao’s cultural revolution back in 1966 through 1979 targeted many intellectuals. Anyone that he considered to be an opponent of communism
column2: ” Lane noted. “It was very violent back then. He had youth gangs that rounded up people and they were thrown in prison. There were massacres. As many as 20 million people may have been killed by Mao during the cultural revolution.”

column1: “So this one is less violent. This one is a quiet revolution that’s happening inside China
column2: ” he said.

column1: Lane observed that a similar crackdown is happening in Hong Kong
column2: where the once-independent Apple Daily newspaper was shut down on June 24. The newspaper is no longer allowed to go to print.

column1: “Seven of their editors and leaders have been arrested for foreign collusion
column2: ” he said. “The newspaper founder
column3: Jimmy Lai was also arrested. This is very serious. A pro-democracy newspaper
column4: the lone remaining voice of democracy in Hong Kong. The editors rounded up. Founder in prison and no more printing in Hong Kong.”

column1: “This shows that the communist party is fully in control there
column2: ” Lane added. “We need to be praying for Hong Kong
column3: because one country
column4: two systems
column5: is no longer in existence.”"/['Sean Adl-Tabatabai']/2021-06-29 11:22:42+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/China-churches.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/president-trump-adam-schiff-arrested-treason//President Trump Says Adam Schiff Should Be Arrested For Treason/"President Trump has suggested Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA) should face “arrest for treason” after he “illegally made up a FAKE & terrible statement” that he read out in Congress in an attempt to frame the president.
For the second time in days
column2: President Trump has accused a Democratic member of Congress of treason
column3: escalating his attacks on those leading an impeachment inquiry against him based on a complaint lodged by a “whistleblower” with no first-hand knowledge of events.

column1: On Sunday
column2: Trump tweeted that Schiff should be “questioned at the highest level” for “treason.”

column1: Trump suggested in a tweet Monday that House Intelligence Committee Chair Adam Schiff (D-CA) should face “arrest for treason
column2: ” claiming Schiff “illegally made up a FAKE & terrible statement.”

column1: Rep. Adam Schiff illegally made up a FAKE & terrible statement
column2: pretended it to be mine as the most important part of my call to the Ukrainian President
column3: and read it aloud to Congress and the American people. It bore NO relationship to what I said on the call. Arrest for Treason? — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 30

column1: President Trump was referring to Schiff’s “analysis” of Trump’s July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Schiff misrepresented the call as a gangster-like shakedown
column2: with Trump blatantly threatening the Ukrainian president.

column1: The U.S. Constitution defines treason as waging war on the U.S. or giving “aid and comfort” to American enemies. Punishment for the crime may include the death penalty.
During a House hearing Thursday
column2: Schiff tried to ramp up criticism of President Trump portraying him as a mob boss.

column1: “It reads like a classic organized crime shakedown
column2: ” Schiff said of Trump’s call. “Shorn of its rambling character and in not so many words
column3: this is the essence of what the president communicates.”

column1: He then parodied Trump’s call in wildly inaccurate terms.
“We’ve been very good to your country
column2: very good. No other country has done as much as we have
column3: but you know what? I don’t see much reciprocity here
column4: ” Schiff said
column5: supposedly “parodying” Trump’s demands to the Ukrainian leader. “I have a favor I want from you
column6: though
column7: and I’m gonna say this only seven times
column8: so you better listen good. I want you to make up dirt on my political opponent
column9: understand
column10: lots of it.”

column1: Schiff explained he was trying to make clear what the president “was trying to communicate with the president of Ukraine.”
“This is
column2: in some character
column3: what the president was trying to communicate with the president of Ukraine
column4: ” Schiff said. “It would be funny if it wasn’t such a graphic betrayal of the president’s oath of office.”

column1: Schiff’s remarks received coverage from Fox News."/['Baxter Dmitry']/2019-09-30 19:17:54+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Trump-arrest-schiff-for-treason.jpg.optimal.jpg"

https://newspunch.com/robert-de-niro-trump-possibly-crazy-medical-sense//Robert De Niro: Trump Is Possibly ‘Crazy’ In A ‘Medical Sense’/"3.5k SHARES LinkedIn Email Reddit Telegram
President Donald Trump is possibly “crazy” in the medical sense
column2: according to Robert De Niro
column3: who provided as evidence a bizarre anecdote about the president standing in front of a helicopter and sweating without asking for a handkerchief.

column1: “When I saw him out in front of the helicopter waiting to go somewhere and talking endlessly and sweating and sweating and not even —I said
column2: this guy is not even aware of what he’s—he should at least ask somebody for a handkerchief or something and dry himself off.

column1: “There is something very strange about that
column2: ” De Niro said on CNN Sunday morning.

column1: WATCH:
CNN “Reliable Sources” host Brian Stelter then asked De Niro if he thought President Trump is an actor playing a role or “performing.”
De Niro nodded slowly before saying that “in some ways I think he is… but in some ways these other pundits on Fox are too
column2: because I can’t believe they would actually buy into this craziness.”

column1: “This guy should not be president
column2: period.”

column1: Host Brian Stelter said
column2: “When you say that
column3: folks on Fox come after you. I remember the Tony’s when he got up there and cursed.”

column1: De Niro shot back
column2: “Fuck ’em. Fuck ’em.”

column1: Stelter said in response
column2: “This is cable
column3: so it’s not an FCC violation
column4: but it’s still a Sunday morning. I do wonder why you choose to go that way.”

column1: De Niro said
column2: “In this country where this guy is like a gangster. He’s come along
column3: and he’s said things
column4: done things we say over and over again. This is terrible. We’re in a terrible situation. We’re in a terrible situation
column5: and this guy just keeps going on and on without being stopped.”"/['Baxter Dmitry']/2019-09-30 19:15:54+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/robert-de-niro-1200x630-cropped.jpg.optimal.jpg"

https://newspunch.com/president-trump-retweets-call-fire-clinton-obsessed-dr-fauci//President Trump Retweets Call to Fire Clinton-Obsessed Dr. Fauci/"President Trump retweeted a post Sunday evening that included a call for Dr. Anthony Fauci to be fired.
Fauci indirectly accused the government of ignoring his advice to institute social distancing measures in mid-February in an interview with CNN on Sunday morning
column2: claiming that lives “could have been saved.”

column1: Later that day a video from Februrary 29 resurfaced showing Fauci on the Today Show telling Americans that they did not need to alter their behavior
column2: despite the Chinese coronavirus pandemic taking hold.

column1: President Trump wrote
column2: “Sorry Fake News
column3: it’s all on tape. I banned China long before people spoke up. Thank you.” His tweet included the Today Show video of Dr. Fauci accompanied by a tweet from former GOP congressional candidate DeAnna Lorraine demanding Fauci’s resignation:

column1: “Fauci is now saying that had Trump listened to the medical experts earlier he could’ve saved more lives. Fauci was telling people on February 29th that there was nothing to worry about and it posed no threat to the US public at large. Time to #FireFauci…”
Sorry Fake News
column2: it’s all on tape. I banned China long before people spoke up. Thank you @OANN https://t.co/d40JQkUZg5 — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) April 12

column1: Today Show video of Dr. Fauci from February 29:
[‘I Love Her More Than Ever’: WikiLeaks Reveals Dr. Fauci’s Messages For Hillary Clinton]
Thegatewaypundit.com reports: Link to Today Show video dated February 29 titled Dr. Fauci on coronavirus fears: No need to change lifestyle yet
Fauci’s interview with CNN’s Jake Tapper on State of the Union from Sunday morning:
TAPPER: “You recommended social distancing guidelines in the 3rd week of February… Trump didn’t announce them until a month later. Why?”
DR. FAUCI: “It is what it is.”
TAPPER: “Would it have saved lives?”
DR. FAUCI: “OBVIOUSLY.” 😢😷💔pic.twitter.com/BS7RTa6Nw5 — The Tennessee Holler (@TheTNHoller) April 12
UPDATE: Transcript excerpt via CNN:

TAPPER: “The New York Times” reported yesterday that you and other top officials wanted to recommend social and physical distancing guidelines to President Trump as far back as the third week of February
column2: but the administration didn’t announce such guidelines to the American public until March 16
column3: almost a month later.

column1: Why?
FAUCI: You know
column2: Jake
column3: as I have said many times
column4: we look at it from a pure health standpoint. We make a recommendation. Often
column5: the recommendation is taken. Sometimes
column6: it’s not.

column1: But we — it is what it is. We are where we are right now.
TAPPER: Do you think lives could have been saved if social distancing
column2: physical distancing
column3: stay-at-home measures had started third week of February
column4: instead of mid-March?

column1: FAUCI: You know
column2: Jake
column3: again
column4: it’s the what would have
column5: what could have.

column1: It’s — it’s very difficult to go back and say that. I mean
column2: obviously
column3: you could logically say
column4: that if you had a process that was ongoing
column5: and you started mitigation earlier
column6: you could have saved lives. Obviously
column7: no one is going to deny that.

column1: But what goes into those kinds of decisions is — is complicated. But you’re right. I mean
column2: obviously
column3: if we had
column4: right from the very beginning
column5: shut everything down
column6: it may have been a little bit different.

column1: But there was a lot of pushback about shutting things down back then."/['Sean Adl-Tabatabai']/2020-04-13 11:38:18+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Trump-retweets-call-fire-dr-fauci.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/nestle-forced-to-ditch-plan-to-extract-water-in-monroe//Nestle Forced To Ditch Plans To Extract Water In Monroe/"Nestlé has been forced to ditch its plans to extract water from a spring in Monroe County
column2: Pennsylvania this week after fierce resistance from the local community

column1: The plan would have seen bottled beverage giant
column2: Nestlé Waters North America
column3: take 200
column4: 000 gallons of waterery day from the source in Kunkletown
column5: located in Eldred Township
column6: and truck it away to a nearby plant to be bottled under its Deer Park brand.

column1: Activist post reports:
The plans for the water grab
column2: helped by the municipality
column3: which may have improperly adopted a corporate-friendly ordinance
column4: had drawn the ire of many local residents
column5: who celebrated the development.

column1: “This entire village of Kunkletown came together and slayed the dragon
column2: and it’s something to be proud of
column3: ” Eldred Township resident Donna Deihl told the Allentown Morning Call.

column1: The change in plans was announced at a township supervisors meeting Wednesday
column2: during which Eric Andreus
column3: a hydrogeologist for Nestlé
column4: said (pdf) the company faced “logistical and design challenges.”

column1: He also acknowledged local opposition
column2: adding
column3: “it is clear to us that the community in Eldred Township does not believe the process around this project worked the way it was intended and that many of you have concerns about this project
column4: ” adding
column5: “We have not been successful in gaining the same acceptance here in Eldred Township as we have in other communities that host our operations.”

column1: When the announcement came
column2: “The room went crazy
column3: ” Deihl said. “We clapped
column4: we applauded
column5: standing ovation. We cried.”

column1: The latest news comes less than a month after Oregon voters in Hood River County
column2: prevented a years-long attempt by Nestlé to extract up to 100 million gallons a year of Oxbow Springs water and bottling it under the Arrowhead brand."/['Niamh Harris']/2016-06-11 18:02:28+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/stop-nestle.jpeg.optimal.jpeg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/netanyahus-household-spending-under-criminal-investigation//Netanyahu’s Household Spending Under Criminal Investigation/"A criminal investigation into suspected mismanagement in the running of the residences of prime minister
column2: Benjamin Netanyahu
column3: has been ordered by Israel’s attorney general.

column1: The attorney general’s decision on Monday came a few months after a report by the state comptroller
column2: an official watchdog agency
column3: that detailed large sums of public money spent on food
column4: furniture
column5: cleaning and gardening at the official residence of the Prime minister and his wife in Jerusalem and in their private home in the exclusive coastal city of Caesarea. Cleaning expenses in that home alone averaged more than $2
column6: 100 a month in taxpayer’s money
column7: according to the February report
column8: even though the couple only spent the occasional weekend there

column1: The Guardian reports: A report by Israel’s state auditor covering 2009-2013 said some of the taxpayer-funded running costs at the prime minister’s official and private residences were unreasonably high and called for steps to improve efficiency.
A justice ministry statement said the attorney general
column2: Yehuda Weinstein
column3: had adopted a police recommendation to investigate “a number of matters concerning the running of the prime minister’s residences”.

column1: The statement mentioned no names and a source at the state attorney’s office said there were no plans to call in Netanyahu and his wife
column2: Sara
column3: for questioning
column4: although this could not be ruled out later.

column2: Benjamin Netanyahu
column3: has been ordered by Israel’s attorney general.

column1: The attorney general’s decision on Monday came a few months after a report by the state comptroller
column2: an official watchdog agency
column3: that detailed large sums of public money spent on food
column4: furniture
column5: cleaning and gardening at the official residence of the Prime minister and his wife in Jerusalem and in their private home in the exclusive coastal city of Caesarea. Cleaning expenses in that home alone averaged more than $2
column6: 100 a month in taxpayer’s money
column7: according to the February report
column8: even though the couple only spent the occasional weekend there

column1: The Guardian reports: A report by Israel’s state auditor covering 2009-2013 said some of the taxpayer-funded running costs at the prime minister’s official and private residences were unreasonably high and called for steps to improve efficiency.
A justice ministry statement said the attorney general
column2: Yehuda Weinstein
column3: had adopted a police recommendation to investigate “a number of matters concerning the running of the prime minister’s residences”.

column1: The statement mentioned no names and a source at the state attorney’s office said there were no plans to call in Netanyahu and his wife
column2: Sara
column3: for questioning
column4: although this could not be ruled out later.

https://newspunch.com/deep-state-brennan-mourns-criminal-reckless-killing-of-iran-nuclear-scientist//Deep State Brennan Mourns ‘Criminal
column2: Reckless’ Killing of Iran Nuclear Scientist/"Deep State spy chief John Brennan on Friday angrily lashed out at the killing of the head of Iran’s nuclear program
column3: Mohsen Fakhrizadeh
column4: condemning his death as a “criminal act.”

column1: Tehran announced that Mohsen was assassinated in Damavand Friday afternoon. Footage of the incident shows two vehicles
column2: one with extensive fire damage and the other covered with bullet holes. Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif blamed Israel for the assassination.

column1: “This was a criminal act & highly reckless. It risks lethal retaliation & a new round of regional conflict
column2: ” Brennan fumed. “Iranian leaders would be wise to wait for the return of responsible American leadership on the global stage & to resist the urge to respond against perceived culprits.”

column1: This was a criminal act & highly reckless. It risks lethal retaliation & a new round of regional conflict.

Iranian leaders would be wise to wait for the return of responsible American leadership on the global stage & to resist the urge to respond against perceived culprits. https://t.co/0uZhyBTM3S — John O. Brennan (@JohnBrennan) November 27
“I do not know whether a foreign government authorized or carried out the the [sic] murder of Fakhrizadeh
column2: ” he added. “Such an act of state-sponsored terrorism would be a flagrant violation of international law & encourage more governments to carry out lethal attacks against foreign officials.”

column1: “These assassinations are far different than strikes against terrorist leaders & operatives of groups like al-Qaida & Islamic State
column2: which are not sovereign states. As illegitimate combatants under international law
column3: they can be targeted in order to stop deadly terrorist attacks
column4: ” he warned.

column1: These assassinations are far different than strikes against terrorist leaders & operatives of groups like al-Qaida & Islamic State
column2: which are not sovereign states. As illegitimate combatants under international law
column3: they can be targeted in order to stop deadly terrorist attacks. — John O. Brennan (@JohnBrennan) November 27

column1: Breitbart.com reports: Brennan is an ardent defender of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action
column2: known commonly as the Iran nuclear agreement
column3: and harshly criticized President Donald Trump for scrapping the deal in 2018.

column1: “Donald Trump simultaneously lied about the Iranian nuclear deal
column2: undermined global confidence in US commitments
column3: alienated our closest allies
column4: strengthened Iranian hawks
column5: & gave North Korea more reason to keep its nukes. This madness is a danger to our national security
column6: ” Brennan said after the president announced the U.S.’s removal from the deal.

column1: In January
column2: the U.S. killed Gen. Qassem Soleimani
column3: the head of Iran’s elite Quds Force
column4: in an airstrike at Baghdad’s international airport. At the time
column5: the Pentagon said it took out Soleimani because he “was actively developing plans to attack American diplomats and service members in Iraq and throughout the region.”"/['Niamh Harris']/2020-11-28 12:15:19+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/John-Brennan-CIA.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/centre-shuts-gate-on-bill-melinda-gates-foundation//Indian Government Shuts Gate on Bill & Melinda’s Foundation/"9 SHARES LinkedIn Email Reddit Telegram
The Indian government has severed all financial ties between the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the National Technical Advisory Group on Immunization (NTAGI)

The ‘gate’ was shut to the foundation on an immunization mission and a likely conflict of interest due to the foundations close ties with pharmaceutical companies according to a report by the Economic Times
The NTAGI
column2: which had been funded by the Gates Foundation-backed Immunization Technical Support Unit (ITSU) at the Public Health Foundation of India (PHFI)
column3: is to be fully funded by the government from now on.

column1: Business Standard reports:
The Gates Foundation-funded Immunization Technical Support Unit (ITSU) had so far served as the secretariat of NTAGI
column2: which is the country’s apex immunisation advisory body and decides on vaccines that should become part of the government’s immunisation programme. However
column3: according to the financial daily’s report
column4: the advisory body’s secretariat will now be fully funded by the government.

column1: The reason behind this shut out? The report cited possible conflict of interest arising from the foundation’s tied to pharmaceutical companies. Further
column2: the report cited sources
column3: saying that objections raised by outfits like the Swadeshi Jagran Manch also factored into the government’s decision.

column1: Conflict of interest
In March last year
column2: allegations of possible conflict of interest were raised by member of the steering group of National Health Mission against the Gates Foundation. The objections centred around the foundation paying for NTAGI’s secretariat.

column1: According to an Indian Express report
column2: the members of the steering group had communicated to the government their reservations and said that it was important to assess what affect would the fact that the secretariat staff was not paid for by the government have on the country’s vaccination policy.

column1: A steering group member
column2: according to the report
column3: said
column4: “The NTAGI secretariat has been moved out of the ministry to the office of Public Health Foundation of India and the 32 staff members in that secretariat draw their salaries from the BMGF (Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation). There is a clear conflict of interest — on one hand
column5: the BMGF funds the secretariat that is the highest decision making body in vaccines and
column6: on the other
column7: it partners the pharma industry in GAVI (Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization). This is unacceptable.”"/['Niamh Harris']/2017-02-08 22:10:17+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Bill-Gates-vaccine.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/john-kerry-says-prepare-for-new-world-order-borderless-world//John Kerry Says Prepare For New World Order ‘Borderless World’/"11 SHARES LinkedIn Email Reddit Telegram
Secretary of State John Kerry has outlined the U.S. government’s plans for a New World Order type of “borderless world
column2: ” that he says is our inevitable future.

column1: During his commencement speech at Northeastern University
column2: Kerry slammed Donald Trump for suggesting the U.S. builds a wall to keep out terrorists.

column1: Washingtonexaminer.com reports:
“Many of you were in elementary school when you learned the toughest lesson of all on 9/11
column2: ” he said. “There are no walls big enough to stop people from anywhere
column3: tens of thousands of miles away
column4: who are determined to take their own lives while they target others.”

column1: “So I think that everything that we’ve lived and learn tells us that we will never come out on top if we accept advice from sound-bite salesmen and carnival barkers who pretend the most powerful country on Earth can remain great by looking inward
column2: ” Kerry added. “And hiding behind walls at a time that technology has made that impossible to do and unwise to even attempt.”

column1: Kerry didn’t mention Trump by name
column2: but Trump has repeatedly called for a wall on the southern U.S. border
column3: and many Democrats
column4: and some Republicans
column5: have taken to calling him a carnival barker.

column1: Kerry also seemed to dismiss the importance of national borders
column2: and said technology has reshaped the world into one that the U.S. must engage at the risk of being left behind. He said Trump and others who want to look inward are making a mistake
column3: even in the face of rising tension and violence in the world.

column1: “For some people
column2: that is all they need simply to climb under the sheets
column3: close their eyes and push the world away
column4: ” Kerry said. “And shockingly
column5: we even see this attitude from some who think they ought to be entrusted with the job of managing international affairs.”

column1: “The future demands from us something more than a nostalgia for some rose-tinted version of the past that did not really exist in any case
column2: ” he said. “You’re about to graduate into a complex and borderless world.”"/['Sean Adl-Tabatabai']/2016-05-09 01:21:49+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/John-kerry-borderless-world-1200x630-cropped.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/while-america-burns-george-w-bush-praises-protestors-marching-for-better-future-lasting-peace//While America Burns
column2: George W. Bush Praises ‘Protestors’ Marching For ‘Better Future’ and ‘Lasting Peace’/"Former President George W. Bush has praised the “protesters” who he says are marching for “a better future” and “lasting peace“ while hundreds of cities across the country are engulfed in chaos and organized destruction.

column1: Bush said that he and former first lady Laura Bush were anguished by the death of George Floyd and disturbed by what they’ve seen since
column2: chiming in on the side of legitimate protests
column3: in what many are seeing as another rebuke at President Trump.

column1: ‘It is a strength when protesters
column2: protected by responsible law enforcement
column3: march for a better future
column4: ‘ Bush said.

column1: ‘But we also know that lasting peace in our communities requires truly equal justice
column2: ’ the ex-president said.

column1: He added that ‘looting is not liberation
column2: and destruction is not progress.’

column1: Former President George W. Bush has praised “protestors” who are marching for “a better future.”
DailyMail report: Trump
column2: in a tweet earlier Tuesday attacking Democratic rival Joe Biden
column3: characterized protesters as ‘anarchists
column4: looters or thugs.’

column1: Bush started out the statement by explaining his reluctance to release one.
He and the former first lady
column2: he said
column3: ‘resisted the urge to speak out
column4: because this is not the time for us to lecture.’

column1: ‘It is time for us to listen
column2: ‘ he said.

column1: But Bush also said it was time for the country to examine it’s ‘tragic failures.’
That way
column2: he said
column3: the country could find its ‘redeeming strengths
column4: ’ which among those was peaceful protests.

column1: ‘It remains a shocking failure that many African Americans
column2: especially young African American men
column3: are harassed and threatened in their own country
column4: ‘ Bush said.

column1: ‘This tragedy — in a long series of similar tragedies — raises a long overdue question: How do we end systemic racism in our society?‘ Bush asked.
Bush suggested that could happen by listening to Americans who are ‘hurting and grieving.’
‘Those who set out to silence those voices do not understand the meaning of America – or how it becomes a better place
column2: ‘ he said.

column1: Bush pointed to what he called the ‘heroes of America‘ – Frederick Douglass
column2: Harriet Tubman
column3: Abraham Lincoln
column4: Martin Luther King Jr. – and noted that they are ‘heroes of unity.’

column1: ‘Their calling has never been for the fainthearted. They often revealed the nation’s disturbing bigotry and exploitation — stains on our character sometimes difficult for the American majority to examine
column2: ’ Bush said.

column1: ‘We can only see the reality of America’s need by seeing it through the eyes of the threatened
column2: oppressed
column3: and disenfranchised
column4: ’ the ex-president added.

column1: And he suggested that’s what the country needed to do now.
‘Black people see the repeated violation of their rights without an urgent and adequate response from American institutions
column2: ’ he pointed out.

column1: ‘We serve our neighbors best when we try to understand their experience
column2: ’ he said. ‘We love our neighbors as ourselves when we treat them as equals
column3: in both protection and compassion.’"/['Baxter Dmitry']/2020-06-03 14:45:17+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/bush-minessota.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/psychic-edgar-cayce-predicted-putin-would-save-world-from-ww3//Psychic Edgar Cayce Predicted Putin Would Save Us From World War III/"One of the world’s most famous psychics
column2: Edgar Cayce
column3: predicted that Russian President Vladimir Putin would be a “force of light” in preventing World War III from occurring amid the global turmoil we see today.

column1: His predictions were made over 80 years ago in a series of “World Affairs Readings” about the future of world finance
column2: world leadership
column3: collective spirituality
column4: and the important role Russia and Vladimir Putin would play on the world’s stage.

column1: Cayce referred to Putin as being “the thorn in the side of the financial powers” who would try to organise themselves against the good of humanity in a post WWII world.
Wakingtimes.com reports:
When asked in 1932 about political and economic trends in Europe Cayce zeroed in on Russia:
Europe is as a house broken up. Some years ago there was the experience of a mighty peoples being overridden for the gratification and satisfaction of a few
column2: irrespective of any other man’s right. That peoples are going through the experience of being born again
column3: and is the thorn in the flesh to many a political and financial nation in Europe
column4: in the world… Q. What is the name of that nation referred to? A. Russia! (3976-8)” [Source]

column1: 70 years after the defeat of the Axis powers
column2: Russia has been reborn
