https://newspunch.com/two-dead-dozens-injured-as-6-7-quake-hits-greek-turkish-resorts//Two Dead
column2: Dozens Injured As 6.7 Quake Hits Greek & Turkish Resorts/"At least two people have been killed and more than a hundred injured after a powerful 6.7 magnitude earthquake struck in the Mediterranean Sea early on Friday morning.

column1: The quake struck at 1.31am local time
column2: was located off the coastal city of Bodrum in southwest Turkey and close to the Greek island of Kos
column3: triggering a mini tsunami which caused flooding in some areas.

column1: The tsunami wave was large enough to reach some hotels located along the Aegean coastline
column2: with Bodrum and Marmaris worst affected.

column1: The Mail Online reports:
The epicentre of the magnitude-6.7 quake was off Bodrum
column2: southwest Turkey
column3: with the country’s Aegean coast and Greek holiday islands including Kos and Rhodes worst affected. Tens of thousands of tourists who were forced to sleep outdoors have now been warned of possible aftershocks.

column1: Holidaymakers fled hotels in terror and some even jumped from balconies as the quake hit before running for their lives to higher ground as tsunami waves surged through beachfront resorts moments later
column2: flooding bars and restaurants
column3: carrying away cars and depositing boats in town streets.

column1: On the island of Kos
column2: where a state of emergency has been declared
column3: two male tourists – a 22-year-old from Sweden and a 39-year-old from Turkey – were killed after being crushed under a collapsed ceiling at the White Corner Club bar. Another man from Sweden has lost both of his legs
column4: police said.

column1: Parts of a historic mosque in Kos Town also came crashing down into the street and rescuers were this morning sifting through rubble looking for trapped survivors. Some 8
column2: 000 Britons are believed to be staying on the island
column3: which was also badly affected by the tsunami.

column1: In Turkey
column2: at least 70 people were admitted to hospitals in Bodrum. Video taken when the quake hit showed staff and patients at Bodrum State Hospital cowering for cover
column3: while the devastation caused a large electrical fire to break out in the city after a power pylon came crashing to the ground.

column1: Tourists were forced to flee their rooms when the quake hit at 1.31am local time (11.31pm BST). They gathered anxiously in the street
column2: and faced a sleepless night by the roadside or on beaches after they were warned not to re-enter damaged hotels."/['Niamh Harris']/2017-07-21 09:43:23+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/earthquake-1200x630-cropped.jpg.optimal.jpg"

https://newspunch.com/trump-corrupt-dnc-attempts-to-destroy-bernie-have-failed//Trump: Corrupt DNC Attempts To ‘Destroy Bernie’ Have Failed/"Donald Trump has accused the DNC of attempting to completely destroy Bernie Sanders in their pursuit of securing a Hillary Clinton nomination.

Trump took to Twitter to respond to the damning Democratic National Committee email leaks that exposed a secret plot between the DNC and Hillary Clinton to oust Sanders. Trump sympathised with Bernie saying that the Vermont Senator ought to distance himself from the Clinton campaign.
Rt.com reports:
“Leaked e-mails of DNC show plans to destroy Bernie Sanders. Mock his heritage and much more. On-line from Wikileakes [sic]
column2: really vicious. RIGGED
column3: ” tweeted the Republican nominee on Saturday afternoon.

column1: “The Wikileaks e-mail release today was so bad to Sanders that it will make it impossible for him to support her
column2: unless he is a fraud!” Trump added in another tweet.

column1: Leaked e-mails of DNC show plans to destroy Bernie Sanders. Mock his heritage and much more. On-line from Wikileakes
column2: really vicious. RIGGED — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) July 23

column1: Trump has made a concerted effort to appeal to “outsider candidates.”“The Bernie Sanders supporters are furious with the choice of Tim Kaine
column2: who represents the opposite of what Bernie stands for
column3: ” Trump tweeted earlier the same day
column4: referring to Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton’s choice for running mate.

column1: But while it is politically expedient for Trump to use Sanders to attack his direct rival Clinton
column2: the leaks have revealed several troubling instances of partisanship among senior members of the Democratic National Committee in the nearly 20
column3: 000 emails released by whistleblower site WikiLeaks on Friday.

column1: One is a suggestion to discredit Sanders after a controversial convention in Nevada in May
column2: which led to his supporters accusing the DNC of fraud and misconduct.

column1: “Wondering if there’s a good Bernie narrative for a story
column2: which is that Bernie never ever had his act together
column3: that his campaign was a mess. Specifically
column4: DWS [DNC Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz] had to call Bernie directly in order to get the campaign to do things because they’d either ignored or forgotten to something critical
column5: ” DNC Press Secretary Mark Paustenbach wrote to DNC Communications Director Luis Miranda.

column1: “It’s not a DNC conspiracy
column2: it’s because they never had their act together
column3: ” Paustenbach said.

column1: Wasserman Schultz also calls Sanders’ campaign manager Jeff Weaver
column2: an “ASS” and a “liar
column3: ” while also claiming that Sanders “someone who has never been a member of the Democratic Party and has no understanding of what we do” and confidently proclaiming that Sanders is never going to be President with a month of the primaries to go.

column1: Tim Kaine is
column2: and always has been
column3: owned by the banks. Bernie supporters are outraged
column4: was their last choice. Bernie fought for nothing! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) July 23

column1: One of the most disconcerting instances appears to be an attempt by DNC Chief Financial Officer Brad Marshall to sabotage Sanders by making his faith
column2: or rather
column3: lack of it
column4: an issue with the voters.

column1: “[F]or KY and WVA can we get someone to ask his belief. Does he believe in a God. He had skated on saying he has a Jewish heritage. I think I read he is an atheist. This could make several points difference with my peeps. My Southern Baptist peeps would draw a big difference between a Jew and an atheist
column2: ” Marshall wrote in May.

column1: Marshall told the Intercept that he says that the letter was about someone else
column2: though claims he is not sure who.

column1: “I do not recall this. I can say it would not have been Sanders. It would probably be about a surrogate
column2: ” Marshall wrote as a response.

column1: Otherwise
column2: the DNC has tried to make the issue of the emails go away by ignoring it.

column1: Jeff Weaver
column2: who judging from the emails
column3: has an antagonistic relationship with Schultz
column4: has called her a “figure of disunity” in the wake of the revelations. There has also been speculation that she will be replaced
column5: or at least sidelined at the upcoming Democratic convention in Philadelphia."/['Sean Adl-Tabatabai']/2016-07-25 07:06:26+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/Trump-DNC-screwed-Bernie-Sanders.jpg.optimal.jpg"

“Leaked e-mails of DNC show plans to destroy Bernie Sanders. Mock his heritage and much more. On-line from Wikileakes [sic]
column2: really vicious. RIGGED
column3: ” tweeted the Republican nominee on Saturday afternoon.

column1: “The Wikileaks e-mail release today was so bad to Sanders that it will make it impossible for him to support her
column2: unless he is a fraud!” Trump added in another tweet.

column1: Leaked e-mails of DNC show plans to destroy Bernie Sanders. Mock his heritage and much more. On-line from Wikileakes
column2: really vicious. RIGGED — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) July 23

column1: Trump has made a concerted effort to appeal to “outsider candidates.”“The Bernie Sanders supporters are furious with the choice of Tim Kaine
column2: who represents the opposite of what Bernie stands for
column3: ” Trump tweeted earlier the same day
column4: referring to Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton’s choice for running mate.

column1: But while it is politically expedient for Trump to use Sanders to attack his direct rival Clinton
column2: the leaks have revealed several troubling instances of partisanship among senior members of the Democratic National Committee in the nearly 20
column3: 000 emails released by whistleblower site WikiLeaks on Friday.

column1: One is a suggestion to discredit Sanders after a controversial convention in Nevada in May
column2: which led to his supporters accusing the DNC of fraud and misconduct.

column1: “Wondering if there’s a good Bernie narrative for a story
column2: which is that Bernie never ever had his act together
column3: that his campaign was a mess. Specifically
column4: DWS [DNC Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz] had to call Bernie directly in order to get the campaign to do things because they’d either ignored or forgotten to something critical
column5: ” DNC Press Secretary Mark Paustenbach wrote to DNC Communications Director Luis Miranda.

column1: “It’s not a DNC conspiracy
column2: it’s because they never had their act together
column3: ” Paustenbach said.

column1: Wasserman Schultz also calls Sanders’ campaign manager Jeff Weaver
column2: an “ASS” and a “liar
column3: ” while also claiming that Sanders “someone who has never been a member of the Democratic Party and has no understanding of what we do” and confidently proclaiming that Sanders is never going to be President with a month of the primaries to go.

column1: Tim Kaine is
column2: and always has been
column3: owned by the banks. Bernie supporters are outraged
column4: was their last choice. Bernie fought for nothing! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) July 23

column1: One of the most disconcerting instances appears to be an attempt by DNC Chief Financial Officer Brad Marshall to sabotage Sanders by making his faith
column2: or rather
column3: lack of it
column4: an issue with the voters.

column1: “[F]or KY and WVA can we get someone to ask his belief. Does he believe in a God. He had skated on saying he has a Jewish heritage. I think I read he is an atheist. This could make several points difference with my peeps. My Southern Baptist peeps would draw a big difference between a Jew and an atheist
column2: ” Marshall wrote in May.

column1: Marshall told the Intercept that he says that the letter was about someone else
column2: though claims he is not sure who.

column1: “I do not recall this. I can say it would not have been Sanders. It would probably be about a surrogate
column2: ” Marshall wrote as a response.

column1: https://newspunch.com/ebola-patients-to-be-forced-into-containment-centers-camps-will-be-guarded-by-us-military//Ebola Patients to Be Forced Into “Containment Centers” – Camps Will Be Guarded By US Military/"1 SHARE LinkedIn Email Reddit Telegram
As the media and government continue their ridiculous addiction to raising the fear factor across the globe
column2: The Washington Post has released two articles in the past week that point to a much darker and more disturbing plan that is unfolding. In an article released to The Washington Post Blog today entitled “AFRICOM’s Ebola response and the militarization of humanitarian aid” (LINK)
column3: authors Kim Yi Dionne
column4: Laura Seay and Erin McDaniel ask the question
column5: “Is a largely military response appropriate for a public health epidemic?“.

column1: Just last week
column2: The Washington Post published a lengthy article (“New effort to fight Ebola in Liberia would move infected patients out of their homes” – link) introducing the public to Ebola camps
column3: or “containment centers”
column4: that are being put into place for Ebola “victims”. The article states: “Looking for a new approach to blunt the Ebola epidemic sweeping West Africa
column5: the Liberian government
column6: the World Health Organization and their nonprofit partners here are launching an ambitious but controversial program to move infected people out of their homes and into ad hoc centers that will provide rudimentary care
column7: officials said Monday.”

column1: In the WHO’s official plan (link here)
column2: they state “(The slowing of contamination) will be done through the establishment of controlled settings
column3: called Ebola Care Units (ECU)
column4: where infected persons can be moved to so that they do not further transmit the virus within their households and communities.”

column1: Though the document does not explicitly refer to the containment centers as “camps”
column2: it goes on to describe the facilities as “simple
column3: inexpensive
column4: existing (e.g. hut) or purpose-built (e.g. tent) structures where people with Ebola infection can be housed separately from their families and community.” At first glance
column5: this may not seem that interesting to many. That is until you look into the other aspects of these facilities.

column1: In the Post article
column2: the authors bring up a salient point: “Many humanitarian actors are concerned about the militarization of aid in a variety of global contexts – some note that the presence of militaries in humanitarian crises can make humanitarian aid actors seem to favor one side of a conflict.

column1: Doing so violates two of the basic principles of ethical humanitarian aid: neutrality and impartiality. In general
column2: aid agencies are supposed to help any civilian who needs it without regard for their ethnicity
column3: religion
column4: or the “side” they might support in a conflict
column5: and most work hard to avoid even the appearance of favoring one side over another. Introducing a country’s military into a crisis can make it difficult for aid actors to appear neutral and impartial. In a worst case scenario
column6: this can put aid workers’ lives at risk.”

column1: The article ends on an interesting note
column2: directly referencing the camps: “The rhetoric framing the U.S. response to Ebola as an issue of national security – and deploying a military force to respond – raises the likelihood that the activities undertaken in the response effort could be largely obscured from those ordinary citizens.

column1: Security responses by nature are not meant to be transparent
column2: and the necessity of protecting Ebola containment facilities and health care personnel means that there will be few ways for ordinary Liberians to know exactly what is going on as facilities are constructed and put into use.”

column1: The design of the camps facilities themselves has only drawn more questions than answers. Below is the official design of the Camps:
The above graphic can be found here and was issued by the CDC
column2: WHO
column3: and Doctor’s Without Borders. The immediate contradiction between the WHO’s official document referenced above describing the facilities as “small” and “uncomplicated” is glaringly noticeable. Of note is that there is a very complicated and confusing “exit” for patients
column4: as well as double (and at times triple) fencing – raising the question “will patients actually be allowed to leave once they are placed into the camp?”.

column1: It doesn’t take much to see where this could go very wrong very fast. In the WHO’s official document
column2: they admit “Finally
column3: given that this is a new approach that has never been tried on a large scale in the past
column4: it needs to be carefully monitored and evaluated.” Given that the US and European governments are already treating the Ebola outbreak as a national security threat
column5: are these camps a small test for a much larger
column6: looming problem we may soon see at home?

column1: Only time will tell.

column1: Dr David Martin also gave us the understanding to help ‘we the people” reclaim the narrative.

“This is mRNA packaged in a fat envelope that is delivered to a cell. It is a medical device designed to stimulate the human cell into becoming a pathogen creator. It is not a vaccine. Vaccines actually are a legally defined term under public health law; they are a legally defined term under CDC and FDA standards.[1] And the vaccine specifically has to stimulate both the immunity within the person receiving it and it also has to disrupt transmission.
And that is not what this is. They (Moderna and Pfizer) have been abundantly clear in saying that the mRNA strand that is going into the cell is not to stop the transmission
column2: it is a treatment. But if it was discussed as a treatment

column4: “What other treatments are there?”

column1: The use of the term vaccine is unconscionable for both the legal definition and also it is actually the sucker punch to open and free discourse… Moderna was started as a chemotherapy company for cancer
column2: not a vaccine manufacturer for SARSCOV2. If we said we are going to give people prophylactic chemotherapy for the cancer they don’t yet have
column3: we’d be laughed out of the room because it’s a stupid idea. That’s exactly what this is. This is a mechanical device in the form of a very small package of technology that is being inserted into the human system to activate the cell to become a pathogen manufacturing site.

column1: And I refuse to stipulate in any conversations that this is in fact a vaccine issue. The only reason why the term is being used is to abuse the 1905 Jacobson case that has been misrepresented since it was written. And if we were honest with this
column2: we would actually call it what it is: it is a chemical pathogen device that is actually meant to unleash a chemical pathogen production action within a cell. It is a medical device
column3: not a drug because it meets the CDRH definition of a device. It is not a living system
column4: it is not a biologic system
column5: it is a physical technology – it happens to just come in the size of a molecular package.

column1: So
column2: we need to be really clear on making sure we don’t fall for their game. Because their game is if we talk about it as a vaccine
column3: then we are going to get into a vaccine conversation but this is not
column4: by their own admission
column5: a vaccine. As a result it must be clear to everyone listening that we will not fall for this failed definition
column6: just like we will not fall for their industrial chemical definition of health. Both of them are functionally flawed and are an implicit violation of the legal construct that is being exploited. I get frustrated when I hear activists and lawyers say
column7: “we are going to fight the vaccine”. If you stipulate it’s a vaccine
column8: you’ve already lost the battle. It’s not a vaccine. It is made to make you sick.

column1: 80% of the people exposed to SARSCOV2 are asymptomatic carriers. 80% of people who get this injected into them experience a clinical adverse event. You are getting injected with a chemical substance to induce illness
column2: not to induce an immuno-transmissive response. In other words
column3: nothing about this is going to stop you from transmitting anything. This is about getting you sick and having your own cells be the thing that get you sick.

column1: When the paymaster for the distribution of information happens to be the industry that’s doing the distributing
column2: we lose. Because the only narrative is the one that will be compensated by the people writing the check. That goes for our politicians… and our media – it has been paid for – if you follow the money you realize there is no non-conflicted voice on any network.”

If you can prove that the NIH and WHO got their treatment guidelines right
column2: you could win $2M

column1: Steve KirschMay 24
https://trialsitenews.com/if-you-can-prove-that-the-nih-and-who-got-their-treatment-guidelines-right-you-could-win-2m/

This is the second in a series of articles arguing that obeisance to constrictive evidence-based medicine (EBM) treatment protocols in a pandemic is causing an unnecessary loss of hundreds of thousands of lives.
In my previous article
column2: I showed that the current NIH and WHO treatment guidelines for fluvoxamine and ivermectin don’t fit the evidence at all. A FOR recommendation for both these drugs is a near-perfect fit to all the data.

column1: In this article
column2: I will make it clear to everyone that their recommendations are so indefensible that no qualifying enabler (see list below) will be able to come forward to support these recommendations even if I offer a million dollar incentive for them to do so.

column1: Any drug protocol used for treating COVID early must fall into one of three categories:
helpful
column2: neutral
column3: or harmful.

column1: I claim that there has been abundant evidence on the table for at least the past 7 months
column2: all in plain sight
column3: that both fluvoxamine and ivermectin when given early at an effective dose are helpful because a HELPFUL hypothesis is a near perfect fit to all the evidence and that the other two alternatives
column4: neutral or harmful
column5: don’t fit the evidence at all.

column1: To win the $1M prize
column2: all you have to do is to provide a convincing argument that the NIH or WHO NEUTRAL and AGAINST recommendations on fluvoxamine or ivermectin (existing on May 21
column3: 2021 when I am making this offer) are:

column1: more likely to fit the evidence than recommendations FOR these drugs
column2: or more likely to save more lives than recommending FOR these drugs.

column1: Either method of proof is fine: fit the facts or superior cost-benefit. You have two completely independent ways to win each prize. What could be easier?
Essentially
column2: my contest is the embodiment of the Precautionary Principle of medicine and use all the available evidence. The failure to use these sound approaches has led to the needless loss of life of millions of people. We use the precautionary principle for masks. Why aren’t we using it for safe
column3: repurposed drugs?

column1: To qualify for the prize
column2: you must be one of the key enablers of the myth:

column1: A professor at any accredited institution of higher learning anywhere in the world A licensed physician anywhere in the world An editor of any peer reviewed medical journal The executive management of Frontiers An employee of the NIH or WHO A member of the mainstream media anywhere in the world (especially in Brazil where they believe that all early treatments don’t work) including newspapers and online
column2: An elected official anywhere in the world A public health official anywhere in the world Any employee at YouTube responsible for the ridiculous YouTube policy banning videos that claim that Ivermectin is an effective treatment for COVID-19 An employee of any social network (including YouTube) who has decision authority for censoring content
column3: suspending accounts
column4: and banning groups related to ivermectin or fluvoxamine A fact checker in any country in the world especially Wikipedia editors who remove content saying that ivermectin works

column1: You must also agree to allow your submission to be made public including your name since this is a matter of great public interest. Also
column2: I request that you check that your work is correct before submitting it. For example
column3: Adrian Hernandez
column4: an open detractor of ivermectin for a year
column5: recently self-published a paper showing that ivermectin didn’t work. The authors made one tiny error: they transposed the control and ivermectin numbers from the Niaee study probably hoping that nobody would notice. People’s lives are at stake; if your entry has errors like this
column6: you will be disqualified. You only get one entry attempt per person.

column1: The first person to submit a winning entry wins the prize
column2: i.e. there will not be more than one winner per drug: $1M for ivermectin
column3: $1M for fluvoxamine. To enter
column4: submit your entry to the comments below. If I believe you met the challenge
column5: you win INSTANTLY. If you want to appeal my decision
column6: I agree we will go to JAMS where the loser will pay the fee (we’ll both put the fee as a deposit). This discourages frivolous entries and is a drop in the bucket compared to the $2M you stand to win if you think you are right.

column1: The entries must consider the 23 early treatment studies of ivermectin and the two studies of fluvoxamine including the symptom data from the Seftel study. Post your entry in the comments for all to see. I probably won’t even have to respond as other readers will tear your analysis to shreds and make a mockery of you and your attempt. Public peer review.

I am not worried about losing $2M. This is an impossible task because all but one of these studies is positive and the only negative study had a p value of .526 (which is basically no confidence whatsoever and would be tossed from any serious analysis since the p-value was so insignificant and the effect size was computed by algorithm and not directly measured). The evidence also shows that the earlier these drugs are given in adequate dosages
column2: the greater the positive effect. If the drugs are neutral or harmful
column3: that’s impossible
column4: a fact that seems to be lost on our experts from the WHO and NIH.

column1: The evidence today is simply impossible to ignore. Cases in Delhi
column2: where Ivermectin was begun on April 20
column3: dropped from 28
column4: 395 to just 2
column5: 260 on May 22. This represents an astounding 92% drop. Likewise
column6: cases in Uttar Pradesh have dropped from 37
column7: 944 on April 24 to 5
column8: 964 on May 22 – a decline of 84%. If it wasn’t the ivermectin
column9: then why aren’t the NIH and WHO all over this to find the real cause so they can let the entire world know? They aren’t investigating because they know the cause: the adoption of ivermectin. They do nothing and say nothing. It’s frustrating. More importantly
column10: it’s costing lives because doctors in many parts of the world including Brazil and Tamil Nadu continue to blindly follow the WHO advice.

column1: The purpose of this challenge is two fold:

To draw worldwide attention to the fact that none of the enablers of the NIH and WHO are able to credibly defend the indefensible recommendations of the NIH and WHO for these drugs even if offered a huge monetary incentive to do so To show that the current recommendations of these two organizations for these two drugs have cost the unnecessary loss of life of hundreds of thousands of people.
If you qualify and would like to submit an entry
column2: please message me on TrialSiteNews or DM me on twitter.

column1: The reason these absurd recommendations even exist is because the NIH and WHO insist on ignoring any evidence that is not a high quality phase 3 clinical trial published in a peer reviewed journal. Thus
column2: in their view
column3: all these drugs do nothing and since there is no benefit
column4: there is no reason to recommend the drug. This is completely outdated thinking that is inappropriate in a pandemic. They totally ignore the cost of death.

column1: If they were smart
column2: they would look at all available evidence and choose the hypothesis about each drug which is the closest match to all the observed evidence and maximizes the number of lives saved. Because they did not do that
column3: we are left with the inescapable conclusion that they aren’t very smart and that their recommendations for these drugs should be ignored. QED.

column1: Finally
column2: why are Dr. Anthony Fauci and Dr. Francis Collins still remaining silent about the NIH guidelines for these two drugs? If a computer entrepreneur from Silicon Valley can figure all this out 7 months ago that it’s virtually impossible for these two drugs not to work
column3: why can’t the NIH leadership? And apparently everyone agrees with me since there are no entries.

column1: We are also left to wonder why
column2: when David Seftel confirmed the 100% success rate in the original fluvoxamine RCT published in JAMA with a real-world study also with 100% effect size
column3: why did they just ignore it like it never happened? Why didn’t they send a team to investigate if there were any biases or confounders? Instead
column4: they just sat back and did nothing when the news came out. There was no investigation. There wasn’t even a phone call or email to the investigator. Even after 60 Minutes did a story on this miracle at the racetrack
column5: they still did nothing to investigate. They could have saved hundreds of thousands of lives if they had acted earlier on the evidence that was hiding in plain sight for at least the past 7 months.

column1: Did you ever see the movie Contagion? That was fictional
column2: but that was a very serious virus that was very contagious and deadly. If we are as inept with evidence on that one as we are on this one
column3: we will be all dead.

column1: Lastly
column2: to support my claim that this evidence has been in plain sight for over 7 months and that it was clear that the data supported action by the medical community
column3: I offer a simple example that I am intimately familiar with: my own personal efforts to get the world’s attention to both of these drugs. For example
column4: on October 17
column6: I wrote about both fluvoxamine and ivermectin in a very long article on Medium — a 23-minute read. This was followed with an email to Elemental entitled “Two drugs that can dramatically reduce the hospitalization and death rate from COVID-19… perhaps to zero” and included a link to my article. However
column7: because these recommendations were counter to the recommendations of the NIH and WHO
column8: my Medium account was suspended for life.

column1: And finally
column2: if they got it wrong on ivermectin and fluvoxamine
column3: do you think they might also have got it wrong about other drugs such as hydroxychloroquine
column4: vitamin D
column5: zinc
column6: and other early treatments too? Of course they did. See Do the NIH and WHO COVID treatment recommendations need to be fixed? and Good Science Saves Lives
column7: Bad Science Has Ruined Lives for the evidence of this. Or read this excellent article in Wired about The 60-Year-Old Scientific Screwup That Helped Covid Kill which documents how the WHO ignores expert opinion that disagrees with their narrative.

column1: The sooner these recommendations are changed
column2: the better. The drugs have been sitting on the shelf the whole time. The data has been available to the public for over 6 months. What we lack are leaders with the ability to clearly see the evidence that is hiding in plain sight. The NIH and WHO should either take my money or they should change their guidelines. Lives are at stake. What will they actually do? Answer: Absolutely nothing. And Congress is supporting this. It’s really very sad.

column1: Steve Kirsch is a high-tech serial entrepreneur based in Silicon Valley. He has been a medical philanthropist for more than 20 years. When the pandemic started
column2: he left his day job at M10 and started the COVID-19 Early Treatment Fund (CETF) which funds researchers from all over the world running outpatient clinical trials on repurposed drugs. CETF funded David Boulware’s trials on hydroxychloroquine and the Phase 2 and Phase 3 fluvoxamine trials
column3: among many other research projects. He was recently featured on 60 Minutes which highlighted his work with fluvoxamine. He has no conflicts of interest; his objective is to help save lives. In 2003
column4: Hillary Clinton presented him with a National Caring Award. He wrote this article to share some of what he has learned over the past year about the failure of evidence-based medicine during a pandemic in the hopes that people will realize their mistakes and change their views.

column1: Everyone knew that home prices were going crazy
column2: and now we have some solid numbers that are simply incredible. Home prices are rising faster than they ever have before
column3: and so if you are shopping for a home in this environment I truly feel sorry for you. In many parts of the country
column4: average hard working American families have already been completely priced out of the market. Prior to the pandemic
column5: the largest price bubbles were in major urban areas along both coasts
column6: but now desirable rural and suburban communities all over the nation are red hot. In some cases
column7: we have seen wild bidding wars that result in buyers paying more than a million dollars over asking price
column8: and this unprecedented frenzy is pushing home prices to dizzying heights.

column1: On Tuesday
column2: the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller home price data for the month of April was released
column3: and it quickly made headlines all across America…

column1: U.S. home prices jumped the most in more than 30 years in April. Nationally
column2: the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller index of property values climbed 14.6% from a year earlier
column3: according to a statement Tuesday
column4: the biggest gain in data going back to 1988. That came after 13.2% increase in March
column5: and was the 11th straight month that price gains accelerated.

column1: This particular series of data only goes back to 1988
column2: and in all that time we have never seen a rise of this magnitude.

column1: One expert that is being quoted by CNBC is calling the rise in prices “truly extraordinary”…
“April’s performance was truly extraordinary. The 14.6% gain in the National Composite is literally the highest reading in more than 30 years of S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller data
column2: ” said Craig Lazzara
column3: managing director and global head of index investment strategy at S&P Dow Jones Indices.

column4: WA

column1: Britney’s Testimony

column1: Britney’s statement began with her explaining how she was forced to go on tour in 2018. Because she was under conservatorship

column4: I couldn’t even get my own attorney. So out of fear
column5: I went ahead and I did the tour.”

column1: Back from tour

I have a (IUD) inside of myself right now so I don’t get pregnant. I wanted to take the (IUD) out so I could start trying to have another baby. But this so-called team won’t let me go to the doctor to take it out because they don’t want me to have children – any more children. So basically

SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — California added five more states
column2: including Florida
column3: to the list of places where state-funded travel is banned because of laws that discriminate against members of the LGBTQ community
column4: the state attorney general announced Monday.

column1: Democratic Attorney General Rob Bonta added Florida
column2: Arkansas
column3: Montana
column4: North Dakota and West Virginia to the list that now has 17 states where state employee travel is forbidden except under limited circumstances.

column1: “Make no mistake: We’re in the midst of an unprecedented wave of bigotry and discrimination in this country — and the State of California is not going to support it

column1: Lawmakers in 2016 banned non-essential travel to states with laws that discriminate against lesbian

column9: South Dakota
column10: Kentucky
column11: North Carolina
column12: Kansas
column13: Mississippi

column1: The five states newly added to the list have introduced bills in their legislatures this year that prevent transgender women and girls from participating in school sports consistent with their gender identity
column2: block access to health care and allow the discrimination of the LGBTQ community
column3: Bonta said.

column1: Florida

column3: Arkansas
column4: and West Virginia passed laws that prevent transgender women and girls from participating in school sports consistent with their gender identity.

column1: North Dakota signed into law a bill allowing certain publicly-funded student organizations to restrict LGBTQ students from joining without losing funding.

Arkansas passed the first law in the nation to prohibit physicians from providing gender-affirming healthcare to transgender minors — regardless of the wishes of parents or whether a physician deems such care to be medically necessary.
These lawmakers “would rather demonize trans youth than focus on solving real issues like tackling gun violence beating back this pandemic and rebuilding our economy

US Attacks Syrian-Iraq Border to Intimidate Iran
Tuesday
column2: June 29

column1: Lucas Leiroz
column2: research fellow in international law at the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro

column1: On Sunday
column2: June 27
column3: the Pentagon carried out airstrikes on the Syrian-Iraq border. According to information from Washington
column4: the attacks were directed at specific targets
column5: which would be Shiite militias supported and financed by the Iranian government. The number of victims is still uncertain
column6: but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights has said that five militiamen killed
column7: with no confirmation yet on the number of civilians affected. On the other hand
column8: Syrian state media reported that a child died and at least three people were injured.

column1: According to information from the US government itself
column2: it is known that the specific factions targeted by the attacks were the Kataeb Hizbula and Kataeb Sayyid Shuhada. Two targets were hit in Syria and one in Iraq
column3: in locations where supposedly there were strategic bases for such organizations. Despite the limited information available on the number of casualties
column4: apparently
column5: the use of force by the American military was excessive
column6: having reached civilians – which could have been avoided if the measures were taken in another way
column7: prioritizing intelligence over force.

column1: In a statement
column2: Pentagon press secretary John Kirby said: “At President Biden’s direction
column3: US military forces earlier this evening delay defensive precision airstrikes against facilities used by Iran-backed militia groups in the Iraq-Syria border region (…) As demonstrated by this evening’s strikes
column4: President Biden has been clear that he will act to protect US personnel. Given the ongoing series of attacks by Iran-backed groups targeting US interests in Iraq
column5: the President directed further military action to Disrupt and deter such attacks. We are in Iraq at the invitation of the Government of Iraq for the sole purpose of assisting the Iraqi Security Forces in their efforts to defeat ISIS. risk of escalation – but also to send a clear and unambiguous deterrent message”.

column1: Although Washington justifies the attacks under its cooperation agreement with Iraq
column2: the Iraqi government has severely condemned the Pentagon’s actions. In his social media account
column3: Yehia Rasool
column4: spokesman for Iraqi armed forces
column5: said that the American attitude was a “breach of sovereignty” – this type of comment is unusual on the part of the Iraqi government
column6: which grants great military flexibility to Washington
column7: so we can see that the attack really was an unacceptable attitude.

column1: Syria and Iran
column2: as expected
column3: also criticized the airstrike. Damascus endorsed the narrative that it was a violation of sovereignty against the states where the operations took place. In a note
column4: the Syrian government renewed “its call on the U.S. administration to respect the unity of the land and people of Syria and Iraq and to stop these attacks on the independence of the two countries immediately”. In the same vein
column5: Tehran emphasized the security instability generated by American actions. Saeed Khatibzadeh
column6: a spokesman for the Iranian Foreign Ministry
column7: said that “(…) what the United States is doing is disrupting security in the region
column8: and one of the victims of this disruption will be the United States (…) path and stop creating crises and troubles for the people of the region.”

column1: On the other hand
column2: Washington further endorsed its bellicose stance. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken commented on the case stating: “We [the American government] took a necessary
column3: appropriate
column4: deliberate action that is designed to limit the risk of escalation
column5: but also to send a clear and unambiguous deterrent message”.

column1: This message is aimed not just at the Shiite militias on Iraqi soil
column2: but at the Iranian government itself. Considering the current scenario of the Persian country
column3: with the election of Ebrahim Raisi as the new president
column4: the American action seems to be an intimidating message for no action to be taken against the American presence in the Middle East. Raisi is an ultra-conservative politician and committed to defending the traditional principles of Islamic theocracy as well as defending Tehran’s international interests. The president-elect has excellent relations with the armed forces and promises investments in defense and security. Little is known about what the new Iranian international strategy will look like with Raisi’s inauguration
column5: but the new leader is precisely expected to make even greater investments in foreign Shiite militias.

column1: Pro-Iran militias abroad are an important balancing factor in Middle East conflicts
column2: representing Tehran’s interests without generating direct Iranian military involvement. In Iraq
column3: where there is a strong Shiite presence
column4: the action of these militias allows the existence of an alternative force to both the American occupation and the expansion of terrorism. This worries the US
column5: which has its bases constantly attacked by pro-Tehran organizations. Eradicating the Shiite militias is a central objective in the American plan for that region and Raisi will certainly be an obstacle to this. So
column6: with the attacks
column7: Washington’s aim is not just to hit the bases of pro-Tehran groups
column8: but to send a message to both the current administration and the future president that any increase in support for the militias will result in more severe attacks.

column1: Iran is unlikely to be intimidated by such US measures. Indeed
column2: the brutality of the attacks could increase exponentially
column3: but Washington is unlikely to exterminate the Shiite militias
column4: as this would undermine the Iraqi government’s interests. It is also necessary to remember that
column5: with the likely approval of the end of the US authorization to use force in Iraq
column6: US troops will no longer be able to carry out attacks under the direct orders of the White House and will depend on Iraqi government approval for their actions – and the Iraqi government will not allow measures against its own sovereignty. So
column7: most likely there will be a simultaneous increase in one-off attacks like this Sunday’s and
column8: on the other hand
column9: an escalation in militias’ actions. Tensions will inevitably worsen
column10: and the hardest-hit parties will once again be Iraq and Syria.

column1: http://beforeitsnews.com/opinion-conservative/2021/06/considering-the-arizona-audit-3586386.html/Considering the Arizona Audit/"% of readers think this story is Fact. Add your two cents.
I understand that there are mixed feelings concerning this audit. Consider the following points for comments:

The liberal media is trying to make a case that this audit is not being conducted in a transparent and valid way. Their talking points have become pathetic. The audit is not to prove that Donald Trump won the state but to ensure that voter fraud will not be an issue in future elections. Does that make sense to anyone else? Panic may be setting in: Arizona’s most populous county is scrapping its voting machines and procuring new ones in the wake of the conspiracy-soaked Republican audit of last year’s ballots. More… What happens if it is shown that Arizona’s senate seat was the result of fraud? This would change the balance of power in the Senate but no one is discussing this point.
Let’s bottom line this: if the audit is fair
column2: Trump will be declared the winner in Arizona. Half of the country will use this to prove that Trump won the 2020 election. The other half of the country will ensure that nothing changes and that half controls the government
